PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Retail Trading Hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 715 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
2. That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory the present restrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia may be lifted.

3. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
4. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
5. The deregulation of trading hours would force small Retail Companies out of business.
6. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.

Your Petitioners most humbly Pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Ensure that retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory continue to be regulated by Ordinance as happened in the past.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that it is my intention on the next day of sitting, at giving notices of motion, to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, for three sitting days after today, to disallow the Building (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1982. I seek leave to make a statement.
—You ought to get yourself in order.

—Mr President, I do wish that members of the Senate would understand that when I give notice of intention to withdraw a matter it is because the Government has given in to a demand of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.
—It has considered it and agreed to it.
—I am sorry; Senator Chaney corrects me. He says the Government has considered and agreed with the Committee.
—Thank you for the explanation, Senator. There being no objection, you have leave to make a statement.

—This Ordinance absolves both the Building Controller in the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth from all liability for actions by the Controller as long as the Controller acts in good faith. The Committee was concerned that conferring such a wide immunity would alter very substantially rights at common law. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has now given the Committee an undertaking to amend this Ordinance so that liability for actions by the Controller, and other building inspectors, will be accepted by the Commonwealth. I seek leave for a more detailed explanation to be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

When giving Notice of Disallowance of the Building (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2 ) 1982 on 16 October 1982, the Committee indicated that section 7 (3A) of the Ordinance appeared to absolve the Building Controller in the Australian Capital Territory from all liability in respect of any act or thing done by him, provided that it is done in good faith. The Committee put to the Minister that the conferral of such a wide immunity on the Building Controller would alter personal legal rights under the common law very substantially.

In his response to the Committee, the Minister advised that the Committee's understanding of the effect of the Ordinance was correct, and that neither the Building Controller nor the Commonwealth was liable for the Controller's actions under the Ordinance.

As the Minister has pointed out:'' . . . public policy and principles of equity would demand that the Commonwealth be liable for any damage to persons or property arising out of the actions of the Building Controller, Deputy Building Controller or inspectors.''
The Minister has therefore given an undertaking that a further amendment to the Building Ordinance 1972 will be made to provide:

(i) immunity from legal action for the Building Controller, Deputy Building Controller and inspectors appointed under the Building Ordinance, in their personal capacity while performing their duties pursuant to the Ordinance; and
(ii) for liability for actions of these officers to be accepted by the Commonwealth.

The Minister has also indicated that the amendment will operate retrospectively to the date of effect of the Building (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1982 so that persons' rights will not be adversely affected. On the basis of this undertaking , the Committee has decided not to proceed with the Notice of Disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In answer to questions earlier this week the Minister has indicated that any proposal for the introduction of prices control is a matter for the States. Did the Government on Monday decide, as reported in the Age this morning, that the Commonwealth opposes proposals from the States for the imposition of prices control or prices surveillance? Will he indicate whether the Government will support or oppose prices control at the Premiers Conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether Senator Ray said 'did the Government make that decision on Monday' or 'if it makes that decision on Monday '. Any decision made on Monday would be a Cabinet matter and, of course, Cabinet discussions are private discussions until announcements are made. I repeat that the fact is that prices control is constitutionally a State matter and it is perfectly competent for any State to use its powers.
—You have no views on it?

—The honourable senator should allow me to decide whether or not the Government has a view. Members of the Australian Labor Party will be disconsolate this morning because it has been isolated in its opposition . Even the three Labor Premiers have found that there is merit in what we are doing and they will basically support it. Everything that the Labor Party has said in recent days has shown that it alone, of all Australians, is not willing to come into a consensus to help the people who are unemployed or who are likely to be unemployed. That is the basic fact; the Opposition is now isolated. I plead with it again to join the consensus and to try to help those who are unemployed or may become unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the specifics of the matter, the Government has made it clear, as it ought to be known to everybody, that prices control is basically a matter for the States and the States may operate as they wish in that regard. If the States believe that by applying prices control they can do some good, then they as sovereign States can take such action. It is not for us to comment on that. It is for them to make their value judgments. What we have said and what is now being recognised by every Premier of Australia, including all the Labor Premiers , is that there must be wages restraint if inflation is to be controlled, if unemployment is to be steadied down and if we are to prepare ourselves for the time in the future when the recession lifts. Against that background I would have thought that the Australian Labor Party would have cut its losses, come on side and would be supporting what is now a growing and a massive Australian consensus.

I answer the question specifically by saying that the power for prices control lies with the States. Any discussions that the Commonwealth Government has had or any statements that it has made have indicated that we recognise that it is within the competence of the States to act on prices control if they so desire. In the past the people of Australia have indicated that they do not want centralised prices control in the Commonwealth. Therefore, with respect to the indications of the people, constitutionally the States have that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can consideration be given at the Premiers Conference to granting additional relief to the many benevolent institutions whose resources are under severe stress because of the heavy demands on their services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether or not the question of the great voluntary work done by the charitable organisations should be raised at the Premiers Conference -that is a possibility because the support for those organisations is both State and Federal-I have no doubt that the Commonwealth Government and my colleague, the Minister for Social Security, will keep under very close observation the needs of those organisations. They are voluntary organisations. Their strength and their quality depend upon individual public support, both physical and financial. They must be carrying an enormous burden these days. I pay tribute to the very great work that they do. I will certainly refer the question to the Government as a whole. I am sure that Senator Chaney will be noting it.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a statement made by Mr John Stone, the permanent head of the Department of the Treasury, in response to the Government's 1977 attempt at a wages freeze. He is reported in the National Times of 28 October as saying that he regarded the exercise as 'economically irrelevant' and, further, that the 'old man'-in this instance he was referring to the former head of Treasury, Mr Wheeler-'had a rush of blood to the head' in pursuing the proposal. Has the Government received advice from Mr Stone and from Treasury with respect to its current proposal? Is it true that both Mr Stone and Treasury do not agree with the Government's view that the current proposal will work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite unaware of the authenticity or otherwise of any statement reported in any newspaper about what the Secretary to the Treasury may have said in 1978.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the sensitivity of all Australian Labor Party senators. Every newspaper is now coming fully on side with the Government against the Australian Labor Party. To answer Senator Bolkus's question specifically, Treasury has advised that it supports the Government in what it is doing. Treasury believes that the Government's action in seeking wages restraint is an effective measure in the context of 1982. I am sorry that the Australian Labor Party finds that an unhappy situation.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether any progress has been made in arrangements between the United States of America and Australia on bluetongue disease which would indicate that changes may be possible in the importation of bovine semen for introducing new blood lines into Australian beef herds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is some advantage in introducing new bovine semen to upgrade the national herd. The existence of bluetongue disease has made it difficult for people to get permission to introduce some of this semen. A fair amount of work has been done on diagnostic methods to ensure that any North American animals which donate semen for Australia, or any animals being imported from North America, are free from bluetongue disease. Although the animals have to be quarantined at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands quarantine station, the development of diagnostic methods to try to tell us whether they are free of the disease is continuing. At present bovine semen can be imported only from Canada and then only if it is from animals which were born in Canada and have been continually resident there or in another country which is free of bluetongue.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Archer's question stems from the fact that the United States is not free from this disease. I am advised that officers of the Department of Health have visited North America and have undertaken extensive consultation. They have done this with a view to assessing whether bovine semen could, with safety, be imported directly from the United States. It has not been possible up to this stage to make satisfactory arrangements. Of course, until those arrangements can be made there is no question of introducing the semen. At the same time efforts have been made to assess whether semen from American-born bulls or Canadian bulls which have visited the United States could be accepted for importation. No decision has yet been reached on that matter. I take it that until officers are quite convinced that there is no danger to the Australian herd the matter will have to be one for continuing negotiation and consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security assure the Senate that in the event of a wages pause or a wages freeze being adopted in Australia pensions and benefits will not be frozen and that benefits which are automatically adjusted will be increased next May to take into account consumer price index movements in the last half of this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for that question from Senator Colston because it gives me an opportunity to confirm what I have confirmed to a pensioner group that has made an inquiry of me and what the Treasurer has confirmed to a pensioner group which made an inquiry of him-namely, that it is no part of the Government's proposal that there should be any effect on pensions and benefits. In other words, the provisions for automatic twice-yearly indexation of pensions and benefits which determined the rises which many pensioners and beneficiaries have received over the last few weeks and which would provide a rise next May are not to be interfered with as part of this proposal. So pensioners and beneficiaries will not be affected.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that it is very much in the interests of pensioners and beneficiaries , as it is for other members of the community, that there should be the sort of wages pause which has been recommended by the Government and which is to be considered at the forthcoming Premiers Conference. Often raised in this place is the fact that when average weekly earnings are shooting ahead of the cost of living those pensioners and beneficiaries whose increases in income are restricted to cost of living adjustments suffer on a comparative basis. I believe that it is in the interests of all Australians but not least those on fixed incomes and those on pensions and benefits that the Government should pursue the course which it is currently pursuing. I hope that all honourable senators will take the opportunity, as I will, to calm any concerns which might be felt among those particularly vulnerable groups that what the Government proposes is directed to them. It is not.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he has seen the article on page 17 of yesterday's Australian Financial Review which states:

QUESTION.PARA: 'All this reds under the beds stuff gives very little credence to our friends at ASIO', said Mr Ernest Spencer, general manager of Apal Maritime Agencies, Australian agents for the Russian flag carrier, Far Eastern Shipping Company . . .

I ask: Is it a fact that there is an interchange of Russian mercantile ships' officers with naval officers? Is it a fact that all Russian mercantile officers are naval reservists? Is it a fact that all Soviet mercantile vessels and crews are engaged in gathering intelligence for the Russian Navy? Is it a fact that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever actually seen a red under a bed?

—No. I am not worried about them under the bed; I am worried about them in the Indian Ocean, the Pacific Ocean and various other places. Is it not standard practice for the Russians always to deny such claims, as their local representative has done in this article, with the words that the charges are so ridiculous that they do not deserve comment? If the answers to all those questions are yes, will the Government consider introducing legislation shortly to exclude the Russian flag carriers from the Australian coast?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I did not see the article in the Australian Financial Review, what I have always understood to be true is that all basic elements of the Russian mercantile fleet are part of the total naval-military concept of the Russian Navy. If there is need to correct that in more modern times, I will certainly get information and let the Senate know. My full understanding is that in fact the various ships, including the fishing fleets, that operate in our waters and extensively in the Indian Ocean are part of the Russian Navy. Therefore one can presume that they are part of an intelligence gathering unit. It is true, of course, that the Russian Navy today in all its elements is by far the largest and the most modern navy in the world and, if that is so, it must constitute a basic threat in any major rearmament.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is joining with the governments of the free world in attempting to get multilateral disarmament throughout the world so that people can look towards peacetime pursuits. No one wants to have permanent enmities in this world. No one wants to have to apply more and more funds to armaments. The Americans, who are second to the Russians in the strength of armaments, have found it necessary to spend more money to get parity. It is a great pity indeed that there should be an arms race in this world; nobody wants it. It is true that, under the recent regime of Brezhnev, the Russian Navy expanded enormously and has become, as I said, the largest and most significant navy in the world, with very significant elements in the Indian Ocean. As to whether, because of these things, one would move to prevent the flag carriers coming to Australia, I would imagine that the Government would not seek to do so, but I will refer that question to the Minister concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I refer to the Government's current consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission report on the orange juice industry. Is the Government aware that the National Health and Medical Research Council is developing a revised guideline defining what exactly is orange juice and that the new guideline will materially affect the cost structure of the Australian industry? Is the Government aware that the Trade Practices Commission has initiated a major investigation of the orange juice industry with a view to prosecuting up to 24 orange juice processors, and that this initiative will also result in much higher production standards and, hence, higher cost structures for the Australian industry? Can the Government assure the Senate that the cost impacts of these independent initiatives by the NH and MRC and the TPC will be fully accounted for in its consideration of the structure and level of tariff assistance to be provided to the orange growing and processing industry in Australia?

—I am sure all of those matters will be taken into account by the Government. It obviously is concerned with the interests of both consumers and growers who can be affected by such inquiries. I must say it is a mark of the complicated world in which we live that even the certainty of what one is drinking in the morning is absent. I note with some trepidation the sorts of statistics raised by the honourable senator. While I am on my feet may I refer to the question asked by Senator Colston and advise the Senate that I issued a Press release on 16 November confirming the facts. I will make further reference to Senator Robertson's question at a later time so that he does not feel put upon.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COST OF LABOUR: EFFECT ON EMPLOYMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The causes of Australia's unemployment problem are varied, as are its solutions. It seems to me that a very real contribution to the solution could be made both in the short term and in the long term if we were to look seriously at ridding ourselves of overtime and penalty rates, seeking a five-day working week in which weekends were no longer seen as different from other days from an employment point of view, accepting permanent part time work as part of the normal structure and, finally, abolishing the 17 1/2 per cent loading on holiday pay. Could the Minister indicate the sorts of savings these initiatives may involve and the consequent boost to employment opportunities in commercial, industrial and tertiary areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Scott has orally raised this matter with me on a couple of occasions and the point that he makes in asking that question is, of course, a valid one. The cost of labour is affected by penalty rates. If the cost of labour is a factor in what employment there is, the relationship is established. The Government certainly believes that penalty rates are inhibiting employment opportunities generally and that their removal would boost employment opportunities.

ANSWER.PARA: The available evidence, which I sought because of Senator Scott raising this matter with me, is that in fact work or employment outside normal hours has contracted. The proportion of employees who work in the evening or night in their main job fell from about 25 per cent in November 1976 to about 20 per cent in early 1981. The proportion of people who work on Sundays fell from 9 per cent to 7 per cent in the same period. I have not been able to obtain full information on all of the matters raised by Senator Scott. However, available information suggests that higher penalty rate payments are incurred in the entertainment, accommodation, hospitality and community services areas, in retailing, transport and agriculture, in the manufacture of food, beverages and tobacco and in mining. Tentative estimates suggest that penalty payments comprise 10 per cent to 20 per cent of total wages in the entertainment, accommodation and hospitality sector and 4.5 per cent to 9 per cent of total costs. The percentages in the other sectors identified are below that.

At a time when excessive labour costs are having their effect on employment, if we could get a reduction in costs that obviously would make a contribution to improving employment opportunities. I do not think it is possible to give a quantitative figure, but I think that must be so. There have been expressions of concern on behalf of the Government by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. But, of course, in Australia the determination of wages and employment conditions is a matter in part for agreement between the employer and the employees and in part for decision by arbitral tribunals. The Commonwealth does not have the direct constitutional power to alter these conditions in general. But, in terms of creating greater employment opportunities in Australia, certainly the matters raised by Senator Scott have merit as matters which could expand employment across a range of industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of an article in today's Daily Telegraph by the former Treasurer, Sir William McMahon, headed 'Tax on cheques ''self-defeating'' '? Whether she is or not, does she agree with Sir William that the proposed Commonwealth taxes on bank cheque accounts will push up substantially the cost of operating personal cheque accounts-by 100 per cent in some cases-that this will lead to many accounts being closed and a retrograde shift back to cash payments and tax evasion which the Commonwealth Government has gone to great lengths to destroy; and that the tax is a multiple tax since sales tax and other levies are already included in the price of the goods being paid for by cheque? In the light of those comments by no less a person than a former Treasurer of this Government, is the Minister prepared to support a move by the Australian Democrats to have the bank account debits tax legislation referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for further investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the article written by Sir William McMahon but I can assure the Senate that the Government would not accept the recommendation of the Australian Democrats that the Bill, which is one of the Budget Bills, be referred to a Senate standing committee for consideration. The Bill is clear, as will be shown when it is debated in this place. If the Democrats choose to delay the passage of one of the Bills to raise revenue for the Budget by suggesting that it will result in such an increase in the cost of transactions or in a reversion to the cash economy, I think that when the Bill is debated in this place that will be shown to be an utterly spurious argument. I am not aware of the effect that Sir William McMahon has attributed to the passage of the Bill but the measure provides for the imposition of only a very small charge on banking transactions. To suggest that it will increase costs or have any other effect overlooks, I think, its provisions, which we will debate probably next week.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It concerns the predicament of workers in some industries, notably the coal industry in the Burragorang Valley. Miners there wish to protect the jobs of their fellow workers. They have negotiated a four-day working week in return for a promise that 170 of their members will not be retrenched. They have been told by their Federal union that, despite the workers being 500-odd versus eight in favour of their plan, the Federal union will step in and prohibit them from carrying out their agreement. I ask: Firstly , what are the rights of rank and file union members in these circumstances? Secondly, does this incident strengthen the need for voluntary unionism, as proposed by the Government in a Bill introduced this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing to hear of a Federal union taking the attitude which has been described by Senator Walters. Clearly, where management and labour can enter into consensual arrangements which have the effect of preserving jobs and, perhaps more importantly in this case, in which the actual amount of work is not affected but its distribution among employees is, this attitude is particularly to be regretted. Where people in a work force are prepared to make common sacrifices in the common interest rather than see some of their number disappear, they are to be congratulated on putting into operation the sorts of principles to which I think the Prime Minister was appealing when he made a statement on leaving hospital. Australia is going through a difficult time. I would have thought it was a time when we should all be trying to pull in the same direction and seeking some equality of sacrifice.

ANSWER.PARA: The rights of the rank and file would probably depend upon the timing of whatever action was proposed. The rank and file would have limited opportunity to intervene in many of the union's actions. I will ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to examine the point which has been raised by Senator Walters and to give her a considered reply. The right of that particular group of unionists to interfere with the operations of the Federal officers of the union is a matter on which I have no immediate information.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. In light of the fact that the International Council for the Exploration of the Seas working group on seals accepted that there are only 380,000 to 500,000 harp seal pups produced each year, that it had insufficient information to make any estimate of the hooded seal population and that the Canadian kill quota for harp seals in 1983 will be 199,000, will the Federal Government, as a matter of urgency, take steps in international forums to ensure that these seals are protected by proposing to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora secretariat before Friday, 26 November-next Friday, the closing date for agenda items-that the hooded seal be placed in Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species and that the harp seal be placed in Appendix II at the fourth meeting of the parties to the Convention in Botswana in April 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I might be able to give some information to assist with the answer. I do not know whether Senator Peter Baume has anything he wishes to add.
—No, nothing.

— The Government has already taken steps to bring to the attention of the Canadian Government, at ministerial level, the concern which many Australians have felt in relation to the annual hunt in Canada of harp and hooded seals. When the Government reviewed the matter in August it was decided that Australia should seek to participate, as an observer, in a meeting in Copenhagen of the International Council for the Exploration of the Seas which was to examine the effect of the hunt on seal populations. The report of this meeting is now available and is being studied. Australia is in touch with Canada and with the European Commission concerning their reactions to the ICES report and in relation to recommendations for action by member countries of the European Economic Community which are under consideration. It is expected that the Government will review Australia's position again shortly and consider the need for any further action. I will refer today's question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether he wishes to take any further steps or whether there is any further information I can offer to the Senate. But in the meantime that is the position as I am presently advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I preface it by saying that no doubt the Minister is aware that most public telephones are in quite noisy areas and yet many do not have sufficient volume; so people, even those with normal hearing, can have difficulty in hearing their conversations. Will the Minister suggest to Telecom Australia that it examine this matter and, if and where necessary, include small amplifiers in public telephones to increase the volume? I might add that the problem seems more prevalent with the green Japanese imported phones than with the red phones.

—I have noticed the difficulty to which Senator Townley referred. It occurs in some areas where no cabinet is provided. It may be that one solution relates to a re-examination of the provision of cabinets to try to cut out extraneous noise. I undertake to refer to the Minister the suggestions which have been made by Senator Townley to see whether anything practical can be done to make it easier for people to gain maximum benefit from the use of public telephones.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In the September issue of Mufti Mr Bruce Ruxton, President of the Returned Services League in Victoria, claimed that up to 10 returned men were being turned away daily from the Repatriation General Hospital at Heidelberg due to a lack of facilities. Was this the case? If so, has the matter been rectified?

—All repatriation hospitals sometimes have an over-demand situation which requires an adjustment with various State community hospitals and various other organisations in order to achieve full service for veterans. However, the cases in which veterans are requested to take advantage of community facilities rather than repatriation hospitals are usually non-urgent cases and are not cases that usually cause any concern on the part of veterans or their medical advisers. I have not read the article. I assure Mr Bruce Ruxton , the Victorian President of the RSL, that regard is given to the urgency of particular cases in the event of situations arising of the kind outlined by Senator Primmer. The fact remains that the repatriation general hospitals offer outstanding service to veterans and will, of course, always meet their objective treating veterans for service-related disabilities as required by the legislation.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the new South Australian Labor Government has withdrawn from the deregulation proceedings against the Builders Labourers Federation, perhaps its first act in office? Is the Minister aware that the Deputy Premier said that the proceedings were 'obviously a political exercise', as reported in the Australian Financial Review of 16 November? Is the Minister aware of an article in the Advertiser on the following day which reported Mr Justice Sheppard as saying: 'I would have thought that this thing transcends politics'? The article also reported that the court heard evidence that John Holland Constructions Pty Ltd had borne the cost of what had been in effect a four-month delay when a concrete pour was stopped during construction at the Sydney Cricket Ground. Is the Commonwealth Government disappointed at the action taken by the South Australian Government, leaving Western Australia as the only State supporting the action? Is it a first step of the Labor Government to meet its indebtedness to unions arising out of the South Australian election campaign ?

—The question asked by Senator Hill and the terms in which he asked it really supply the answer. It is a matter of very great regret that the South Australian Government has withdrawn from that action relating to the Builders Labourers Federation. I am sure that the people of South Australia will be disappointed and that many would have wished that Mr Bannon had announced that intention before the election, instead of leaving it until after the election. I suspect, Mr President, that you will find nothing in all the public statements of the Australian Labor Party before the election in South Australia that suggested that a Labor Government would withdraw from the action. —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he or his Department is aware of the Delaware River Basin Commission in the United States of America which, like the River Murray Commission, has responsibility for a river system that passes through a number of States? Has the Minister's Department undertaken a study of the Delaware Commission's wide ranging powers, which were achieved despite similar constitutional problems to those existing in Australia? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both my Department and I are aware of the Delaware Commission. In 1972 the then Department of National Development commissioned a comparative analysis by Professor Clark, Professor of Law at the University of Melbourne, of compacts in the United States of America and Canada similar to the River Murray Waters Agreement. Professor Clark's report, completed in February 1973, included a detailed analysis of the Delaware River Basin Compact of 1961. The Delaware Commission was brought into existence through the deliberate voluntary sacrifice of sovereign rights by the respective State parties. This and other models, including the Tennessee Valley Authority, established with lesser powers by the unilateral action of the United States of America Federal Government, were examined during the negotiations between the four governments which led to a new River Murray Waters Agreement. They were all rejected as unsuitable models for the administration of the River Murray system.

ANSWER.PARA: Overseas experience has clearly indicated that the use of Federal legislation to compel co-operation has not been acceptable; available provisions have not been used nor have they been put to the constitutional test. The Tennessee Valley experiment has not been a happy one and has not been repeated either in the United States or in other federal systems. But, in any case, although I think the question is a valuable one, because the Delaware experiment is an interesting one and should have been studied as it was, the fact is that my Government and I and the States concerned are confident that the recent River Murray Waters Agreement is such that it has made very significant advances, particularly in water quality control, and that, with goodwill by all four parties to that Agreement, it can function as well as any Federal-State body controlling water anywhere in the world. I think we ought to give it a fair go. I know of and acknowledge Senator Jessop's great interest in the River Murray water, and his great desire that we should have better quality and quantity control. I am sure that with goodwill we will achieve that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — If we went further into the matter we would look at the way in which adult male wages and other wages increased during the past year. We would see the excessive wage increases that occurred during the past year when compared with inflation in the past year. If there were to be the sort of increase that occurred last year-it was 17 per cent or 18 per cent in some wage rates-we would certainly expect a reduction in that sort of increase this year and, consequently, a reduction in inflation as that effect flowed through to commodity prices.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SECONDARY SCHOOL STUDENTS: PART TIME JOBS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and refers to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report entitled ' Learning and Earning: A study of Education and Employment Opportunities for Young People' which was placed before the Senate yesterday. Is it not a fact that this report refers to the fact that academically able teenagers are, in fact, abandoning their education in the scramble for full time jobs? I refer the Minister particularly to page 71 of the report, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: To this latter group--
That is the academically able teenagers-
the current shortage of full time jobs would seem to have acted as an incentive to leave rather than to extend their education.

Is not this situation seriously exacerbated by the participation rate in the work force of secondary school students-now running at the rate of 22 per cent- those secondary school students working an average of 8.7 hours a week? Will the Minister advise the Senate of his attitude and that of the Government to this participation rate of secondary school students, its effect on education, on unemployment and on the tax burden that has to be taken up by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers? Can the Minister advise the Senate what action and what advice the Department of Education is giving to these teenagers in this situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The really important findings from this study on learning and earning relate to the fact that fewer academically able Australians are remaining in full time education than 10 years ago. If we want to get the maximum benefit out of this report we should look at that finding and work out what we can do to improve retention rates and participation rates by Australians in educational activity. We need this, of course, for national purposes to get a trained group of people to fulfil a whole range of functions in the years to come. If Senator Harradine is pursuing that kind of outcome, I think we are in agreement. His question, though, relates more specifically to the fact that many people at school undertake part time employment. They do this to get themselves some discretionary income, some pocket money, money to spend. The Government has not, in the context of the learning and earning report, paid any attention to that question raised by Senator Harradine. It really stands apart from the report. The report is about educational policy making, how we get a greater extent of participation--
—I had to use the coathanger as the hook.

—The honourable senator says that that is the hook that he hangs his question on. Nevertheless, it is an important study. It relates to participation and to retention in schools. I think if we are to get the maximum benefit we have to learn those kinds of lessons. I do not have any objection in principle to school students undertaking part time work. Whether it produces the kinds of effects which have been referred to by Senator Harradine I cannot say. But I would not be inclined to overemphasise the down side. I do not believe the participation of school kids in activities to earn themselves a bit of money will have any major effect on overall employment opportunities. I will certainly put under study the points raised by Senator Harradine. I come back to where I began: The learning and earning report is of major importance to all of us. I would like to hope that we can develop policies from it to increase student retention rates around Australia-perhaps to the level they are in the Australian Capital Territory or to double them-so we will end up with a better prepared and a better trained work force and nation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question on this very vital matter. The Minister skated around the central issue. The central issue simply is as reported in the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report in these terms :

QUESTION.PARA: Academically able teenagers are abandoning their education in the scramble for full time jobs.

One of the reasons for that is the current shortage of full time jobs. One of the reasons for the current shortage of full time jobs is the very high participation rate of school children, aged 15 years to 19 years, in the labour force occupying part time jobs which, if otherwise arranged by the employers, could provide full time job opportunities. Surely that is a question not only of academic interest but also of very important interest concerning the economy of this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the participation by school children in part time work is a major cause of a shortage of full time jobs-I am emphasising the words 'major cause'. In any event those are matters which I might refer to Mr Macphee as they fall within his area of responsibility. The question was asked of me, not surprisingly, as Minister for Education, and quite correctly, I think, I emphasised in my answer the education aspects and considerations.

—I hesitate to intervene in the debate on the education report. However, I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the Government's floating of $800m worth of bonds by tender and the anticipated interest rate rise of 1 per cent as a result of that float. I ask him, in view of the freeze which will be imposed on those who have to meet increased payments for home loans, whether the Government would not consider entering the market-place with a level of interest that would substantially freeze interest rates throughout Australia. Would the Minister not accept that it is unreasonable to impose freezes of the nature that have been suggested by Senator Scott in the Senate today-freezes on penalty rates and overtime-and agreed to by Senator Chaney? Is it not unreasonable to accept those propositions when interest rates are to be allowed to float at a higher level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges's question shows, if he will pardon my saying so, a misunderstanding of the market rate for interest. What is happening is that the Government has a deficit which it must fund. It can fund the deficit in one of two ways.
—What a deficit!

—What a deficit, yes! Not quite as large of course as Mr Hayden would have it to be and not as inflationary as Mr Hayden or Mr Hawke would have it to be, but a deficit smaller than the Labor Party asked for and larger than the Government wanted because the Government has had to enlarge its deficit due to drought relief and to increased unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue and I intend to give the answer despite the interjections because the public of Australia are entitled to know. Let the Australian Labor Party shout. Let the public understand why Labor Party senators are shouting. They are trying to stop the answer being given. A deficit can be funded in one of two ways. It can be funded by printing money which is absolutely directly inflationary or it can be funded by going to the public and asking it to subscribe to bonds and, therefore, to draw off that amount of money and thus reduce inflation. If the second course is to be taken the public must be willing, at a particular interest rate, to subscribe to those bonds. This is not a closed economy. Interest rates in Australia are influenced enormously by overseas interest rates, which have been extraordinarily high. Because of those high overseas rates, if Australian interest rates are not sufficient there will be an outflow of money and the bonds will not be subscribed. Senator Georges is saying that we ought to keep interest rates down and yet the policy of his political party is to so inflate the deficit that it would either have to print money or go into the bond market in an enormous way. If it went into the bond market in an enormous way it would drive interest rates up further and further.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not possible to get bonds in Australia subscribed to by freezing interest rates. The fundamental way to get interest rates down is first of all to get inflation down. Inflation will always bear a relationship to interest rates. If interest rates are to be real, clearly they have to have a margin above the inflation rate. If Senator Georges wants to get interest rates down he must get the current level of 12 per cent inflation down so that the real margin of interest rates will fall. If he wants to do that-I have no hesitation in answering this question at length as it is a serious question-he should subscribe to the wage freeze as everybody except the Labor Party has agreed to do because that wage freeze will bear down on inflation and therefore on interest rates. I repeat: The suggestion that we should freeze interest rates comes strangely from a Labor Party that is seeking to inflate the deficit enormously and therefore to go into the bond market in an enormous way and compete for scarce money. Interest rates cannot be frozen when external forces have a major influence. If they were to be frozen there would be an outflow of capital from Australia, undersubscription of the bond market and an upward surge in inflation because we would be printing more money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Much as I hate to ask supplementary questions, I take advantage of that course in order to extend Question Time, which I believe should go longer than it has. I ask the Leader of the Government: Is he admitting that the Government is maintaining a high interest rate so as to balance its overseas deficit with hot money? Is the interest rate in Australia much higher than it is in the United States and can he explain why the interest rate in Australia has not fallen in line with interest rates in the United States? Is it not a fact that he has constantly misled the Senate as to the reason why interest rates have been maintained at that level? Is it not right that a high level of interest rates in itself is inflationary and leads to further increases in the inflation rate rather than decreases?
—Order, Senator!
—They had a debate before, so why should not I?
—Senator Georges, I merely wished to ask whether that was a supplementary question or an addition to your previous question.
—It was a supplementary question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the best of good humour, I say to the honourable senator who says that questions are far too long and should be short and pithy, that he should take note of the injunction 'Physician, heal thyself'. I say that with the best of good will and I say it because the original question deserved a full and lengthy answer and got it. Two influences force up interest rates in Australia. I itemised them. The first is the pressure of interest rates overseas -every economic commentator makes that point-and the second is the relationship between interest rates and the inflation rate. Quite clearly, if the rate of inflation were 12 per cent interest rates would be higher, otherwise they would not be real interest rates. If they were 12 per cent or lower they would be moving into the negative phase.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat, the way to keep interest rates down is to keep the deficit as small as possible. The Government has sought to do that. The Australian Labor Party argues that the Government was wrong in so doing; that the deficit the Government proposed ought to be of perhaps twice that order. We do not intend to put on the bond market and interest rates any more pressure than is necessary. Unfortunately, drought relief has added to the deficit some $350m, plus the effect of unemployment. Nobody ought to object to that. We will strive to keep the deficit within limits. The Labor Party wants the deficit to burst beyond bounds. If money cannot be raised in the bond market through an interest rate that will attract interest-nobody can force people to subscribe-we will have undersubscription. We will have to print money, which in turn will cause inflation. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to raise a point of order. Again I raise the matter of prepared questions being given to Ministers. On two occasions today I asked for documents to be tabled. It is quite clear that both the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Senator Messner knew that the questions to which I have referred would be asked. Once again they have aborted Question Time . Mr President, I ask you to take some action and have a look at this matter to see that it does not happen again.

—This matter has been raised in this place over a long period and has been discussed many times by the Senate Standing Orders Committee. The practice that has been accepted is that an honourable senator may inform a Minister that he or she seeks an answer on a certain subject.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. This matter has been considered, of course, by the Senate Standing Orders Committee. If the Australian Labor Party does not want Ministers to respond to those honourable senators who, prior to Question time, ask for information we will make it clear that we will not so respond. Not infrequently, Labor senators and the Australian Democrats inform us that they want responses to certain questions. Because we believe that they want decent, full answers to those question, we so respond to them. Clearly, it is quite vexatious for Senator McLaren constantly to rise to his feet knowing that many Labor senators follow this practice.
—I do not do so. Also, you are assuming that I know that.

—In recent days it has been proved to Senator McLaren and his colleagues that to be holier than thou is a most uncomfortable situation . Labor senators constantly ask Ministers for prepared answers. We will continue to give them for as long as we are advised by the Standing Orders Committee and the Labor Party itself that that procedure ought to be followed.

—Mr President, I wish to take up one or two of the matters raised by the Leader of the Government in speaking to the point of order. In effect, he said that if the Opposition insisted that honourable senators refrain from following the procedure that has been followed by Government senators he would refuse to answer questions asked by it. Let me make it clear that we are complaining about the abuse of procedures which was described today. Senator Messner admitted that he received notice of the question which he answered a full week ago.
—On 10 October, a month ago.
—A month ago?
—Yes, 10 October.

—Order! Senator McLaren, you have made your point. I appeal to some honourable senators in this place not to become too emotional about the issue we are discussing. It has been discussed here many times in the past. I suggest to honourable senators that they allow Senator Georges to give his response to the point of order that has been raised.

—I complain about the abuse of the procedure. What has been revealed today is a gross abuse of the procedure. In effect the Minister for Veterans' Affairs received notice of the question almost a month ago. The material was prepared possibly by an adviser in his Department. I say to you, Mr President, that that question should have been placed on the Notice Paper and answered through the Notice Paper. It was not a question that should have been asked in that way during Question Time. I am asking you, Mr President, to assess the position. Because this has been done before does not mean that it has to continue in this way. The Senate Standing Orders Committee has a responsibility in this matter. With respect I suggest to you, Mr President, that you should take it upon yourself to create new precedents for the future. Question Time has deteriorated in a way which makes it impossible for questions to be asked quickly without undue notice and to be answered reasonably and interestingly by the Ministers concerned. That is why we had the farce we had today.
—I wish to speak to the point of order. I want to say that I was misrepresented. I made no threats.
—Order! You have spoken to the point of order.
—Then I speak to the point that I was misrepresented. What I said--
—How about that! What a change!

—Order! I ask all honourable senator to keep cool in this discussion. We had a very sensible Question Time this morning. It is getting towards the end of a long week and the end of a long session. I ask all honourable senators not to spoil it in these last few moments on a matter that has been raised, as I said, many times in this place. The Leader of the Government has the call. He claims misrepresentation, a point which the Chair suggested to him in the first place. If honourable senators look to the Standing Orders they will see that leave is not required for misrepresentation. I call the Leader of the Government.

—(New South Wales-Leader of the Government in the Senate)-Mr President, Senator Georges said I had threatened the Australian Labor Party. To the contrary, I said that the Senate Standing Orders Committee and this Senate have looked at this matter and have decided that honourable senators on all sides can give notice if they so desire and that answers can be given. In fact, members of the Labor Party have given such notice before. If they do not want to do so they need not resort to that practice at all and I will be perfectly happy.

—(South Australia)-I claim to have been misrepresented by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) when he said that I was fully aware that members of my Party repeatedly gave notice of questions without notice. I am not aware that that practice is engaged in. I do not engage in it myself. I am not aware that my colleagues do it. That is the point on which I was misrepresented. If the Leader of the Government and Ministers are receiving prepared answers or prepared questions, before they answer them they ought to say: 'Senator so and so has given notice of this particular question'. Then there will be no argument.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November, Senator Sibraa asked me a question about import parity pricing. In so doing he referred speculatively to a rise in petrol prices of between 4c and 8c a litre. In my answer I stated that the Government's import parity pricing policy would remain in place and I reiterated the logic behind the policy. I did not in any way refer to a possible rise or to the possible extent of such a rise. I have nevertheless been reported in some parts of the media as appearing to be confirming that there would be a petrol price rise of 4c to 8c a litre as a consequence of our import parity pricing policy. That is wrong and it is a misinterpretation of what I said.

ANSWER.PARA: I wish to make the true position clear. The Government will maintain its import parity pricing policy. The practice under that policy is to review the price of crude oil every six months and to make any necessary adjustments to the price on 1 January and 1 July. Adjustments in the past have been down as well as up. The intent of the policy is to maintain the price of crude oil used by Australia at parity with world prices. Since 1 July, the last adjustment, the posted price of Saudi Arabian light crude-the marker crude-has remained unchanged at $US34 a barrel but the Australian dollar has depreciated against the US dollar. The price of imported crude has, in consequence and because of freight rates, risen in Australian dollar terms. I can say, however, that Senator Sibraa's guesstimates much exaggerated the position. If the present prices and exchange rates were to be used to calculate a new import parity price, this would, I am advised, result in an increase which would be somewhere within the range of less than 2c-not 4c to 8c-and slightly less than 3c a litre . I do not want to speculate on posted oil prices overseas, nor on the strength of the Australian dollar as it might be on 1 January next. That must wait.
