SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills should never have been required. They are a function of the sustained gross negligence of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and his Department, and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The sorry history of ministerial and bureaucratic sloth-what is at best sloth-is fairly well known and I do not propose to repeat it now. What is not well known is the degree to which the Government has surrendered to tax dodgers since the first version of these Bills was introduced in the Parliament on 23 September. That is not known because a slothful, negligent and incompetent Press resiled from its fundamental responsibility to report the news. With the very limited exceptions of the National Times of 26 September, the Australian Financial Review of 27 September and a feature article in the Age of last Monday, the Press-I include the electronic and the written media-has failed to report the addition to the original Bill, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill, of sub-clause (12) of clause 3, let alone the implications of that clause for the revenue, for the credibility of the Government and for the logic of its taxation policy. Sub- clause (12) decisively testifies to the corruptibility of this Government and its craven subservience to vested interests through this partial surrender to the recipients of stolen money-to use the Prime Minister's one-time term. What is sub-clause (12) of clause 3? In the reasonably simple language of the explanatory memorandum I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Sub-clause (12) is designed to ensure that the legislation will not operate to recoup unpaid company tax where the funds of a target company were removed- rendering it unable to pay tax-on the basis of an objective view as to the efficacy of a post-sale tax scheme designed to reduce or eliminate tax liability .
The second reading speech goes a little further and states:
The third category--
That is, the third category of companies-

is different, as it can fairly be put that, because the avoidance scheme could not be said to be part of the arrangement to leave the company unable to meet its tax liabilities, an element of fraud is not present.

Accordingly, there is a specific provision in the Bill to the effect that if the target company was the subject of a post-sale attempted avoidance scheme which, objectively viewed, would have had reasonable prospects of succeeding in its purpose, and the scheme is not part of, or associated with, the stripping arrangement so that the arrangement carried no purpose of rendering the company unable to pay, there will be no recoupment tax liability.

The explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech are framed in relatively simple English-relative, that is, to the lawyers' gibberish or gobbledegook in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill. The second reading speech further states:
In line with that, the recoupment legislation will also not apply where there was a pre-sale avoidance scheme--
This goes beyond the explanatory memorandum-

which, though ultimately shown to be unsuccessful, might reasonably have been expected to have worked, if at the time of the sale the commissioner had not raised an assessment rejecting the claims made under the scheme.

In simple English, what all that means is that if individual shareholders of a company with current year profits themselves put the company into a tax avoidance scheme and then kept the company, and the Commissioner of Taxation or the court struck down the avoidance scheme, those shareholders will have to pay. If they put the company into a tax avoidance scheme and then sold it to Brian Maher, or somebody like him, instead of keeping it themselves, and Brian Maher then sold it to a painter and docker, to use the shorthand term, and the Commissioner or the court then struck down the avoidance scheme, nobody has to pay the tax; nobody! On the other hand, if they sold it to Maher with the current year profit and Maher put it into an avoidance scheme and the avoidance scheme was struck down by the courts or rejected by the Commissioner, and Maher sold it to a painter and docker before that happened, again nobody pays the tax. According to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) in the House of Representatives on 28 October, and his assertion was not contradicted, clause 3 (12) merely restores the original intention of the legislation as announced by the Government on 25 July. This is very important. Mr Sainsbury said:

The other point I want to make is that clause 3 sub-clause (12) is a matter of faith by the Government on the basis that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his 25 July statement made it quite clear that this legislation was meant to catch cases of the nature of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It was well known when the first draft of the Bill came out and we examined it that there were many other cases that would be caught, cases which would extend well outside the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That was never the intention of the Government. If that had been the intention of the Government then I should think we would want to be debating that quite separately under a separate Bill. This has brought the Bill into line with the original intention.

He was referring to sub-clause 12 of clause 3. If that is correct, tax avoidance schemes, subsequently struck down, of companies which are flogged off to painters and dockers are not precluded by the 1980 Crimes (Tax Offences) Act. If Mr Sainsbury's interpretation is correct-and I stress that it was not contradicted-what is to stop somebody with a current year profit company now selling it to a new Brian Maher who puts it into a tax avoidance operation, flogs it off--

TALK.START.PARA: —Part IVA.
—I am coming to that. Sainsbury said Part IVA does not apply.
—It does now.

—Was the honourable senator not listening? Sainsbury said that the Bill in its original form would have caught cases which were not caught by the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act and therefore sub-clause (12) of clause 3 was introduced so that only those arrangements which would be caught by the 1980 amendment were in fact caught. So what we are talking about here are, according to Sainsbury's uncontradicted statements, arrangements outside the scope of the 1980 Act. If that is so, what is to stop someone with a current year profit company selling it today or next week to a new Brian Maher who puts it into an avoidance scheme which ultimately fails but, before the ultimate failure, flogs it off to a painter and docker? What is to stop anyone doing that if Sainsbury is correct?

SPEECH.PARA: A possible answer, Senator Watson, which may be tried is section 86 of the Crimes Act. But if section 86 is adequate to stop that sort of arrangement we do not need this legislation, and never did. Why, if that is the case, is not section 86 of the Crimes Act being used against all the people who indulged in these arrangements instead of a tiny fraction of them, instead of those who just sold the companies straight on to the painters and dockers without putting them through at least the pretence of a tax avoidance operation? A possible answer again for the Government might be-this was hinted at in the Treasurer's original statement of 25 July-that, yes, the money could be recovered under section 86 of the Crimes Act but it would take a long time to do this, it would be extremely difficult and we need legislation like this to get the money quickly. If that is going to be the Government's defence, it has been undermined to a very significant extent by the Government itself-firstly in giving those who actually receive assessments up to 12 months to pay the tax and secondly in reducing the interest which accrues for late payment from 30 per cent, as proposed originally , to 20 per cent. Both of those deviations from the original Government proposal will slow down the collection of whatever residual revenue will be left if the Bill in its present emasculated form is passed.

The question of illegality, fraud and illegal acts-the sorts of terms that pop up throughout speeches of Government members on this matter-is always a difficult one to handle because if the acts referred to or covered by this legislation were fraudulent and illegal at the time they took place, logically there is no need for the legislation. If it is already illegal why do we need to make it illegal twice? A review of the history of the last five or six years shows that it does not matter how many Acts there are if we have an Attorney- General and an Attorney-General's Department at the best slothful and negligent, by the most charitable assessment, and not enforcing the laws which already exist. There were always logic and credibility problems for the Government. Following the insertion of sub-clause (12) of clause 3, there is no way in which the Government can escape from the dilemmas which it has created for itself. No matter how much the Government wriggles and contorts it cannot provide a coherent rationale for this Bill. Every escape route is a blind tunnel.

The Government obviously had a good reason for deviating from the original Bill and inserting sub-clause (12) of clause 3. It did have a good reason. This is the Horgan amendment, inserted to enable Denis Horgan and other powerful Liberal Party tax dodgers to avoid repaying the money which the Prime Minister two months ago was saying they had stolen-$7m in five years. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald a couple of months ago was headed 'How Horgan Dodged $7m in Five Years'. He went on to give the details of the Metro group of companies. I say that this is the Horgan amendment because there is an account in the McCabe-Lafranchi report of the disposal of Treamog Ltd. It states:
The purchases made by Romera Fleur included the purchase of shares in a public company, Treamog Ltd.--
Sixty per cent of which was ultimately owned by Denis Horgan-
which was previously Whiteway Sign and Lighting Co. Ltd. That transaction took place on 10 August 1977. Treamog Ltd is the only public company involved in this investigation--
The McCabe-Lafranchi investigation, of course. The report continues:

In December 1976 shares in Treamog were purchased by the dealer for a total consideration of $6,180,533. Following those purchases, minority shareholders in the company still had a total of 6,064 shares. The dealer took steps to wipe out the current year profits of the company and later, on 28 February 1977, sold the shares to interests associated with Colin Coghill. Hurley alleges the company was then dividend stripped--
That is, stripped of accumulated profits-
by the Coghill organisation without regard to the interests of the minority shareholders.
The shares in Treamog were later repurchased by the dealer on 30 June 1977 and then sold to Romera Fleur on 10 August 1977.

The report goes on, but I have read the important part. The important part is that the dealer, who was Maher, purchased the company and took steps to remove the current year profits through a tax avoidance scheme. He purchased it in December. In February it was sold on to Coghill, repurchased by the dealer in June 1977 and sold to Romera Fleur, the shorthand name for the painters and dockers, on 10 August 1977. That series of transactions fits the exemption described by sub-clause (12) of clause 3.

These are some additional points. Very rarely did the Maher organisation bother to go through the exercise of putting the current year profits through some sort of tax avoidance or attempted tax avoidance arrangement. Maher's methods usually were much cruder. The second point is that Treamog was a public company, about 30 shareholders of which, incidentally, were utimately defrauded of any equity in the company because of the actions of Horgan, Maher and company. But because it was a public company there was an extra reason for being careful in the way in which the transaction was handled. There were minority shareholders who might let other people know what was going on. As it turns out, they did not, but that was an additional constraint. The very fact that it had to be sold on to Coghill to strip the accumulated profits of the company after the current year profits had been stripped means that the books had to be in reasonably good order, otherwise a number of people could have been in legal trouble. Then the company was sold back to Maher before finally being dumped on the painter and docker.
A few months ago, the Prime Minister had a very puritanical view, not only of tax evasion, but also of tax avoidance. On 30 August, he said:
In a real sense the recipients of those funds--
That is, from tax evasion or tax avoidance-
have in their hands stolen funds whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.
On 27 September, nearly a month later, he said:

It is the law together with an ethical attitude of society to the people with whom one does business, that makes this country and if we have to legislate for every wrongful act that people might have in mind, then we will be so subsumed in legislation of every kind Sir Lawrence Street and every judge in the land will have to work overtime and never get a Sunday off because so much would have to go to the courts.

That was the Fraser public posture a couple of months ago. The reality is that the Fraser Government writes a clause into this legislation which enables Denis Horgan and others to keep the money which the Prime Minister asserted a couple of months ago they had stolen. We have been given notice that Senator Crichton- Browne and others want a total surrender to the tax dodgers disguised as an innocence clause which would allow all of them to keep the stolen money forever. That will be the subject of debate in the Committee stage. In relation to the revenue implications of clause 3, the Australian Taxation Office estimates that some 700 companies would be exempted by it. That is about 15 per cent of the total. But because many of the companies exempted by that clause were big companies, the lost revenue is likely to be a great deal more than 15 per cent of the estimated loss. It is more likely to be 30 per cent. Treamog is one of the companies whose transactions will be exempted by this clause. At the time of the sale, Treamog had current year profits of $3.7m. Therefore, it had a current year tax liability of $1.7m. That is just one company; there are about 700 of them. Treamog Ltd may be the biggest; I do not know: There are probably people in the Taxation Office who do know. But it was certainly a very big company in terms of the amount of tax avoided and many of the other 700 companies, if not most of the other 700 companies are likewise large.

The Government has said that money for capital works for the relief of unemployment and the alleviation of the present disastrous slump has to be found elsewhere; it cannot be obtained by increasing the Budget deficit. It has to be found by cutting Government expenditure somewhere else. The immediate suggestion is by freezing Public Service wages. But it has probably written off $200m in revenue by the insertion of clause 3 (12). That has exactly the same effect on the deficit, ultimately, as increasing the Budget deficit by $200m to finance capital works. The Government will write off $200m of revenue to oblige Denis Horgan. It has the same effect on the deficit as spending an extra $200m on public works to alleviate unemployment. The public, of course, does not even know that this has happened. It does not know-I repeat-because of the sloth, negligence and incompetence of the Press, whose members apparently would rather devote all their time to chasing each other's early election rumours around the corridors of Parliament House than fulfil their fundamental responsibility to report the news. In the Committee stage, the Australian Labor Party will move to amend the Bill to remove clause 3 (12) from it. I trust that we will get support from the other non-Government senators.

Before commenting on the innocence clause, I refer again to the letter of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of 8 November to Mr Willis in response to an earlier inquiry from John Dawkins, who was the acting shadow Treasurer a couple of months ago. The Treasurer gives the most recent estimate of the revenue likely to be recovered by this legislation-a total of $620m. The figure keeps creeping up, which is not surprising as more information comes to light. But the point is that that letter apparently makes no allowance for the loss of revenue pursuant to the insertion in the original Bill of clause 3 (12). The letter goes on to state that there is probably $1,280m in other than current year profits in companies sent to the bottom of the Harbour-dry Slutzkins, which used to be, according to the Prime Minister, morally identical to wet Slutzkins, but since Mr John Reid was caught red-handed being involved in a dry Slutzkin, the Prime Minister says that dry Slutzkins are all right but wet Slutzkins are still thoroughly reprehensible.

Basically the argument put forward by those who support the innocence clause, is that affected by this legislation will be people who did not even know that the transactions were taking place. That may even be true. I do not think that it would be true of many, but it could be true of some. But that is not the point. They are not being subjected to any criminal sanction. All that a few of them-by no means all of them-are being asked to do is to repay the money which they should not have got in the first place. They innocently got the money and they should innocently pay it back, just like the age pensioner who might be overpaid by a clerk in the Department of Social Security and who, when that mistake is discovered, must pay the money back. I agree with that. It was not the pensioner's fault that he or she was overpaid, but the money still has to be paid back. So it should be in this case.
Lest I forget, I will move the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill which has been circulated in my name. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-

(a) condemns the abject failure of the Treasurer and the Government, knowing of the existence of straw company tax evasion schemes since at least 1978, to respond quickly and effectively to the massive tax evasion occurring through the use of such schemes;
(b) is of the opinion that the Bill is grossly inadequate in that:

(i) it deals only with company and undistributed profits tax remaining unpaid on current and prior year profits and does not recoup personal income tax lost in relation to accumulated after-tax profits disposed of by vendor shareholders in the same transactions,
(ii) fails to recoup sales tax evaded by the use of straw companies,

(iii) allows for non-recovery of a substantial proportion of the company and undistributed profits tax lost by use of the scheme because of the deliberate exclusion of an important category of use of the scheme, and
(iv) provides for more leniency to tax evaders in respect of the time allowed to pay their assessed tax irrespective of the degree of hardship being experienced;
(c) notes that because of the Bill's deficiencies the sum to be recouped will be far less than that which has been lost through straw company tax evasion schemes; and
(d) calls on the Government to amend the Bill and associated measures so as to ensure that all the tax lost through straw company schemes will be recouped'.

The Government has assiduously promoted the myth that it is tough on tax dodgers . I do not have time to quote from some of Mr O'Reilly's letters, written between the middle of 1978 and the end of 1981, but any perusal of the telephone book of documents and Mr O'Reilly's increasingly frantic appeals to the Treasurer to do something about this matter will establish beyond all doubt that this Government was not tough on tax dodgers, and the way in which it has watered down this Bill establishes that it is not tough on tax dodgers. I want to clear the Australian Taxation Office and the Commissioner of Taxation of any culpability. The only legitimate criticism in my view which can be made of the Taxation Office is that it made the mistake of trusting the Attorney-General and his Department. I guess that is a defensible sort of mistake for another government department to have made. The increasingly frantic appeals of the Commissioner of Taxation through 1978, 1979 and 1980 were futile because the Government refused to act, except in one respect. The Committee of which the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), and I believe the Treasurer, were members decided that it would cut back the staff of the Taxation Office thereby making it even harder for it to catch the limited number of tax evaders against which the state of the law, the sloth of the Treasurer the Attorney-General, and, to put it kindly, the incompetence of the Attorney- General's Department, had enabled it to act. The Taxation Office laboured under a host of difficulties that were not of its own making. The same, of course, cannot be said for the Treasurer, the Attorney-General or the Attorney-General's Department.

The fundamental reason for the Government's continuing negligence in this area is its ambivalent attitude to tax evasion. The Canberra Times of 26 November 1977 published an article headed 'Trust used to minimise tax, Anthony says'. Mr Anthony admits that he has a family trust to minimise, that is avoid, tax. The Prime Minister had a trust which he has publicly admitted he set up to avoid paying probate duty. When he abolished the trust he issued 40,000 company shares to each of his four children. I would like to know the reason for that if not to avoid taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you legislate against that?

—Against what? I do not know the precise details of that family trust. If the honourable senator will give them to me I will be glad to give a personal opinion on it. Until he does so I cannot. The Prime Minister was invited to table in the Parliament his taxation returns in exchange for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) tabling his also. I would be delighted if both of them did so but I do not think it will happen.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robertson

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, due to the imbalance between the number of speakers on the Opposition side and those on the Government side, I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Walsh be granted an extension of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the best of goodwill I say that I do not know whether this matter has been discussed with the Whips, but time after time throughout this session there has been a great imbalance in favour of Opposition speakers. In fact, often only Opposition speakers have contributed to particular debates. I do not want to refuse an extension of time but it would be courteous if these matters were discussed beforehand. Is an extension of time of five minutes suggested?
—Whatever he needs.

—The honourable senator can speak at the Committee stage of the debate. I do not want to be in any way irritant in this situation, but any speaker from the Government side could say: 'In view of the imbalance in favour of Opposition speakers on other matters, Government senators ought to be given an extension of time.' I am prepared to agree to Senator Walsh being given five minutes if he wants five minutes.

—As is usual, the statements of the Minister are not factual. There has not been anything like such an imbalance at all, and he knows it. If he checks the figures he will see that they balance out very evenly. The percentage of Opposition speakers to Government speakers is about the same as the comparative representation in the chamber and the Minister should know that. I am happy for Senator Walsh to be given five minutes. I am sure that that will be enough. Given all of the good will to which the Minister refers I suggest that Senator Walsh be granted an extra five minutes.

—Mr Deputy President, I will try to finish in less than five minutes. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak a little longer because I think this matter is quite important. Senior members of this Government have always had an ambivalent attitude to tax evasion and tax avoidance. The Prime Minister's shuffling and prevarication in the last couple of months over the retrospectively discovered differences between dry and wet Slutzkins is a case in point. In the item, to which I referred briefly, from the Canberra Times of 26 November 1977 it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, said yesterday that his family trust was used to minimise tax payments.

The Prime Minister's trust, as the Prime Minister said, was established to minimise probate duty. That is tax avoidance. The trust was ultimately abolished , he said, because probate was abolished. But then, in the case of the family company of Fraser Properties Pty Ltd, immediately after the winding up of the trust, 40,360 shares were issued to each of his four children which makes them together the majority shareholders in the company.

What of the Government's attitude and its retrospectively discovered difference between dry and wet Slutzkins? The difference was not at all apparent to the Prime Minister on 27 September or 30 August; they were all the same then. We were not ruled by mere law; we were ruled by law plus ethics, so the Prime Minister said. That was so until, of course, Mr John Reid, whom he had just appointed to head an inquiry in to the Public Service, was caught red-handed for involvement in setting up, on behalf of his mates, I know, a dry Slutzkin operation, which, on the admission of Mr Moore, avoided the payment of $45,000 in tax.

That is not the first time. There are matters on the public record for some time before that to show Mr Reid's attitude to tax evasion. For example, on 23 June 1978 the Australian reported a tax accountants' conference in Perth at which the Treasurer was condemning in public 'successive blatantly artificial schemes unrelated to financial or commercial reality.' He was condemning them publicly yet in private he was ignoring the increasingly frantic pleas of the Commissioner of Taxation to do something about it. The Australian article continued:
In response, Mr Reid, of James Hardie Asbestos Ltd, said he was disturbed at Mr Howard's comment.

Accountants should not be asked to become the ''watchdog'' of society. It was up to the framers of legislation and those in power to draft regulations that adequately managed this role rather than to criticise accountants.

The newspaper article reports that Mr Reid was loudly applauded which in Perth, the tax dodgers' capital of Australia, is not really surprising. After five years of neglect, inertia and incompetence, two months ago the Government finally moved to recover a tiny fraction of the billions of dollars of tax that had been evaded because of that negligence, inertia and incompetence. The Bill originally introduced on 23 September has now been watered down very seriously. We will seek to amend that Bill to remove the clauses which watered it down. I hope we succeed but, if we do not, we will still vote for the Bill because it is better than nothing-but only just.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the words of the second reading speech incorporated by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick), the matters to which the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Vendors) Bill 1982, the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax-Promoters) Bill 1982, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1982 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1982 relate have been the subject of considerable public and political debate. Two years ago the Parliament passed the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 which had the effect of outlawing schemes to avoid the payment of company tax by the use of straw companies and straw trusts, schemes that were designed to put a company in a position in which it would be unable to meet its debts. Although that legislation may not have been necessary-we have all read the conflicting opinions of Queen's Counsel in recent times-it was nevertheless effective. The Act was in fact one of many introduced by this Government to curb what might be called artificial schemes of tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has put through over 30 pieces of legislation directed against tax avoidance. I mention this aspect because this legislation must be considered in the context of a government that has committed itself to the task of reducing taxation avoidance. To all intents and purposes it is succeeding. Not only has it succeeded in knocking out artificially contrived schemes but also I believe it is the first government in Australia's history to attempt to wrestle with the massive evasion taking place through the cash economy by the scheme that it is proposing for deductions at source of an amount on account of tax in respect of certain payments for labour and services.

Consistent with its philosophy, which I applaud, when closing a loophole, it has not been the practice of this Government then to legislate retrospectively to recover tax previously avoided by the use of that loophole. It did not so act in relation to the 1980 Act which outlawed bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Interestingly, there was no public outcry at that time.

However, the publication in more recent times of certain reports-the McCabe- Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-has very dramatically illustrated the gross impropriety of these schemes and the very large sums avoided by companies which were ultimately scuttled. It is not suprising that both the public and the Government should be incensed that there are within the community those who are prepared to evade tax by stripping a company, transferring shares to non-existent men or men of straw and then burning, shredding or dropping to the bottom of the harbour its books and records. The Government decided in view of these particularly unsavoury circumstances and the objective that the taxation system must be seen to be acting fairly in relation to the total community, and bearing in mind the extent of the avoidance, to introduce this special recoupment legislation. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) said:

Our normal and general reluctance to introduce legislation having any retrospective element has, on this occasion, been tempered by the competing consideration of overall perceptions as to the equity and fairness of our taxation system and the distribution of the burden.

Thus, after some initial wavering, the Government acknowledged the retrospective element of the legislation and decided on the balance of principles. I respect the decision the Government reached. It is a position that I would have liked to support. Honourable senators know that on a number of occasions I have spoken of the need for fairness and equity in the taxation system. However, when I weighed the principles I reached a contrary conclusion which I intend to explain and to which I hope to persuade others. One of the great benefits of being on the Liberal side of politics is that one is not forced by the discipline of Caucus to compromise principles. In closing the second reading debate on this subject in the other place the Treasurer said:
The Liberal Party is the stronger for being able to accommodate within its ranks a healthy and honest debate on matters of principle.
Unfortunately, we will never know the true views of all honourable senators on the other side of the chamber in relation to this subject because of their limitations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are totally opposed to it, every one of us.

—We simply will not know that because once the Caucus has made its decision that decision is final. The vast proportion of the tax avoidance took place by shareholders selling their shares in companies which had an actual or contingent tax liability to a purchaser who was prepared to pay a price that did not discount the value of such shares by the contingent tax liability except by a modest sum-modest in percentage-of perhaps between 5 per cent and 20 per cent of that liability, which was then referred to as the commission. The purchaser or the promotor of the scheme then stripped the company of the commission and scuttled the shell.

SPEECH.PARA: In weighing principles it is therefore necessary to look at the position of the vendor shareholders and of the promoters, and to look at them separately. The promoter's action is clearly improper, according to all reasonable standards. Furthermore, as far as it is related to the destruction of company books and accounts, failure to lodge returns and so on, such action is illegal. It may be that the action of stripping the company of its assets and putting it in a position in which it is unable to pay its debts is also illegal. Certainly it was the advice of Mr Brinsden, Q.C., to the Commissioner of Taxation as far back as 1974 that such was the case. Certainly the potentials for both criminal and civil proceedings abound. Sections 47, 231 and 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, sections 124, 367 and 374 of the Companies Act, and section 86 of the Crimes Act, to which Senator Walsh referred, come readily to mind. It appears, however, that despite affirmative advice being given back in 1974, no such proceedings have yet been instituted.

The position of vendor shareholders is more complicated. On a very literal approach it might be said that the vendor shareholder avoided no tax at all, being protected by the corporate veil. However, the shareholder is substantially better off than if the company had paid tax and distributed profits, or even if it had not distributed profits. The ultimate financial position of the shareholder is that by converting the income profit of the company into a capital profit for himself his position is substantially improved. It is, of course, impossible to say what the motive was for the sale by each and every shareholder. It seems reasonable in the circumstances, however, to assume that the motive for many was the financial gain to the shareholder of being able to sell for a price which did not take into account anticipated company tax. The vendor must have then assumed that either the purchaser was a fool or, alternatively, that he had a means of using, offsetting or avoiding the company tax liability. I remind the Senate that before 1978 such schemes abounded.

The first question to be asked is whether the vendors acted illegally. If they were a party to the ultimate intentions of the promoter, as no doubt in some cases they were, it is very likely that they were acting illegally. Proceedings have not, however, been instituted. If they were not a party to the ultimate intentions the consensus of opinion would appear to be that they were not acting illegally. Whether the Commissioner could have set aside the transaction under section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was not tested. In these circumstances the Government decided to act to recoup that company tax which the company would have paid if it had remained in the hands of the vendor plus undistributed profit tax. From the vendor it is to recover a sum related to the consideration he has received and from the promoter that sum related to the commission he received which is fixed at 20 per cent of the total tax liability. Recoupment is to take place in transactions which relate back as far as 1972.

What is imposed is clearly a retrospective tax. A new taxation liability is imposed where it did not exist before. As a matter of principle I object to retrospective tax laws because of what I see as the inherent injustice in such laws. It is no coincidence that the Liberal Party platform is opposed to taxation adjustments having retrospective effect, that retrospective laws are prohibited by the American Constitution and, I think, also by the French Constitution and that in statutory interpretation there is a presumption that laws are not intended to have retrospective application. Together with many judicial expressions over the years they reflect the injustice that can be done to individuals by retrospective legislation. I would have thought that all honourable senators would support the rule of law-the right of certainty before the law and the reasonable expectation that the law will protect those who have acted within its confines. The importance of the need for a degree of certainty, for orderly conduct of business and individual affairs go to the heart of the argument against retrospective legislation.

I do not dispute the power of this Parliament under the Australian Constitution to pass retrospective taxation law. I have, therefore had to consider the arguments advanced by the Government as warranting such drastic action in these particular circumstances. The argument that appears to be most often put forward is that it is manifestly unjust that this avoidance should take place, that the rest of the community has as a result suffered and should be reimbursed. This fairness argument comes in different guises. Some argue that the shifting of the taxation burden by artificial schemes is unfair. Others say that the vendor is only losing a windfall profit, that he is simply holding the tax, albeit in the form of a premium. As I indicated earlier I have some sympathy with these arguments but fairness is a very subjective notion.

Is tax avoidance via the so-called artificial schemes more unfair than the use of trusts, companies, superannuation funds and partnerships to minimise tax through simple splitting methods apart from others? Is it fair to impose a recoupment tax upon a vendor shareholder because he happens to sell to a promoter who dumps the company as opposed to a promoter who succeeds in legally avoiding the tax-the lottery that the vendor appears to have faced unknown to him at the time? Is it fair when the courts have endorsed a legalistic approach and where vendors first sought legal advice which confirmed the legality of the proposed sale? Is it fair, when we are taught as a matter of law that it is the right of every person to organise his affairs to pay a minimum of taxation, that the rules should now be changed and backdated ten years? What of those people who aid and abet the cash economy-a straight fraud on the revenue? Should they not be required to repay the community? The only distinction is that it is more difficult to determine their identity. In other words, what I am saying is that fairness is a very vague concept to be weighed against what, to me, is a clear and unambiguous principle-the inherent injustice of the imposition of new obligations by retrospective taxation laws. Unfairness is not one-sided. I do not accept the argument put by Senator Walsh that the proposed law involves only recoupment and not penalty. When people organise their affairs according to the law they obviously suffer if they are asked to repay moneys years later-moneys which may have been reinvested and since lost in the current recession.
I believe it is also important to recognise that there has been a change in tax morality. Bruce Pascoe, President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, said when referring to 1978:
It is, perhaps, not going too far to say that the tax paying community in Australia almost went mad in its rush to become a party to a tax avoidance scheme.

I am not sure that the so-called new found tax morality goes much beyond artificially contrived schemes. But even at that level, is it fair to impose today's tax morality on yesterday's tax avoiders? Is it not true that if tax decisions are to be made on the basis of moral judgment about what is fair, the very need for a tax Act is negated? Is not the Government making a subjective judgment to the effect that for the past ten years some people have been morally wrong in their actions and the Government now proposes to pass retrospective legislation to correct their sins? Is not the next step to pass the role of assessing moral standards from the Parliament to the Taxation Commissioner and give him a greater discretion to impose what he sees subjectively as fair? Even Mr Justice Murphy has advised against such a step. I cannot accept the argument that it is fair because the sums concerned are large. Where is the line to be drawn? The principle is the same whether the sums are large or small. The morality of taxation within the law is a personal thing. Even the judiciary exhibits differing standards of tax morality. Viscount Simon in Latilla v. Inland Revenue Commissioners said:

Judicial dicta may be cited which point out that, however elaborate and artificial such methods may be, those who adopt them are 'entitled' to do so. There is, of course, no doubt that they are within their legal rights, but that is no reason why their efforts, or those of the professional gentlemen who assist them in the matter, should be regarded as a commendable exercise of ingenuity or as a discharge of the duties of good citizenship.
His views on tax morality are made clear. On the other hand, in Commissioner of Stamp Duties v. Byrnes, Lord MacNaughten said:
No one may act in contravention of the law. But no one is bound to leave his property at the mercy of the revenue authorities if he can legally escape their grasp.
In the same case Lord Clyde also said:

No man in this country is under the smallest obligation, moral or otherwise, so to arrange his legal relations to his business and property as to enable the inland revenue to put the largest shovel in his stores. The inland revenue is not slow to take every advantage open to it under the taxing statutes for the purpose of depleting the taxpayer's pocket . . . The taxpayer is in like manner entitled to be astute to prevent, so far as he honestly can, the depletion of his means by the inland revenue.

The attitude of those two judges also is apparently clear. The famous New South Wales Chief Justice, Sir Frederick Jordan, looked at these two conflicting views on the morality of taxation in the estate of William Vickers, deceased. He commented.

No doubt those who, like Viscount Simon, regard it as a patriotic duty to pay the largest amount of taxes lawfully exactable will so arrange their transactions as to attract a maximum of liability . . . and those who, like Lord MacNaughten . . . recognise no such duty, will order their affairs so as to incur liability for no more than is legally necessary.

In other words, the law is the law. Individual tax morality is something different. Perhaps the greatest indictment of the call for this legislation, for the call to override the principle against retrospectivity, is that we do not even know whether it is necessary. We have only just set up a special prosecutor to pursue criminal and civil remedies. It may well be that another principle is to be sacrificed unnecessarily. The Taxation Institute of Australia stated its views in a recent publication. It said:

There can never be any justification for retrospectivity of the kind proposed. Such retrospectivity seriously undermines the rule of law, which is the fundamental cornerstone of our democracy. It can and will undoubtedly be used as a precedent for further reprehensible legislation in times to come.

Such will certainly be the case if the Opposition comes to power because at least to some extent retrospectivity is within its policy. But even the Opposition has difficulty in drawing the line. When I asked Senator Walsh whether the Australian Labor Party planned to include family trusts in retrospective legislation he declined to answer. It depends on a subjective, moral judgment. I have no wish to impose my moral judgment on taxation matters upon anybody else. I do not agree with the Institute that there can never be any justification for retrospectivity, but when the claimed benefits of this Bill are weighed against the injustice of retrospectivity I find the scales firmly fall on the side of the latter.

I wish to end by referring to the need for tax reform. I have accepted before what Professor Mathews said: 'Personal income tax is a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner'. The taxation system must be seen to be fair from the outset, not retrospectively made fair. I have argued before that if it is better balanced it can be both more easily enforced and more just. The taxation consequences of a business decision should not depend upon the vehicle used, be it trust, company or partnership. Income tax rates should not be at a level which discourages initiative and incentive and encourages elaborate and contrived tax avoidance. If not anything else, this debate should be a spur to all of us to press ahead for a more equitable, simple and efficient taxation system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I admire the speech delivered by Senator Hill and agree with everything he said. I am resolutely opposed to this legislation for the reason that it is retrospective legislation.
—What does that matter?
—Senator Missen, with whom I rarely disagree, wishes to challenge the statement that this is retrospective legislation. The second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Our normal and general reluctance to introduce taxation legislation having any retrospective element has, on this occasion, been tempered by the competing consideration of overall perceptions as to the equity and fairness of our taxation system and the distribution of the tax burden.
Let us pad away to the slips, if I can use that cricketing term, any humbug that this is not retrospective legislation. It is retrospective legislation and it is on that basis that I oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking nonsense, as usual; nobody has said it is not retrospective.
—I do not know why Senator Missen has to be so offensive. I thought I was being extraordinarily courteous.
—I didn't make the point you are trying to put in my mouth.

—If the honourable senator wants to be offensive that is his prerogative. I will not go with him down that track. He can go down that pathetic little track that he has made if he wants to. I will come back to the issue of fairness versus retrospectivity in a moment. Having stated that I am opposed to the legislation, I now state for the record, as one of the facts of life in this place: 'Be thou as pure as ice, be thou as chaste as snow, thou shalt not escape calumny'. Senator Martyr will realise in a flash that that quotation comes from Shakespeare. I am totally opposed to tax cheats and to those people who, because of their privileged position can avoid tax, whereas pay-as-you-earn wage and salary earners cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard tax evasion as, among other things, not stating income earned, understating income or overstating expenses. These are clear-cut cases of evading tax properly due. Then there is the second category of tax avoidance. I am not quite sure what 'tax avoidance' means. One can get clear examples that are quite legal and quite proper. It is not improper to avoid paying a certain amount of tax by inviting one's wife or one's brother to join in a partnership which is earning income. That is an honourable institution that goes back almost to the beginning of English law. That is a tax avoidance mechanism used in many cases. It is perfectly proper and perfectly legal. Every person who has been in business has been advised by an efficient accountant at one stage or another that when his level of income reaches a certain point it is better, for tax- purposes to form a private company than to continue paying tax as a private person or as a partnership. Quite apart from the protection that a company gives a person operating a business, that advice is normally given essentially for the purpose of minimising tax. The minimising tax and avoiding tax mean the same thing but certainly they are not illegal.

I can remember some very smart life assurance salesmen conning me 25 years ago into paying a hefty insurance premium which I certainly could not afford. But I signed on the dotted line. The thing that finally swung me was the fact that by signing a policy to mature at the age of 60 or 65, I would be receiving a handsome benefit and at the same time I would be avoiding tax. I remember the salesman's words. He said: 'If you sign this the tax man will pay half your premiums'. Are we getting to the stage where we say that that is improper? It is certainly tax avoidance. I have a great deal of confusion in my mind as to when an arrangement made by a taxpayer is proper or improper. This is where the subjectivity referred to by Senator Hill in his excellent speech becomes a problem. If we take fairness as the criterion of whether retrospective legislation should be applied, the fairness will depend on the judgment of the government, the Treasurer or the Prime Minister of the day. What might be fair to one person might not be fair to another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely the distinction is whether there is fraud?
—I thank Senator Hamer for his interjection; it is a valuable contribution. There is no question of fraud in this legislation, as I understand it.
—Bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are fraudulent.

—I acknowledge Senator Hamer's second interjection. If they were fraudulent or are fraudulent, surely there is existing law to cope with them. Fraud is an offence against existing statutes. One would not need a sledge hammer to hit the tack, namely, the retrospective legislation. I know that any true liberal-that does not only include members of the Liberal Party-is opposed to retrospective tax legislation. I know even the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is opposed to retrospectivity as a principle.

SPEECH.PARA: The third type of scheme is between evasion and avoidance. I refer to the artificial scheme. Clearly, one could say that dreadful scheme and I hope I have it right-Senator Hamer, I think, exposed this one--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not involved.

—I know that the honourable senator is not involved. I think he exposed that scheme. It had to do with works of art where a person bought a work of art overseas for, say, $10,000 and donated it to a museum. It was valued at $ 100,000 and the donor was able to claim $100,000 as a deduction off his income. That is, clearly, an artificial scheme; it is clearly a fraudulent scheme. I have no problem identifying that and saying that it should not be allowed to go on.

SPEECH.PARA: A great number of schemes are entered into which one could well argue are proper. Senator Walsh referred to the Prime Minister's family trust schemes. I have not one, but I cannot see anything terribly improper in a situation where a person is able to minimise his or her income tax. One of the great problems in this area, in my view, was caused by Sir Garfield Barwick and his then colleagues on the High Court of Australia when they virtually torpedoed the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation under section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act which in effect said that if, in the opinion of the Commissioner, a contract was entered into essentially or primarily for the purpose of escaping tax, the Commissioner had the power to declare it void. It was unfortunate that the Barwick decision torpedoed that sort of legislation.

One could argue also that the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, as we know them, no doubt were artificial and should not have been permitted. They should have been stopped as soon as they were discovered. When that was we do not know because the Government will not produce the documents to the Senate that have been asked for by Senator Evans and the Australian Democrats. We still have not given up hope of obtaining those documents, but it would seem fairly clear that as early as 1978 the present Government did know about bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and no action was taken. I suggest that this would have made it unnecessary for these particular Bills to be brought before the House.

What is a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme? I place on the record my oversimplistic concept of such a scheme. Subsequent speakers may for the record and for people who will, no doubt, devour as a study of what is right and what is wrong every word that is spoken in this debate by honourable senators correct me if I am wrong in my judgment of it. Let us assume that a man and his wife are in business and call themselves Melbourne Bakeries Pty Ltd. Let us assume that last year they made a profit of $100,000 and that a Mr Maher, or some other unscrupulous crook like him, approaches the couple who have no knowledge of law, no knowledge of tax and are barely literate; but they have run a business, the Melbourne Bakeries, for many years. The promoter gets them to sign a few documents, forms another company called Melbourne Bakehouse Pty Ltd-a company very similar in name, with the same address-and transfers all the assets, including machinery, ovens, goodwill and furniture, from Melbourne Bakeries Pty Ltd to Melbourne Bakehouse Pty Ltd. But he leaves $100,000 in the bank account of the original company, Melbourne Bakeries Pty Ltd, which fortuitously, to make the example easy, represents the profit that the couple made last year. On that $100,000, the company owes $46,000 in tax which it has not paid. Before the assessment comes in Mr Maher offers the couple $80,000 for the company. They grab the offer with alacrity because they are elderly and they see an opportunity to take $80,000 and buy a little shack at Gosford, on the Gold Coast , or in some other pleasant place, in which to live out their days.

This legislation, as I understand it, will reclaim $46,000 from that couple who did not mean to do anything crooked and who were advised correctly by their lawyer or accountant that in 1972 what they were doing was legal. Now, 10 years later, when they are 67 years of age, they suddenly receive a demand from the Australian Taxation Office to pay $46,000. The Prime Minister talks about fairness and the Treasurer talks about equity. That does not seem terribly fair to me. That is why in the Committee stage I will move an amendment-the celebrated so-called innocence clause. This clause has two components; namely, the onus will be on the taxpayers to prove, firstly, innocence and, secondly, hardship. If they can prove those two things, I believe that they ought to escape the provisions of this legislation. The bottom-of-the-harbour scheme that I have just mentioned was good for that couple because they received $80,000 for something which virtually was worth $54,000. The very good point might well be made that surely, if someone offered them an amount which was so far in excess of what the company was worth they should have smelled a rat. They should have said: 'What are you after?'. That is a fair point. But had they done so, they would have then said to their lawyer or accountant: 'Look, I don't want to do anything shady. Is this legal?' In many cases this kind of scheme was legal. There is no question at all about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it moral?

—That was a very good interjection by Senator Walters. If they did not know about the transaction what they did was not immoral; if they knew, it was immoral. I am saying that provision ought to be made for those people who did not do something which they knew to be immoral or improper but something which was legal. I do not think that the purpose of this Parliament is to legislate for morality. I do not want to score a point off Senator Walters because she and I have many tussles on the question of morality and the capacity or place of parliaments in legislating for morality. I have said for many years, since I was Minister for Customs and Excise, that parliaments cannot and should not try to legislate for morality. They should make the law and people who abide by the rule of law should be able to live unencumbered by governments or their instrumentalities. Under this arrangement the promoter does very well, too, because he obtains $100,000 cash to put in his bank account. He has paid only $ 80,000 for the company, so he is $20,000 in front. The old couple who own the bakery also do very well out of it. I have no sympathy whatsoever with the promoter in regard to what is done to him. That would be all right with me. I am worried about the innocent and the principle involved. In answer to the interjection by Senator Walters, I say that the actions of the promoters and of those who knowingly went into bottom-of-the-harbour schemes was contemptible but nevertheless legal. One asks: Why has the Fraser Government changed its attitude ? I quote the Prime Minister, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must place the principle of fairness above the principle of retrospectivity.

I think this is the crux of the debate. That is why I am indebted to Senator Hill for highlighting the fact that what constitutes fairness is a subjective judgment. I would say that in the Senate at the moment there are 10 senators. If we took a range of issues we would get 10 different opinions on what was fair and what was unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to determine it?

—I ask the honourable senator through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, who indeed is to determine it. We have changing governments and changing Prime Ministers. If we are to have changing standards of fairness, morality or whatever and legislate retrospectively to accommodate those differing definitions it will be a nightmare for anybody who lives in this country. We will not know what to do because if we do something today a future Prime Minister might say, 'That is unfair. Therefore what you did last year was unfair. We will make what you did last year punishable notwithstanding that it is legal this year.'
—Like your partnership example.

—Yes. When Senator Gietzelt's party takes office, if a local store -keeper takes his wife into partnership this year and in so doing escapes tax, will that government or some member of it say, 'That was unfair, therefore we will legislate back to the time that act was committed and make it illegal'?
—That judgment is exercised by the Taxation Office now.
—With great respect, if it is, why do we need this legislation?
—Because there are people who have contrived to bring about this situation.

—During the last elections the Australian Labor Party stated quite honestly, out in the open, that it favoured retrospectivity in regard to tax avoidance. I was forced, by a blunt question from the editor of the Australian as to whether I agreed with retrospectivity, to come out on the issue. I said no . The Labor Party was honest and, with great humility, let me say that I also gave an honest reply. I hope that Mr Fraser and the Liberals can live with their consciences because during that campaign they won hundreds of thousands of votes by saying that under no circumstances would they have a bar of the Labor Party's proposal to introduce retrospective legislation to catch tax avoiders.
—I didn't say that.

—Senator Teague allowed his leader to say it. He should not hide behind the thunderous cloak of silence that he puts around himself to evade responsibility. When his leader said that the Liberals would not have a bar of retrospectivity, as a candidate for office the honourable senator should have risen and said, 'I don't agree with Mr Fraser'.
—When did he say that?

—I will give chapter and verse at the conclusion of my speech, also the relevant news cuttings. It occupied page 1 of the Australian for many days. I wonder where these people were at that stage. Why is it wrong? I do not trust politicians; that is why it is wrong. I do not trust politicians to legislate retrospectively. One of the few protections that the ordinary citizen has is that he knows the law. If he abides by that law he knows he is safe from prosecution and safe from the instruments of politicians, namely, the police. He knows exactly where he is.

SPEECH.PARA: Good heavens; give politicians the chance to legislate retrospectively and we will open a Pandora's box. I find that quite frightening. On this occasion a Pandora's box is opened in the excuse of catching the filthy people who cheat on tax. It is done for a noble purpose, one might say, and I agree. But I have never been one to subscribe to the view that the end justifies the means. That sort of proposition leads one down a track which is fraught with disaster. That is the track that Adolf Hitler went down. It is the track that every tyrant in history has gone down; that is, to make illegal today something which was legal last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like slavery.
—If Senator Missen wants to continue to amuse himself by making ridiculous statements, he may do so.
—Morally, tax evasion has never been legal.

—Tax evasion is not and never will be legal, and the present law will catch offenders. I agree with the honourable senator. But why have prosecutions not been launched under existing legislation? Why has the Senate not been given the documents that Senator Evans, the Labor Party and the Democrats want to see if prosecutions were possible? I am told that there are at least three legal opinions in those documents which the Senate has been denied which state that prosecutions were possible and should have been proceeded with. Why can we not see those opinions?
—Having failed in that direction--

—We have not failed yet. I am prepared to go to the barricades in respect of this matter and have public servants appear at the Bar of this chamber. If the Senate is to be denied that kind of information upon which it must base its judgment it is almost a waste of time for the Senate to be sitting . If this lofty Parliament in the national Capital introduces retrospective legislation we will be amazed-heed this warning-at how quickly the retrospective concept will be copied around the nation. It did not take Mr Wran long to copy the concept in respect of stamp duty. He was not going back 10 years. He introduced legislation requiring stamp duty on documents that were signed 62 years ago. This was not just 10 years ago; it was 62 years back. That legislation met with so much opposition, thankfully, that I believe he has dropped it. But I am not singling out Mr Wran. This legislation is as regressive and dangerous as that proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the strengthening of section 260 and a responsible attitude by the High Court of Australia, which in the past has been totally irresponsible-Madam Acting Deputy President, if you rule that statement to be unparliamentary, I regret it is one statement I will not withdraw, even to the extent of being thrown out of this chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp, I remind you that you must not make reflections on the judiciary while you are debating in this chamber.

—I thank you for your reminder, Madam Acting Deputy President. I hope that in future the High Court will be responsible in following the wishes of the national parliament and the democratically elected legislators with regard to tax evasion and other matters. I hope that the Government will be more diligent in prosecuting when it sees a need and an opportunity to prosecute.

SPEECH.PARA: How can we cope with artificial schemes? I do not know whether there is merit in the suggestion put forward in respect of these schemes because one has to be fair to Consolidated Revenue and taxpayers generally and to individuals who have been advised by their accountants or lawyers that a tax avoidance scheme or a tax minimisation scheme is proper. If somebody's lawyer or accountant says to him: 'If you do this you will minimise tax', how is he to know whether a future government, be it Labor or Liberal, will not go back five years and say: 'We are going to undo what you did in 1982; we are going to legislate retrospectively'? That sort of thing is not satisfactory for governments; it is not satisfactory for individuals. Is it not possible to have an arrangement under which a taxpayer who is advised by his accountant or lawyer that a scheme is legal is able to notify the Taxation Commissioner of that scheme and the Taxation Commissioner has to refer the matter to the government of the day and within three months and the government has to come back and say that the scheme is all right or that if that person goes ahead with that scheme, which the government regards as an aritifical scheme, the government will legislate to make it void.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they are doing that 12 months later it will apply retrospectively?
—Yes, exactly.
—That is almost what has happened in this case, is it not?
—That, to me, is not retrospective legislation. I do not know whether that sort of scheme would work. However, I believe it would be preferable to the one before the Senate at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp concentrated on retrospectivity but ignored the question of fraud, and I think that is the downfall of his argument. I will come to that matter in a few minutes. We are debating the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982. I think it is most appropriate at this point to quote Oliver Wendell Holmes, who said: 'Taxes are the price we pay for a civilised society'. I believe that those words bear thinking about. Nobody likes to pay tax but we all like to live in a civilised society. I believe it is just and fair for everyone, according to his means, to pay his share for the privilege of living in the civilised society which we so proudly call our home.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been considerable lobbying of all members of the Senate by people who , I believe, have often had a particular vested interest in stopping the Government from passing this legislation. We have been assured by the lobbyists, and again today by Senator Chipp, that many innocent people will be affected by this legislation. I cannot accept the example put up by Senator Chipp of a business couple who ran such a good bakery that they made a very large profit at the end of the year and, when offered $25,000 more than that business was worth once it had been stripped of all its assets, did not think anything was wrong, did not ask any questions and did not think that anything was going to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they ask whether the tax had been paid?

—They did not even ask whether the tax was to be paid. They just decided that it was not their responsibility to ask such questions, that their responsibility was just to grab the money and run and show no more concern.
—They were often advised not to ask questions.

—We have been advised that on many occasions they were told: 'Do not ask questions-leave it to me'. I do not believe that anyone who runs a business similar to the one Senator Chipp was talking about, which makes a profit in which a promoter would be interested-we are not talking about small- time people-would be as gullible as that.
—You judge everyone by your own high standards.
—That is the nicest thing Senator Chipp has ever said to me.
—I have been misrepresented.

—Well, Senator Chipp will not get time to say so. He has certainly thrown me off balance. I return to those so-called 'innocent people'. As most people would know Eric Risstrom and the Taxpayers' Association spoke out early in the piece, saying that they could not support the retrospective legislation on any account. It must not allow the situation to develop in which one section of the community, just because its members are taxed under the pay-as-you-earn system, ends up paying its fair share of tax while those who are not in the PAYE system, who believe they can indulge in these immoral, smart-Alick tricks, can end up bragging at the end of the year-I have heard people do it-'Look, I haven't paid tax for years'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 and four other related Bills which are primarily concerned with imposing retrospectively upon certain vendor shareholders a new taxation, equivalent to the amount that has been evaded by subsequent shareholders who purchased the companies from either the vendor shareholders or shareholders who purchased from the vendors. My first fundamental objection to this legislation is that which I have to any legislation which retrospectively imposes a penalty. My second objection is that the legislation, in imposing this new and retrospective taxation, does not seek to distinguish between those vendor-shareholders who received a benefit as a result of evading taxation and in so doing committed an offence under a number of present laws and those vendor-shareholders who acted strictly within the law and committed no offence.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said by Lon Fuller that King Rex's bungling career as a legislator and a judge illustrates that the attempt to create and maintain a system of legal rules may miscarry in at least eight ways. There are eight distinct routes to disaster and one of those eight ways is the abuse of retrospective legislation which not only cannot itself guide action but also undercuts the integrity of rules prospective in effect since it puts them under threat of a retrospective change in the future. It has been reasonably argued that a total failure in any one of these eight directions does not simply result in bad law. It results in something that is not properly called a legal system at all. Certainly there can be no rational grounds for asserting that a man can have a moral obligation to obey a legal rule that does not exist or that comes into existence after he has acted. The United States Constitution provides that no Bill of attainment or ex post facto law shall be passed by the Congress. Part 5 of section 23 of the New Hampshire Constitution of 1784 states:
Retrospective laws are highly injurious, oppressive and unjust. No such laws therefore should be made, either for the decision of civil causes, or the punishment of offences.

Retrospectivity is outlawed also by the French code, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which has been ratified by Australia. So strong was the principle against retrospectivity that when the American Constitution was being drafted two framers of that Constitution who later became judges of the Supreme Court of the United States urged that prohibition against ex post facto laws was unnecessary. One of those gentlemen was moved to observe, during one constitutional debate, that there was 'no lawyer, no civilian who would not say that ex post facto laws were void of themselves'. The courts have over very many years expressed grave concern at retrospective legislation and have consistently ruled that only when legislation specifically and categorically states the intention of retrospectivity can it be read as retrospective. This concern has been expressed particularly when it relates to taxation and commercial transactions. If the law is not certain commercial transactions cannot be carried out in an atmosphere of certainty and men will not be able to arrange their affairs to achieve the legal result which they intend. Lord Simmons in Russell v. Scott had this to say:

My Lords there is a maxim of income tax law which, though it may sometimes be overstressed, yet ought not be forgotten. It it that the subject is not to be taxed unless the words of the taxing statute unambiguously impose the tax upon him. It is necessary that this maxim should on occasion, be reasserted and this is such an occasion.

That statement of the legal position has also been reinforced in a number of cases and the rule which, according to those authorities, is to be applied is thus clearly defined in Maxwell's On Statutes. He states:

It is a fundamental rule of English law that no statute shall be construed so as to have a retrospective operation, unless such a construction appears very clearly in the terms of the Act or arises by necessary and distinct implication.
Maxwell goes on to say:

Perhaps no rule of construction is more firmly established than this, that a retrospective operation is not to be given to a statute so as to impair an existing right or obligation, otherwise than as regards matter of procedure, unless that effect cannot be avoided without doing violence to the language of the enactment.
If the enactment is expressed in language which is fairly capable of either interpretation it ought to be construed as prospective only.
He went on to say:

The courts have held that it is chiefly where the enactment would prejudicially affect vested interests, or the legality of past transactions, or impair contracts that the rule in question prevails. Every statute it has been said, which takes away or impairs vested rights acquired under existing laws, or creates a new obligation, or imposes a new duty, or attaches a new disability in respect of transactions or considerations already past, must be presumed, out of respect to the legislature to be intended not to have a retrospective operation.

As I say, the reason why the courts have taken such a position is their strong opposition to retrospectivity, particularly where it imposes an additional and new burden or penalty. As the courts concede, where the Act specifically states its intention to have a retrospective character, there is nothing that the courts can do but to interpret it accordingly. But their opposition to retrospectivity is manifest in their comments and the strict interpretation that they impose upon it.

While the courts do all that is possible to ascertain the meaning of a taxing Act, they regard the imposition of a tax as of such importance as it is incumbent upon the legislator to make the Act's intentions clear beyond doubt. To quote Dr Gerard Nash:

Once retrospectivity is accepted the decision as to where to draw the line is totally subjective. The disease can spread to laws of criminality, contract, land ownership or any other area of activity. All people should be subject equally to the law, including Government, but retrospectivity puts Government above the law, not under it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote that?

—It is a very profound observation from Dr Gerard Nash. The Liberal Party is not the only party that in the past has expressed grave concern and reservations about the element of retrospectivity in taxation legislation.
