One group of opponents to the legislation--
He was referring to the Curran scheme legislation-
were opponents to the principle of retrospectivity, a position to which Bill Hayden is sympathetic.
We were also told later in the National Times that:
Leader Bill Hayden has told colleagues that he is strongly opposed to retrospectivity on principle.
That doubt-that concern-that temporary integrity-seems to have been washed away with his unbridled ambition to seek office.

I am moved to question why this Government has chosen now to introduce this tax recoupment legislation. What new knowledge has come to the Government since 27 June 1982 when the Treasurer (Mr Howard) told us that the Australian Taxation Office and the Government have known of the full extent of such schemes since 1979 or 1980? It was the knowledge of these and other activities that prompted the Government to introduce the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980. If there was any question of the laws in place in 1978 being effective to prosecute the guilty and recover the tax evaded and according to Costigan and a number of other authoritative and eminent legal opinions they were effective, then the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980 certainly provided the Government with all the necessary legislation it required to put these schemes to rest. The very purpose of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 was to deal with and to stop those schemes now described as bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The very nature of the Treasurer's response on 27 June to the McCabe-Lafranchi report leads me to question the reason for or the need to have this legislation presently before us . When responding to that report, the Treasurer said:

Perhaps one of the most unfortunate aspects of the publication of the report is that it was used to create the false impression that this was new information or new schemes with dramatic new revenue losses. This clearly is not the case. In fact the only new feature of the report was that for the first time tax avoidance and evasion of this kind was personalised as individuals and companies were identified by name . . . without wanting to labour the fact that neither details of the schemes nor the revenue losses involved came as a surprise to us, it is worth recalling some of the things that I said at the time of introducing our remedial legislation.

As I have so frequently said in recent weeks the practices described in the schemes outlined in this report were the target of the Crimes (Taxation Offences ) Act passed by the Commonwealth Parliament in December 1980.

That legislation took two years in its preparation, drafting and presentation. The reason that legislation took two years is that the Government was particularly concerned and the Treasurer, to his everlasting credit, took great care to ensure that that legislation was impeccably fair and reasonable. The areas of prime concern to which the Government was directing its energies were to ensure that no innocent people should be accidently caught by the provisions of the legislation and, particularly, that there should be no shifting of the burden of the onus of proof onto the taxpayer. These are the areas of concern that taxed the Department of the Treasury, the former Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Australian Taxation Office for nearly two years. Of course, at that time there was absolutely no thought of introducing any element of retrospectivity. Great care was taken to ensure that it was to be excluded. The Treasurer tabled the various documents in the House of Representatives, pursuant to a resolution of the Senate of 9 September. He said:

There was particular concern and care about the onus of proof provisions. I make no apology for having evidenced such concern. I personally felt considerable care should be taken to ensure the protection of the innocent.

I believe it is worth recalling that such was the concern of the Federal Government, notwithstanding a very clear and broad knowledge of company stripping and trust stripping, to ensure that the law was not draconian in its application or retrospective in its effect and mindful of the seriousness of the steps being taken, it was prepared to sacrifice two years of lost revenue to ensure that it did not implement bad legislation. Now we have legislation that not only has absolute retrospectivity as an element but which also removes the onus of proof. The Government has legislated to ensure that there is no innocence at all. The Treasurer in explaining, quite properly, the various reasons for the delay until 1980 in introducing the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill made the very reasonable point that until that time community attitude was one of tolerance towards tax avoidance and tax minimisation. He said:

The point is that public attitudes against tax avoidance were only in their formative stages at the time the schemes described in the report were reaching their peak in 1977 and 1978 and were, therefore, nowhere near as pronounced as they are today.
He went on to say:

These attitudes have of course, hardened considerably in recent years. Public hostility has grown, as tax avoidance practices have received considerable publicity and as the Government has intensified its campaign against them.
The Treasurer further stated:

Hence without wanting to downplay in any sense the significance of the schemes covered in the report, it is clearly important to recognise the considerable different state of mind of public opinion towards tax avoidance that existed at that time.

If, as the Treasurer said, prior to 1978 tax avoidance was tolerated and that was one of the fundamental reasons the Government did not act earlier, are we now to condemn or condone-honourable senators can make their own choice- retrospective morality? Is the Government saying that it is now legislating to impose today's values on yesterday's attitudes? As I understand the Government's logic, it perceived during the 1970s that the community did not frown on tax minimisation or tax avoidance; that because they had the moral imprimatur of the community they were perfectly legal. Accordingly, the Government felt that it did not have the community's support, or a mandate from the electorate, to make illegal, what was then legal. However, as the community's view changed the Government was able to legislate in accordance with its perception of the newly evolving attitude of society towards tax avoidance. In 1980 the perception was that tax avoidance was immoral and ought to be outlawed. Therefore, the Government acted accordingly. Now, in 1982, the Government is decreeing that according to its perception of the community view a very harsh and heavy financial penalty should be retrospectively visited upon people who, in some cases as long as 10 years ago, acted within the law of the land and within the framework of society's standards and values. The Treasurer went on to say:
The significant shift in public attitudes in recent years has been most welcome and it is in no small way due to this Government's concerted campaign against tax avoidance and tax evasion practices.

I believe all liberal senators share that view. However, I would be very concerned if I thought that this Government were a willing party in joining with the Opposition in arousing passions, indignation and anger amongst the community by extravagant and inflammatory statements in order to be able to implement retrospectively confiscatory legislation. That is an unhealthy way to govern. History has many sobering reminders of its danger. Perhaps, while contemplating the Government's response to changing community views, we ought to draw a distinction between society's views on tax avoidance and society's views on retrospectivity. I refer the House to a survey conducted in past weeks by the Gallup poll organisation. By and large those polls are pretty precise in reflecting judgments. The survey shows that 58 per cent of Australians are opposed to retrospective legislation, that only 34 per cent are in favour of it. What I find interesting also is that 67 per cent of those polled drew the conclusion that most Australians do not declare their full taxable income on their taxation returns each year. One can only speculate, but I think it is reasonable to assume, that that 67 per cent figure reflects the present state of the cash economy, which has been variously judged to be costing the Federal Treasury between $10 billion and $13 billion a year.

—The Commonwealth just did not hear about it. Spry, Q.C. , said inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: Nor is it clear why, despite the existence of such provisions as S231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and of relevant provisions in companies legislation and in the Crimes Acts of the Commonwealth and of the various States and Territories, prosecutions were not commenced against any persons who were responsible through illegal acts for preventing the recovery of tax which was due to the Commissioner.

The very great tragedy is that not one of these opinions was tested in law by way of a prosecution and all were offered prior to the introduction in 1980 of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It is not without significance to note that the only prosecutions that have been implemented against certain individuals in respect of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes have been launched under 86E of the Crimes Act-an Act which was available in 1972. The Treasurer, in his statement of 25 July, conceded this:
The Solicitor-General has now advised, in relation to a particular case, that action is available primarily against people other than the vendor shareholders under Commonwealth and State laws--
That is present State and Commonwealth laws-

that offer avenues for recovery through procedures under the Companies Act whereby funds could be restored to the stripped company to enable it to meet the as yet unsatisfied income tax assessments that had been raised on it.
The Treasurer continued:

The appropriate authorities will, no doubt, wish to consider whether in this and the numerous other cases that have occurred the evidence that is or becomes available warrants civil or criminal proceedings.
That confirms my view on those matters which I have referred to during my speech . In my view this legislation is not necessary. However, in respect of this legislation the Treasurer went on to say:

In view of the revenue implications and having regard to the fraudulent nature of the scheme, the Government has concluded that, in the public interest, it must act to provide a simple and more certain avenue of recovery of the evaded company tax by way of the vendor shareholders who benefitted from the scheme.

To me that is a very inadequate, poor and unreasonable course of action to be taken by the Commonwealth Government. The long and the short of those paragraphs from the Treasurer's statement is that in the cases so far examined no action rests against the vendor shareholders, presumably because they have committed no offences, and the Government now fully concedes and recognises that existing laws are more than adequate to satisfy its intentions. However, it wants the money quickly and it wants the money from those people from whom it can quickly get it, irrespective of their responsibility or any illegality or irrespective of any offence they may have committed. This is all in the name of public interest. What the public interest is has not been made clear. I have always thought that a miscarriage of justice, against an individual or in a collective sense, is contrary to the public interest.

As we learn from Costigan, Q.C., in his report, he was advised by a senior officer of the Taxation Office that as a consequence of false advice from the Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office-which claimed in essence that the current laws were not adequate for prosecution or recovery of evaded tax in the case of company stripping schemes-two years were spent preparing and introducing the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980, which should never have been introduced in the first place. Mr Costigan said:
Thus the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia was induced to enact new criminal laws of great breadth and scope when all that was required was the enforcement of the existing laws.
He continued:
The only reason why the former laws were not effective to inhibit their breach was because those laws were not enforced.

I do not in any way condemn, criticise or downplay the magnificent contribution and role that this Government, over seven years, has played in pursuit of tax avoidance and tax evasion. It has closed more loopholes than any other government since Federation. That is highly commendable. I in no way criticise the Taxation Office which, as I said, in unrelenting pursuit, has endeavoured, with concern and anxiety, to collect that tax which is available to it under the existing laws. It is very regrettable that it was provided with wrong, poor, inadequate and incompetent information which in very many ways inhibited the proper implementation of the laws. I find it very regrettable that the Government has not chosen to apply the full force of the existing laws but instead has chosen the expedient and dangerous path of introducing this legislation now before us.

If I am going to refer, as I have, in a very unkind way to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth I remind the Senate also-there have been suggestions made in this place and in another place, by an unfortunate creature, that the Liberal Party had some role in this-that the only solicitor in that Office who has been identified so far, a Mr Bercove-whom we have read about so often-is a member of the Australian Labor Party. He signed an advertisement, as a member of the Australian Labor Party legal fraternity, supporting the ALP. I hear all about people on our side but not one of those people in the Perth Crown Solicitor's Office is a member of the Liberal Party. The Opposition ought to look a bit closer at Mr Bercove and what he is supposed to have done. I intend to say no more about the question of innocence. I would have been delighted to have dealt with those rather disappointing and inadequate observations of Senator Walters in respect of innocence but I will save them for when I move the amendment on the innocent clause, of which I have given contingent notice.

—Senator Georges, a motion is required.

—Mr Deputy President, I will not persist. I did not interrupt the honourable senator on a point of order while he was reading his speech. The purpose of having those papers tabled is to indicate that he read his speech throughout. I think that was in breach of the Standing Orders. —Mr Deputy President, I did not read my speech. Unlike a number of members of the Opposition I write my own speeches so I know what they contain. There is a very clear association between what Hansard says and what I say because I know what I am talking about. That is why I do not bumble and stumble and fall all over words that I cannot pronounce, unlike a number of the honourable senator's colleagues.
