SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to Senator Crichton-Browne's speech. It had all the enthusiasm of Custer's last stand on behalf of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party. His speech was largely devoted to the strippers who, I understand, were part of the business of Mr Bercove when he operated from the Attorney-General's Department in Western Australia in pursuit of the State motto of 'Relax in a State of excitement'. I really find it extraordinary that the debate should be reduced to the level to which it has been reduced. It really is about some fairly simple sorts of issues. I understand Senator Crichton-Browne to be saying that there was a whoopee period in the middle of the 1970s when the Government did not pursue tax evasion or tax avoidance, and that some change in community attitudes has been brought about by this Government and therefore this retrospective legislation is being introduced. Of course that is a source of great regret to the honourable senator.
—That is their argument, not mine.

—I know. It is a source of great regret to Senator Crichton- Browne because the situation which prevailed in the mid-1970s would have continued had this Government not been caught out in its negligent approach to collecting revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by reminding the Senate of the importance of the issue of tax evasion and tax avoidance. I do so by quoting from a speech by Professor Russell Mathews , a Government adviser, in which he said:
Indeed, if the same enthusiasm were to be shown by the Commonwealth for controlling revenue collections as for controlling Government expenditures, higher rates of taxation would not be necessary.

In an earlier paper, I have estimated conservatively that something like 20 per cent of personal income tax nominally payable is being lost to revenue through avoidance and evasion, usually by high-income taxpayers other than wage and salary earners. Quite apart from the unfortunate effects on the distribution of the tax burden, this revenue loss has had a direct impact on the size of the public sector Budget deficit, the level of Government borrowing, the rate of growth of the money supply and the level of interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Mathews?

—That is Professor Mathews, a Government adviser, on the question of tax avoidance and evasion, which is the subject of the legislation now before the Senate. On Monday of this week the Government announced that in order to get out of its economic difficulties, as it perceives them, and in order not to increase further the size of the deficit, it would implement if possible a wages pause in the public sector and use public sector wages to provide employment creating schemes. It suggested further that that pause should flow through to the private sector and, indeed, to all sections of the community. I am very skeptical about whether that will happen and I am even more skeptical about whether it would work. What is important about the Government's suggestion is the recognition that this country is in a time of economic crisis and that people will be called upon necessarily to make sacrifices in order to contribute to a solution of that crisis. That is a vastly different atmosphere from which existed in the late 1970s and in 1980-81 in connection with tax evasion and avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems which Professor Russell Mathews identifies as being basically wrong, structurally, with the Australian economy are, in his view, largely attributable to tax evasion and tax avoidance. They are largely attributable to the Government's failure to collect revenue over a considerable period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Primarily in the cash economy.

—That is not what he says at all. He refers to the evasion and avoidance largely being undertaken by high income taxpayers. I do not know whether the honourable senator clearly disagrees with that view because it suits his purpose to do so as his interest is in high income taxpayers, not so much the cash economy.
—I thought you said high income taxpayers are not paying tax. Are you saying people with high incomes are paying tax?

—If the honourable senator listens to what I am saying he may be able to put it all together himself without getting into the difficulties he is getting into. It is in that context that we approach this debate. These Bills represent a very limp response to one of the greatest tax scandals, and economics scandals, that this country has known. From the very beginning this Government has been spineless on the issue of tax fairness. Senator Crichton- Browne keeps talking about fairness for tax evaders and avoiders. He ought to look at the distribution of tax in this community, at the income tax burden now as distinct from what it was when this Government came to power, and talk a little about tax fairness in that area as distinct from tax fairness for those who have broken the law. Senator Crichton-Browne says the only successful prosecutions have been launched under section 86 (1) (e) of the Crimes Act. I do not know how successful they have been, but the section says:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who conspires with another person . . . to defraud the Commonwealth or a public authority under the Commonwealth, shall be guilty of an indictable offence.

That is a provision which has not been used very much. Senator Crichton-Browne suddenly finds it very attractive compared with the present legislation. Of course it ought to have been used and of course the provisions of the 1980 legislation ought to have been used. These provisions have not been used because in this whole sorry episode there has been a reluctance of will to use them. What we are talking about in this context is an issue of fundamental public morality. That is the issue we are talking about, not nice little legal loopholes and how they can be plugged or unplugged. That is something that this Government has been pretty weak on because it cannot go to people in this community and say that they cannot have a pension rise or that they have to have a wage pause or any of these things if it has tolerated this sort of thing for the period over which it has tolerated it-that is, from 1977. One has only to read the telephone book of documents tabled in this place when the Government finally got caught on this issue to realise the Government's knowledge of this matter over a long time. That is the fundamental question which has to be debated. A government cannot with any credibility ask people on low incomes to make sacrifices, to make hard decisions, unless its own house is in order on this fundamental question of collecting revenue.

This whole sorry episode has illustrated the extent to which the Government has been prepared to preside over, and indeed engender, inequities in this country. This Government has not governed on this issue in the interests of the many. It is the interests of the few that have been looked after and are still being sought to be looked after in the context of this debate. In the course of debate on this legislation we have had evidence of culpable negligence by senior Ministers, such as the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard). We have had evidence of criminal delays in Government departments, including sections such as the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. We have had evidence of gross tax dodging activities by senior Liberals, such as Mr Horgan. We have had prime ministerial fudging and hypocrisy on this issue, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has changed his view on whether this question involves the recovery of stolen money or whether the various categories of stolen money have to be looked at, and we have had the extraordinary growth of cunning tax lawyers, corporate accountants and the like who have fed and fuelled this industry.

What does this legislation do to try to rectify this dreadful situation? First of all, it provides for basic conditions under which promoters and shareholders become liable for unpaid company taxes and undistributed taxes. These provisions are retrospective. I have no concern about these provisions being retrospective, because while every honourable senator ought to be concerned about retrospective legislation it should not be a veil behind which cowards hide. Surely a greater social morality than that is involved in this matter. For every judgment of the House of Lords that Senator Crichton-Browne can dig up in support of his case I can dig up another dozen which put a quite contrary view in relation to retrospectivity in tax legislation. This is not a question that bothered the Government much when it legislated retrospectively in relation to the Curran schemes-not to the extent that it bothers it now-and the reason was that not as many prople in the Liberal Party were caught up in Curran schemes as have been caught up in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. That is why the question of retrospectivity really bothers some supporters of the Government now and becomes a veil behind which they try to hide in dealing with this fundamental question of public morality and ethics.

In addition to the things I have mentioned this legislation imposes liabilities on promoters for 20 per cent of the tax liability. It provides for increased late payment penalties. But the legislation is deficient in a number of respects . Firstly, it deals only with company and undistributed profit tax which remains unpaid. It does not recoup personal income tax lost in relation to accumulated after tax profits disposed of by vendor shareholders in the same transactions. The Bills provide a totally unjust exemption for some classes of tax dodgers. I refer to clause 3 (12) of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill which was added later in a rather sneaky concession after the tax debate commenced in the House of Representatives. That clause lets the really efficient , conspiratorial tax dodger off the hook. The tax dodger who mucks it up, as it were, as a result of bad advice or is not so experienced in his efforts, gets caught under this provision. Of course, the legislation also fails to recoup certain sums of sales tax and provides for greater leniency to tax evaders in respect of the time allowed to pay their tax. I do not object to that but of course again it introduces a double standard. That leniency is not available to the ordinary taxpayer; it is available to those who get caught in tax avoidance.

As a result of the deficiencies in this Bill it is clear that the sum to be recouped will be far less than that which has actually been lost and which the Government expects to recover. Indeed the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) admitted this in answer to a question I asked her on 26 October this year. The Treasurer has also admitted that some $500m of tax will be lost because of a failure to recoup personal income tax involved as well as the watering-down provisions of the legislation.

I do not want to canvass in great detail the provisions of the Bill. I simply wish to point out some of the massive inequities that are involved in the tax debate in this country. The great issues about which we have to be concerned as a parliament are the inequities and so on which have developed in the tax debate illustrated by standards in propriety in ministerial behaviour, the inequalities which this Government both perpetrates and tolerates and the extent of tax avoidance to which I have already referred.

I quoted earlier from what Professor Russell Mathews had to say about the extent of tax avoidance and evasion and its effects on the economy of this country. Not only Professor Russell Mathews has made those sorts of comments but also the Commissioner of Taxation has pointed out the extent of the problem in a number of his recent reports. In the sixty-first report for 1981-82 $1,035m was owed by participants in identified tax avoidance schemes and $465m was owed by stripped companies. In both cases the money was owed as at 8 October 1982. What was this Government's response to reports of the Taxation Commissioner from 1977 to 1981 which pointed out the growth of tax avoidance and evasion in this country year by year? What was this Government's response to pleas from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation for additional resources to deal with the problem? What was its response to the request for prosecutions from the Attorney -General's Department under the existing law? Pleas of the kind made by the Commissioner of Taxation were ignored by this Government.

Instead of providing additional staff to deal with tax evasion and avoidance, as the Commissioner repeatedly requested year after year, what did the Fraser Government do? It cut the staff available to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation . When the Commissioner asked year after year for additional staff to deal with this problem the Government cut staff numbers. That was the response he got from this Government. How can we say that this Government has any bona fides at all on this issue when it behaves like that? That was the pattern of condonation, connivance and collusion in which this Government engaged in protecting the tax avoidance industry in this country. One looks at the reports of the Taxation Commissioner to see the extent of that. One looks also at independent commentators such as Mr Risstrom of the Taxpayers Association who for one has put the figure of revenue lost as high as $7,000m. Under this Government tax avoidance has flourished and the consequent tax inequities have become greater and greater. It should not be forgotten that tax avoidance costs every household this country $30 a week. This $30 goes into the profits of those who have engaged in this sort of activity.

This legislation attempts in a rather lame way to come to grips with one of the grossest forms of tax avoidance-the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. It should be remembered that this legislation would never have seen the light of day without the report of Commissioner Costigan-the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-and its damaging findings and without the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Senator Crichton-Browne could have sat back waiting for somebody to do something under the existing law. He would have been waiting in vain as he would have waited for the last seven or eight years for something to happen under the existing law since that prosecution first went astray in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —It demonstrates that the new laws are not required.

—It may be. It may be also, as the honourable senator points out, that the new laws are just another stunt by this Government rather of the kind which has been described by, I think, Mr Baume, the honourable member for Macarthur, as being seen to be doing something. Maybe this legislation, as Senator Crichton-Browne has pointed out, is just being seen to be doing something about an important problem, just as the 1980 legislation was being seen to be doing something about a matter about which the Government clearly was not concerned at all. Prior to that the Government was being seen to be doing nothing under the existing law between 1976 and 1980.
—What about the 30 separate Acts against tax evasion?

—I do not want to misrepresent the honourable senator. This Government has talked more about dealing with tax avoidance and evasion than any government in Australia's history. That is true. The problem has got bigger and bigger under this Government because people involved in tax evasion and avoidance have known that it is all talk and no action under the existing legislation. I will deal with that matter in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation would never have been necessary but for the fact that the Government was caught by Commissioner Costigan and the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Government inaction in this area has been almost criminally negligent. There has been overwhelming evidence from the Australian Taxation Office and expert legal opinions available to the Government as early as 1976 but no attempt at all was made to outlaw these schemes until 1980. There was very little action until the legislation which was inroduced in 1980.

The Treasurer initially claimed that he was unaware of the full extent of these schemes until 1980. That claim has been proved to have been fatuous and false by the evidence contained in a set of documents the size of a telephone book which has been tabled in this Parliament. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister of this country knew in 1977 of the growing extent of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It is quite clear also that the Taxation Commissioner emphasised from the outset that action was needed in relation to these schemes. He did not get action from the Attorney-General's Department or from the Deputy Crown-Solicitor's office but he knew that it was needed. No less than 18 calls were made by the Commissioner of Taxation to the Treasurer of this country for action on these schemes before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was finally passed in 1980 outlawing such schemes. There were 18 calls from the Commissioner of Taxation to this Government urging action in relation to the collection of revenue from the people involved in these schemes-18 calls asking for action which were ignored. At the same time, as Professor Mathews would no doubt point out, the Government was spending a lot of time talking about cutting government expenditure, razor gangs and all those sorts of things. The money was not coming in because the Commissioner of Taxation was being ignored by a slothful government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that legislation necessary?

—I do not want to express a legal opinion on the 1980 legislation . I think it might have been helpful if it had been used effectively, just the same as part of this legislation may have some effect if it is used effectively. I think the legislation which the Government has introduced is all very much in the same sort of basket; it is seen to be doing something. That is what the legislation is about. A series of prosecutions for criminal fraud should have taken place in the mid-1970s under the existing law. That is what it is- conspiring to defeat the revenue of this country. None of those things happened. This Government could have acted a lot sooner and it did not. It could have stopped tax avoidance earlier on and it did not. When it was finally embarrassed by the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports it acted with totally uncharacteristic speed in introducing this legislation. It did it for political reasons-that it had to be seen to be doing something.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate has to be seen also in the context of tax fairness generally in this country. This Government's attitude to tax avoidance is indicative of its attitude to tax inequalities in the community at large. Since 1975 when this Government came to power, the proportion of tax paid by low income earners has increased enormously when expressed as a proportion of total pay-as-you-earn tax collections. In the 1981 Budget alone the proportion of tax paid by PAYE taxpayers increased by 22 per cent alone in that year. At the same time Professor Mathews says that 20 per cent of the revenue of this country is being lost in tax evasion and tax avoidance by people, as he put it, on high incomes. At the same time, the burden of taxation is being shifted to the ordinary wage and salary earner by a factor of 22 per cent in 1981 alone. The proportion of tax paid by high income tax earners has diminished and the proportion paid by low income tax earners has increased. The Government should recognise that a major effect of its delay, its unwillingness to take firm measures against these schemes as they appeared is to increase the degree of cynicism in the community about the whole taxation system.

I do not, like Senator Martyr, attempt to use expressions like 'moral fibre', but that sort of thing is destructive of the moral fibre of society. The Government shifts the tax burden to the poor, it alleviates the rich in terms of the tax scales and, at the same time, 20 per cent of the tax revenue is forgone as a result of tax avoidance. There is a perception in the community that the taxation system is unfair, that the wealthy are being allowed to have a go and have been allowed to have a go at avoiding tax and have opportunities to do so that are denied the ordinary, average taxpayer. When the Costigan Royal Commission reported on this issue and the Government got caught and was prompted into some sort of activity, I had a lot of conversations with taxi drivers and various people in the community who complained to me that they had been hounded by the Taxation Office in respect of a $70 claim for chemist bills for which they could not find the receipts. Officers of the Taxation Office are pursuing people for those sorts of amounts. Then we have a fellow like Mr Denis Horgan in Western Australia evading $7m in tax in three years, and nothing was being done about it by the Government. Why was nothing done about it? It is because Mr Horgan was a functionary of the Australian Liberal Party of Australia. That is how the argument goes and how the perception in the community goes about about this sort of thing.

The tax system, in those circumstances, is not perceived to be fair. It is most important that the tax be seen to be administered according to a fair system. The present tax system is not fair because of widespread avoidance and the loss of confidence as a result. Is it any wonder that Professor Russell Mathews, whom I quoted from before, had this to say in January of this year about the taxation system in Australia. He stated:

The Australian taxation and social welfare system, far from contributing to greater equality in the distribution of incomes and wealth, has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes from the poor to the rich and from wage and salary earners to other income recipients, as well as a major cause of the budgetary problems of all Australian governments and a source of growing social, business and economic instability.

If Governments were to set out deliberately to design a taxation system which would redistribute income from the poor to the rich, which would substantially relieve the rich of the cost of financing social welfare transfers and public services, which would consciously discriminate against wage and salary incomes in favour of other incomes and capital gains, which would distort the pattern of consumption and production, and which would provide a major stimulus to wage inflation and industrial conflict, it would be difficult for them to develop a set of tax arrangements that would be more successful in meeting such perverse objectives than the existing Australian system.

That is what Professor Mathews said and that is really what this debate is all about. What we need, more than anything else, is a government determined to enforce the present capital gains provisions and, if necessary, introduce stronger ones; a government determined to redistribute income through reform of the taxation scales and a government which is prepared to crack down hard on tax avoidance with a thorough retrospective program, if that is necessary. These things are needed in this society if we are to retrieve ourselves from the current economic crisis and the current social crisis which now grips this country. These issues are of fundamental importance. The present Bills give no confidence that the Government is prepared to bite the bullet on these issues, nor does the past behaviour of the Government give any confidence that tax fairness will be achieved in this country while the Fraser Government remains in power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate on the five taxation Bills which are now before the Senate. If anyone ever had any doubts about the value of a parliamentary back bench in either House, I think those doubts now should be resolved. Every now and again-for that infrequency as a government senator I am grateful, because I do not like voting against the Government-there comes a time when, irrespective of party discipline or public and private abuse, members and senators are called upon to respond to their consciences. It seems that it is only back benchers who can do this for the reality, it is sad to say, of a Cabinet Government is such that if there are any differences in the Cabinet that are carried forward by Cabinet members into either House, the Cabinet member in question has to resign. What I am saying is that I cannot believe that every member of this Cabinet believes absolutely in retrospective legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Bills we are debating now are about the worst of a retrospective kind that I have seen. These Bills are the mechanism for making illegal that which, until now, was legal. The Government is using incredibly bad means-that is, punitive retrospectivity-to achieve what everyone would regard as a reasonable end; that is, fair taxation. My difficulty is not with the end, but with the means. I can never justify an improper means to a good end. For me the end must be good and the means must be good.

We can argue endlessly in this chamber that what was done by those who avoided tax was not avoidance but evasion-forbidden by the present law. If this is true, why have they not already been charged under existing taxation law? It is said by the Government that the present taxation law is inadequate to gather what the Government says is owed. If this is true, why has it been necessary for the Government to create a new tax and apply it retrospectively? Senator Walters does not accept this. She gave an example which, in all charity, I say was fairly primeval, of the sale of a stolen watch. This example bears no relationship whatsoever to the retrospective Bills that we are debating. The watch that she talked about was clearly stolen and receiving stolen property is clearly against the law. Therefore, no new law is needed to cover that type of offence; the law is already there. In the case that we are speaking about the tax avoidance was clearly legal.

TALK.START.PARA: —In all cases?

—Yes. As proof of that a new tax has had to be devised and applied retrospectively to collect what the Government says is owed. Senator Watson may have sympathy with his Tasmanian colleague, but I have none. There are many Bills and pages of explanatory memoranda but, in brutal essence, after all of the legal obfuscation, the truth lies in two sentences in the explanatory memorandum of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to recover from former owners of shares in stripped companies and from promoters and their associates the tax evaded by those companies it is necessary for constitutional reasons for the Bills to impose a tax on the persons concerned.

If the Government had been completely frank it would have inserted the word 'new ' before the word 'tax'. Any discussions with officers in the Australian Taxation Office will verify that the word 'new' should be inserted. It is a new tax. The second sentence that I extract from the explanatory memorandum states:

In order to make the legislation apply only from a time shortly before these schemes came to be practised on a wide scale, the Bill is expressed to apply to schemes entered into on or after 1 January 1972.

As I said, the word 'new' should have been inserted. That can be easily verified with officers from the Taxation Office. I am sure that the vendors of shares who are to be the subject of the new tax engaged in perfectly legitimate transactions-as they were-which they certainly would not have contemplated had they known that in several years a new tax would be imposed upon them as a result of the actions they had taken. It is grossly unfair for respectable citizens to be taxed as a result of transactions which they legitimately entered into years ago because other persons have committed offences as a consequence of which the Commissioner of Taxation has not been paid. In recent months the Liberal Party in Western Australia, Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia, as well as the National Party of Queensland and the National Country Party of Western Australia, have opposed this legislation. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate a document which shows what the Western Australian Liberal Party had to say about this matter on Saturday, 7 August 1982.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RE: RETROSPECTIVE LEGISLATION
Motion passed by the State Council of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, Saturday, 7 August 1982.
That this Council:
1. Advise the Federal Government that it strongly opposes retrospectivity in laws creating offences and imposing penalties on individuals on the grounds that such retrospectivity is:
(a) An offence against natural justice and human rights, and
(b) Contrary to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is a signatory, and which Australia undertakes to respect.
2. Strongly requests the Federal Government to suspend action on proposed laws imposing retrospective tax liability on individuals and companies, because such laws would:
(a) Wrongly take away basic citizen rights, and
(b) Wrongly impose penalties for actions that were lawful when taken.
3. Strongly requests the Federal Government to continue its fight against tax evasion by fair means.

4. Strongly commends the Federal Government for its consistent opposition to tax evasion, and its effective closure of tax loopholes on a non-retrospective basis-especially by the introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 which imposed penalties of five years gaol and $50 000 fines, and stopped ' bottom of the harbour' evasion by buyers and strippers of companies.

5. Strongly warns the Federal Government that there is mounting evidence that the retrospective proposals it has been considering could destabilise the financial affairs of individuals and companies, leading to thousands of bankruptcies and a substantial increase in unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Law Council of Australia has come out strongly against the Government proposal. I do not recall any professional organisation in Australia favouring what the Government is doing. An article which was published in the Herald on Saturday, 6 November 1982, with regard to a public opinion poll, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Fifty-eight percent of Australians oppose respective tax legislation, says the Gallup Poll.
The same poll shows that 65 percent of people oppose retrospective legislation generally, that is, any legislation that makes new laws apply from dates in the past rather than from now.
Twenty-five percent are in favour of retrospective legislation generally and ten percent are unsure.

I have no doubt at all that that reflects a very strong reaction from the public to this disgraceful legislation. If Senator Haines is listening I hope that she comes into the chamber to verify that her Human Rights Bill 1982 is strongly against retrospective legislation. Section 27 (1) of that Bill is strongly against retrospective legislation. I expect that she will be with those of us who oppose this dreadful legislation.

I am concerned also that the Costigan report indicates quite clearly that a stand may have been taken as far back as 1975 against those people who were involved in illegal activity concerning so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I know that there is contrary advice to this, but I also know that everyone would agree that those persons who appear to have broken the law and who, after a professional investigation, are thought to be guilty of tax evasion, and fraud relating to tax evasion, should be prosecuted under the existing legal remedies available. I refer in particular to the Crimes Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Companies Act, et cetera.

I believe that we are all totally opposed to respectable members of the community being penalised because of the fraudulent acts of other persons who remain free and who have not been brought to account for their actions. I hope that people will not be misled by emotive rhetoric about the public being ripped off. Any of us who have any practical experience of government know that very little in the end will be recovered from the attempts the Government is making. There will be an enormous increase in the Public Service, computer usage and consultants. In the end I doubt that there will be any profit for this Government or for anybody else. I do not think that people ought to be misled- particularly the lawyers in this place-about the totally out of context quotations of senior English judges which have no bearing on the legislation with which we are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —With exceptions.

—The ones which the honourable senator quoted were right; the ones which the Opposition quoted were wrong. To sum up why I will be voting against this legislation, I believe that these Bills destroy certainty before the law. Surely this certainty is more important than any other principle. For instance, the so-called principle of equity and fairness means nothing unless there is certainty before the law. I know that there are oversophisticated smart -Alicks-they are probably lawyers too-who will say that no one has any certainty before the law and that that is the purpose of the legal profession, to achieve that certainty. In answer to those people, I maintain that there are basic certainties of tax law. If these certainties were reinforced by legal decisions, citizens are entitled to feel certain that what they did was legal. I refer in particular to the decision of Sir Garfield Barwick in the much publicised Slutzkin case in the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had nothing to say so far about the morality of what was done to avoid tax. All I know is that what was done was legal at the time. I note that my learned friend Senator Button had something to say about public morality and making moral judgments. This is truly a death-bed repentence for the Australian Labor Party. Between 1972 and 1975 the ALP created the vast gulf between morality and public policy-a gulf which I believe will not be bridged in my lifetime. It made nonsense of firmly held traditional moral views. So it is not much good members of the Labor Party, in this year of 1982, bemoaning the fact that there is a vast gulf between public morality and public policy because they created it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about, you old woman? You don't know what you are talking about.

—If that is not clear to Senator Button, there is no way that I can make it any clearer. The present Government Bills prove that all those who have been accused and named in this Parliament are innocent. Senator Button named people. That was really not a decent thing to do because there has been no trial and no charges laid. The aim of naming people here is undoubtedly to shatter and destroy their reputations. All those who have been accused and named in this Parliament are innocent. Why are they innocent? Because the only means that the Government has used to get what it alleges is owed to it is a new tax retrospectively applied 10 years. So certainty before the law has suffered a shattering blow in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give a few quotations about the importance of certainty. I quote from the evidence of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence's Sub- Committee on the Pacific Basin and from such authorities as Mr William John O' Reilly, Commissioner of Taxation, and Mr Samuel Stuart McBurney, Assistant Secretary, Taxation Policy, in the Department of the Treasury. On page 980 of the evidence, Mr O'Reilly complained quite justifiably of the 'unacceptable level of uncertainty' in certain taxation arrangements between the United States Government and the Australian Government. Later, Mr O'Reilly said:

So in this day and age in my view-it might be a personal view but I think it will be shared to a large extent by Mr McBurney and the policy formulators-the main benefit gained from double taxation agreements is that of certainty, of having delimited in an agreement between the two countries, in a document which becomes part of the law of those two countries . . .
Mr O'Reilly then said:
. . . the certainty that your taxes are going to be 15 per cent of gross of dividends or 10 per cent of gross of royalties;
And so on. It is quite clear that he regards the principle of certainty as being vitally important in taxation agreements. He stated:
I would say only that one of certainty I think. Businessmen do look for certainty. Insofar as at the margin or somewhere, Mr McBurney and I have made the same point.
Mr McBurney said:

As Mr O'Reilly said, it does affect the certainty in the businessman's mind. It is not only written down what is agreed but the agreement puts some limits on each country's right to change its law in the future while the agreement lasts. That is an additional element of certainty in their minds.
One can see how bad retrospective legislation could be in this context. I asked Mr O'Reilly about these matters because naturally they were of interest because this debate was coming up. I asked him:
Would you say that in all taxation agreements or all taxation law anywhere certainty is the most vital component?
Mr O'Reilly replied:
It depends on your definition of 'certainty'. There is going to be a lot of certainty about this new law.
I then told him:
That is just my problem with it, I might tell you.
Mr O'Reilly replied:
Certainly certainty is a desirable thing, but exceptions prove the rule and circumstances alter cases.
To which I replied:
And hard cases make bad laws.

I think I can safely say to the Senate that here we have an example of some hard cases being responsible for some very bad laws. If it would not tax the patience of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the quotations from Mr O' Reilly. I have not circulated them but they are quite unexceptionable, I think.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

On this point I might mention that a recent report prepared for the United States Congress by the Government Accounting Office in relation to the United States Treasury regulations setting out guidelines for United States transfer pricing legislation asserts that the existing complex guidelines create an unacceptable level of uncertainty and significant administrative burdens for both taxpayers and the Internal Revenue Service.

So in this day and age in my view-it might be a personal view but I think it will be shared to a large extent by Mr McBurney and the policy formulators-the main benefit gained from double taxation agreements is that of certainty, of having delimited in an agreement between the two countries, in a document which becomes part of the law of those two countries, the full extent of the responsibilities each has in relation to the taxation of a transaction which straddles the two or an organisation which straddles the two; the certainty that your taxes are going up by 15 per cent of gross of dividends or 10 per cent of gross of royalties; the definition of what royalties are so that you know which of your transactions are going to involve royalties; the definition of what dividends are; the definition of what interest is; the fact that there is going to be only a 10 per cent tax on interest; what constitutes a permanent establishment, because without a permanent establishment, without real presence in a country, that country cannot reach out its tax tentacles to you. So you know what is likely to be determined to be a permanent establishment, bringing in its train some tax consequences in a country where you are operating, that sort of certainty.
Mr O'Reilly-I would say only that one of certainty I think. Businessmen do look for certainty. Insofar as at the margin or somewhere, Mr McBurney and I have made the same point;

Mr McBurney-I would think any effect on the amount of the flow would be fairly marginal. As Mr O'Reilly said, it does affect the certainty in the businessman's mind. It is not only written down what is agreed now but the agreement puts some limits on each country's right to change its law in the future while the agreement lasts. That is an additional element of certainty in their minds. Probably it also leads to a slightly more orderly arrangement for the actual administration of tax by the tax collectors in each country. The overall effect on amounts of flow I would think would be pretty marginal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you say that in all taxation agreements or all taxation law anywhere certainty is the most vital component?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Reilly-It depends on your definition of 'certainty'. There is going to be a lot of certainty about this new law.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just my problem with it, I might tell you.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Reilly-Certainly certainty is a desirable thing, but exceptions prove the rule and circumstances alter cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —And hard cases make bad laws.

—I thank the Senate. I have the greatest respect for Mr O'Reilly and for Mr McBurney. They are honest, diligent and conscientious public servants . I had the privilege of watching and listening to Mr O'Reilly answering the inquisition of Opposition Senators Evans and Walsh at a meeting of Estimates Committee C. In my view the Australian Taxation Office is entirely blameless in this whole matter. It has done its duty and done it well. I do not know that the Government can be fairly blamed for its reluctance to spring into action on these matters. It seems to me, in fairness, as I contemplate the issue that the Government was reluctant to act because it kept being forced back all the time to this awful concept of retrospectivity. That is enough to make any government hesitate. I wish it would overcome its difficulties by test cases. As I have said before, there were other ways of overcoming the difficulties, but I give credit where credit is due. I am sure it was the contemplation of this dreadful practice of punitive retrospectivity which made the Government hold. I am sure that there are other ways and I wish that they had been implemented. What is being contemplated is the destruction of certainty before the law.

SPEECH.PARA: Having destroyed certainty by declaring illegal what was legal, the Bills also destroy, along the way, the principle of being assumed innocent until proven guilty. With these Bills-if I may use crude terminology-someone is fingered immediately and with not much chance of proving his innocence, because the new law is absolutely certain that what he did all those years ago is now illegal and he must pay what is assessed. It has been suggested that because some of us who feel as strongly as we do about our opposition to retrospectivity supported a strictly limited retrospectivity in the case of Curran we are somehow inconsistent. I well remember the legislation in question. I was a member of the House of Representatives at the time. We were promised after Curran-in that case there was only 11 months of retrospectivity-that no more retrospective legislation would ever be presented to either House. We supported the Curran legislation because we believed that if the Treasurer gave a warning in the House of Representatives to those people who he believed were doing the wrong thing and said that they would be apprehended and that the purpose of legislation he was to bring down was to apprehend them it was reasonable to make the legislation retrospective to the time of his announcement, bearing in mind that it takes quite some time for legislation to go through both Houses and to be proclaimed. We believed that this was reasonable to stop smart-Alicks from exploiting something when they had been warned not to do so. In that case the period of retrospectivity was only 11 months. Some of us, having gone down the road of retrospectivity at that time, did not like what we saw, did not like what we had to do even though it seemed like abundant common sense at the time. But to jump, as this Bill does, from 11 months-call it a year in round figures if you like-to 10 years is more than we can take. That is why we will vote against it. What we feared then has happened. Retrospectivity, once used in seemingly quite a normal, legitimate and logical way, is now being used in this way.

The Government's argument for punitive retrospectivity can be made to apply to anything, making things illegal which were legal and punishing those presumed guilty. I ask people to recollect what Senator Chipp has had to say about this. The points he made are quite relevant. Because of what the Federal Government is doing government in New South Wales is seriously contemplating how it can have a retrospective stamp tax. As Senator Chipp said, they want to go back upwards of 60 years. That is absolutely incredible. I hope that there is some sort of resistance against that legislation in New South Wales. But that is not our problem here. Our problem is to try to stop the legislation here. In Victoria, the new Labor Government of Mr Cain is seriously contemplating and has seriously contemplated retrospective land tax. I know that there has been opposition to this in Victoria as there has been oposition to the stamp tax in New South Wales . I hope it is successful. We can clearly see what the example-the example that we as a Federal Government are setting-is doing to the country. It is a bad example and it will be followed by others. As I said, once the door to these practices is opened there will be no closing it. I cannot help but be anything else but nervous when I see that Senator Evans, leading the debate for the Australian Labor Party in this matter, is so totally dedicated to this principle that, in a statement in the Sunday Observer of 7 November this year, he said:
We pledge ourselves, in office, to wage a war on tax evasion and avoidance that will make all the activities of the present Government look like minor skirmishes . . .

If the major activity of the present Government is to employ a new punitive retrospective tax that goes back 10 years-and Senator Evans says that activity will look like a minor skirmish compared with what the Labor Party will do-must not everybody in this chamber and everybody who is listening to the debate be terrified of what we are promised will be done? This is absolutely scandalous. I hope that people who have contemplated this retrospective legislation will see what a dreadful, damaging and demoralising thing it is. It is something to which no government should resort. It is wrong in that it destroys the certainty before the law that is absolutely essential for subjects to have.

I will vote-there will be others voting with me-for certainty. We do not want any misunderstanding on the part of the Government or anybody else about what we are voting against. We will vote for all subjects' certainty before the law. Take that certainty away and nothing else will mean anything. I insist: It is not a question only for today. When we in this chamber vote against punitive retrospectivity, we will vote for what is right today, but we will be voting for those who are to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that, until now, the debate has not been met. In a sense, whilst proposals have been put in relation to the retrospectivity of the legislation, those in favour of it spoke almost entirely in relation to whether a person will support tax dodging, tax evasion or whatever. Not one person to whom I have listened so far in this debate who is opposed to this legislation has expressed any sympathy for the activities of people who have been ripping off the country for quite some time. What has been made exceptionally clear is that, if at any stage a person was acting against the laws of the Commonwealth in a fraudulent way, he or she ought to have been acted against by the Government. I will refer later to the types of advice that the Government said it has received on this issue. I believe that the central issue in this debate should be this: What justification can possibly be offered for making a person suffer on account of actions which were legal? That is what this legislation is about. It is seeking to make people suffer on account of actions that were legal. Senator Walters put the proposition that this is not retrospective taxation and that there is no new tax in this Bill. That is a highly idiosyncratic view, and indeed I do not expect it to be voiced again in this debate. That view has been voiced by nobody else in the community and, presumably, is held by Senator Walters alone.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is-it is not disputed even by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-that people will be liable to pay tax on the basis of acts which, when performed, did not attract tax consequences. I think that is beyond doubt. The point that Senator Walters was endeavouring to make-I think it is an important one and needs to be met-is that many of the vendor shareholders who are to be taxed under this legislation certainly were aware at the time that for the sale price that they were receiving the person they were selling to must in some way be avoiding tax. I believe that in almost the majority of cases that was probably so. I do not say that in respect of all cases because I believe it is impossible to assert that. Indeed I had representations from people who were able to convince me that at the time they did not know. But let us take it that in the majority of cases they knew that the company or the person they were selling to would in some way be avoiding tax .

The point at issue is whether they could also have genuinely believed that those people were able to avoid tax legally-in other words, whether they could engage in a variety of activities which would legally give them relief from that tax. I shall mention some procedures which are currently available to anybody who wishes to do that. For example, if one sought to enter into a scheme which is accepted by the Department of the Treasury to pay interest to an overseas organisation the position is that the interest paid by an Australian company is fully tax deductible and only 10 per cent is payable to the Australian Taxation Office on behalf of the overseas recipient. That procedure is perfectly legal today, and it is unaffected by this Bill. A person could sell a company for more than its value and know that the purchaser would not pay tax on the transaction. Under the provisions of section 23 (jb) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, if that friendly overseas financier happened to be a superannuation fund which is not subject to tax in its own home country-and that is often the case-no Australian tax is payable on any amount of interest or dividends paid to it. This section became effective on 1 January 1968 and is still operative.

The Income Tax Assessment Act also exempts from tax the dividends received by public companies from private companies. Thus, if the shareholders of a private company wished to avoid tax legally on the accumulated profits of previous years , they merely had to find a public company to buy their company. This procedure is still available and is unaffected by this Bill. In other words, there are legitimate ways by which a purchasing company could have a reasonable expectation of avoiding tax. Surely, it is not possible for the Treasurer to maintain that everybody who went into such a scheme was engaging in a fraudulent act. Let us allow that that was the case; we still run into what I believe is an extremely important principle. And it is a very simple one. If what the person was doing was fraudulent, that person too is entitled to his or her day in court . After all, we even allow murderers and drug runners a day in court; yet in this case we are introducing legislation which will state: 'You are guilty'. In other words there will not be the opportunity for a person, in meeting the requirements laid down in this Bill, to be able to say that he or she is innocent. We find, for example, as will be the case in the Committee stage, some extremely odd and idiosyncratic drafting which we cannot find in other Commonwealth Bills and which makes it almost inevitable that the person appearing before a court will be declared guilty.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have denied, on behalf of the Government no doubt, that they had any knowledge prior to 1977 of the form of avoidance which is dealt with by this Bill. Yet, this legislation is to be retrospective to 1 January 1972 because the Treasurer says that these schemes were practised on a wide scale shortly before that date. Quite frankly, if that does not condemn out of his own mouth the chief taxation officer of this land and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) I do not know what does. We have, on the one hand, the proposition that this tax avoidance was being practised on a wide scale and, on the other hand, a denial by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of any knowledge of it. Surely those two statements cannot go together. Surely they are incompatible. Yet officers of this Government-the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-are seeking to maintain a holier than holy stance. They say that it was nothing to do with them and certainly they knew nothing about it at the time. What precisely could be defined as a wide-scale practice if it never came to the attention of the Department of the Treasury?

Senator Walsh drew an analogy between people who avoid tax and a pensioner who is overpaid. He made the point that the pensioner who is overpaid, through no fault of his own, is required to repay the money. Although such a practice might be hard, it is fair and I think it is accepted within our community. However, that is not a fair analogy. We are not talking about an illegal action. We are talking about a piece of legislation which seeks to make illegal an action which was legal at the timne it occured. If the act was illegal, surely a law must have been breached. If a law has been breached a prosecution ought to be made. But, quite apart from considerations of social morality, greed or whatever else one wants to consider, if the act was not illegal the person concerned was entitled to engage in it.

Notable upholders of civil liberties in this place, such as Senator Button and Senator Evans, would be considerably put out if we were to debate other immoral and unethical matters. For example, some people believe it is immoral to smoke. Some others believe it is immoral to drink. Others believe it is immoral to use contraceptives, others to have blood transfusions and others to work on Sundays. There is a wide range of beliefs in this country about morality and ethics. The law, except where it explicitly seeks to take a moral stance, does not apply to activities which may be considered immoral. I think it is incontestable that if there is no law governing a particular action, a person is legally entitled to engage in it, whether it is morally supported or not.

I, and I believe, most honourable senators condemn tax avoidance actions as being against the best interests of the Commonwealth and the citizens of Australia. Nevertheless, I could not vote for a law which now seeks to make illegal actions which were legal at the time they occurred. I believe that every person in this community is entitled to know the legal consequences of his or her actions at the time he or she undertakes them. That seems to me to be a principle that we ought not to go past.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not say it was legal to conspire to defraud the Commonwealth, do you?

—I do not. In fact, I have already said that I believe that a vast majority of those actions were illegal. If they were fraudulent, as the Treasurer keeps asserting, it is possible-the Commissioner of Taxation has the power to go back to 1972-to require that those people pay tax. I am objecting to the inexcusable dereliction of duty of this Government which is now seeking in a shoddy way to put onto others in the community what it itself was not able to take on.
—Not able or not prepared?

—It was certainly not prepared. Indeed, it would probably be more just to bring into this Parliament a Bill to confiscate the property of members of the Cabinet since 1972 to pay some of the bill for the lost revenue. I am sure that members of the Cabinet would speak against such a proposition as would probably every member of the Senate. But that is the type of legislation that we are talking about. It affects citizens outside this place. The people in power in this land are protecting themselves by introducing legislation that will hurt others. They are quite happy to stand up everywhere and proclaim that what they are doing is fair. That is the hypocrisy of the whole exercise we are considering today. The actions of this Government and the Cabinet reek of hypocrisy. They are seeking to blame others in the community so that they can rescue themselves from the results of their dereliction of duty.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government was unwilling to charge those people who were, on the say-so of the Treasurer, engaged in fraud surely the Treasurer and the Prime Minister must stand condemned. There can be no other explanation. The explanation that the Government has sought to give cannot be accepted. The Government proclaims that it had legal advice that such action was not possible. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister have denied publicly to every vendor shareholder the claim that the taking of legal advice is a justifiable excuse. As a result they have destroyed their own single argument as to why they should not stand condemned. If the Senate could get hold of the documents which have been denied to it we would undoubtedly find within them that the Government had strong advice that it ought to have taken legal action. I believe that is why this Government has sought time and again to prevent the Senate from getting hold of those documents . The Government seeking to cover its own shameful acts in the past. That it should then seek from honourable senators an acquiescence to this law I find not only reprehensible but also shameless.

A most disturbing aspect has been raised in the debate that has gone on in the Parliament and in the rest of the country. We are now seeking to visit on every citizen who may have engaged in a particular act the consequences of the doubtless wrongs that some have undertaken. We have had here-thank goodness we have not had it in this debate today-an attempt on the part of a number of honourable senators to say that anybody who would raise his or her voice against this retrospective legislation must be a friend of tax dodgers and tax evaders. The hysterical pronouncement on national television by the Prime Minister attempted to do precisely that. A memorandum drafted in August 1936 by Adolf Hitler, which became the basis of the infamous Nuremburg laws, laid down the principle that the Jewish community as a whole should be responsible for any damage done to the German economy by individual Jews. Not one voice was raised when that law went through. I am pleased to be able to argue in this place against this retrospective law. I am also pleased that we live in a country where other honourable senators also have been able to argue against such a law. At least this debate suggests that democracy is still alive in this country and that people are willing to stand up and fight for principles no matter how unpopular they may be.

I come finally to the point that is the sticking point for me. I do not wish to vote for a law unless a person is able to be innocent, and to proclaim his innocence, of breaking it. Retrospective legislation is not that type of legislation. Whilst the government, by enactment, may reach backwards, the vendor shareholder is not likewise entitled to reach backwards and change his or her action. If that were to be permitted, if the vendor shareholder could opt to change his or her action retrospectively, we would doubtless have equivalence. This legislation enables the Government to reach back to 1972, but does not enable someone who engaged in a certain action in 1972 to reach back and say: ' If that is now to be the consequence of my action, I will choose another'. Surely that is the effect of the legislation that we are now proposing to enact. We are now proposing to say: 'What you did I now declare wrong. I also declare that you shall not be able to change it'. When any other law is enacted in this place we say: 'This is wrong and if in the future you undertake that action you will be penalised'. That enables every citizen contemplating the legislation to say: 'If I do that, these will be the consequences'. In other words, every citizen will know the legal consequences of his or her actions. This legislation will affect a group of citizens who, between 1972 and 1980, were unable to know the consequences of their actions.

I believe that the Government's motivation in introducing this retrospective legislation is quickly to collect tax from vendor shareholders without having to prove them guilty of fraud. I believe that to do such a thing by legislative fiat is objectionable, abhorrent and against the good order of the Commonwealth. I do not say that all retrospective legislation is wrong. Indeed, in many cases it could be legitimate and those to whom it applies could accept that fact. Honourable senators will remember the second last pay rise we received. We passed a piece of retrospective legislation because all of those to whom it applied, in this place and in the other, said: 'Yes, we'll pay back that extra amount of money'. In other words, there are cases where retrospective legislation can be legitimate. But it cannot be legitimate when it applies to citizens who did not wish their legal actions to be deemed illegal. I hope that the Government, even at this late hour, will look again at this legislation. I have no doubt whatsoever that it will be effective, but lynching is extremely effective also. I am not disputing the effectiveness of this legislation; I am disputing its justice. I believe it would be far better if those who supported it actually said that in this instance they were supporting injustice and gave their reasons. Then at least we would have an honest debate in this place and would all know where we stood.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting as melodramatic as your leader.
—I believe that this legislation will have unfortunate consequences.
—This is sanctimonious humbug.
—He is working on it. He is not quite up to that standard yet.

—A couple of honourable senators have just come into the chamber and decided that they will play a funny game. I believe that this is extremely serious legislation. Whilst Senator Chaney and Senator Evans may indeed believe that it is funny, many people in this country do not believe that it is in any shape or form. I hope that when those honourable senators speak they will seek to contribute to the debate in a sensible and straightforward manner. I hope they will try to talk about the legislation instead of seeking to make jokes and poke fun at the many problems that this legislation will raise within our community. We cannot predict the economic consequences. All honourable senators are probably aware that many in this country will become bankrupt as a result, that many will be forced to fold up their companies, that many will become unemployed. If those were the consequences of a legitimate piece of legislation it could be accepted. The fact that they will be the consequences of illegitimate legislation merely adds to the unfortunate aspects of its proposed enactment.

SPEECH.PARA: At the second reading stage I will vote against this legislation. If, as seems evident from the numbers in this place, it is given a second reading I will seek to move certain amendments and will also support particular amendments moved by other honourable senators. I hope that at the Committee stage it will be possible at least to ameliorate in some way the problems that many in this community will face as a result of the breaking of a principle on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support justice and equity. Therefore I support these Bills. Currently we are debating five Bills cognately. These Bills involve the collection of tax from vendor shareholders and promoters and the levying of tax. The principal Bill, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill sets out the basic conditions of liability and contains some necessary machinery provisions. These Bills also impose a rate of tax. It is necessary to have a separate Bill relating to promoters to bring them within the scope of this legislation. The Bills seek to recoup tax which is legally payable. The Government is seeking to recoup tax from people who derived a taxation benefit; nothing more, nothing less. The Bills relate to the period from 1972 to 1980 because since 1980 we have had on the statute books the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act and Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The latter legislation has proved particularly effective in wiping out a whole host of tax avoidance in this country. But, I repeat, the basis of this legislation is to provide taxation equity.

SPEECH.PARA: Our opponents to this legislation have asked why we have not acted under existing legislation. Let us look at the existing legislation under which, according to our opponents, we should have tried to bring people to justice. Firstly, it was suggested that we use the companies Acts. The relevant section of the Victorian Companies Act is section 374 which deals with offences. The first part of that section deals with officers. The penalty for offences against Division 1 is imprisonment for three months or a $500 fine. Is that adequate to deal with offenders who trade in millions of dollars and who cheat the Commonwealth of millions of dollars? Indeed, the Commissioner of Taxation may have been able to make out a case against a vendor of shares where that vendor knew or ought to have known that the only way the sale of a company could proceed, in economic terms, would be with the Commissioner being a creditor and with that creditor being defrauded. But such cases would have had to be dealt with State by State under the various companies Acts. Such a course would have been completely inadequate in dealing with fraud on this scale.

The other legislation mentioned is the Commonwealth Crimes Act. Every honourable senator would be aware of the Western Australian case. The advice that was given to the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of that case was that a prosecution would not succeed. In other words, there was a high risk or a great doubt about that case succeeding. Is this the sort of legislative basis upon which tax evaders should be prosecuted? What happened? The Commissioner asked that that matter be reviewed. Again what happened? On further advice this Parliament set up the position of Special Prosecutor and already one individual, named Maher, has been charged under that Act.

A question was raised about recovering tax under existing legislation. There is a difficulty because the existing companies have been reduced to a shell and there are no assets from which to pay. It was not one of the normal complicated taxation schemes such as the Curran scheme. It was a relatively unsophisticated scheme whereby a company which traded during the year and had a current year's profits had, by its directors, been reduced to a shell. That shell represented nothing but cash on the one hand and on the other hand unappropriated profits, which included profits for the current year. The directors sought a purchaser. That purchaser then acquired the company, in most cases, at a price which excluded a tax liability on that current year's profits. This is something like getting $150 for $100 cash. It is the same sort of thing. Who missed out? The taxpayers, the people of Australia, missed out.

Yet we talk about justice. These people have got away with hundreds of millions of dollars. Senator Chaney, the Minister for Social Security, is in the chamber. I ask him: What would have happened to pensioners who had been overpaid? They would have been asked to return the money. In many cases some of them have been taken to court. This legislation seeks to provide a reasonable base of certainty under which taxation revenue, legally due to the Commonwealth, can be collected on a fair basis, State by State, across the board, irrespective of whether the taxpayer is a primary producer, farmer, businessmen or whatever. I think it is an injustice that ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayers in Australia have had to carry a taxation bill disproportionate to their means while others have been allowed to get away without paying tax. This Government seeks to remedy that. In seeking to remedy that it has drawn a fair amount of flak.

The recoupment tax legislation applies equally to ordinary company tax (that is tax on a company's taxable income) and undistributed profits tax (that is additional tax under Division 7 of the income tax law on the undistributed income of a private company).

In the example given (and assuming the year of income is 1979-80 and all the income up to the date of sale was trading income) the contingent undistributed profits tax liability of the company at the date of the sale of the company would have been $8,100. The undistributed profits tax liability of the company for the whole year, assuming no dividends were paid by the company in the prescribed distribution period would be $20,250 (a private company must distribute at least 90% of its after tax income from interest to avoid undistributed profits tax).

A vendor shareholder who held 100% of the shares in the company would, if none of the company tax were paid, become liable under the proposed recoupment measures for vendors recoupment tax of $8,100 in relation to the unpaid undistributed profits tax liability of the company.

A liability would, prima facie, arise in relation to ordinary company tax of the company up to the date of sale, if this had not been paid, but if the promoter had taken off with the whole of the $46,000 set aside for ordinary company tax the Commissioner would be empowered to cancel that prima facie liability.

If the company had incurred a loss after its purchase of $50,000, the vendor shareholders could (depending on the circumstances) get the benefit of that loss in any calculation of their recoupment tax liability. It is not possible to determine precisely what that liability would be unless the nature of the loss is known and the effect that the current year loss provisions of the income tax law have in relation to it.

Companies 1 and 2 have provided for all income taxes currently accrued up to the date of sales. TALK.START.PARA: —There are really two types of schemes. I have outlined the general nature of what is known as the current year's profits schemes which are the subject of this legislation. In some cases the directors, having been directors of a company that traded during the year, had no further use for that company. But in selling that company they deducted from the sale price the tax liability for the period in which it operated. It would appear from this legislation that under those circumstances the only liability that the vendor shareholders would have to meet would be the Division 7 tax. I think this is one of the unfortunate features of this legislation. I think a lot of businessmen may have sold such a company, after having deducted the primary tax, genuinely thinking they could have sold it to, say, a public company. If it had gone to a public company the dividend that would be required would be fully rebateable under section 46. The end result would be that there would be no further tax liability.

SPEECH.PARA: However, one of the tragedies is that these people, having done the right thing under the legislation, are caught up with those who knowingly operated companies for a period during a year and paid no recognition to their tax liability when selling that company. Obviously they had criminal or defrauding intentions in mind. It is regrettable that both these classes of directors are unfortunately caught within this framework and are labelled by some in the community as cheats , liars, tax defrauders and so on. But I wish to point out that this legislation does not seek to provide or impose a criminal liability. All that it seeks to do is to recoup tax. So perhaps that charge that is laid is a little unfair.

Perhaps the other unfortunate feature of the legislation is that it does not distinguish between tax evasion, on the one hand, and tax avoidance, on the other hand. Many people think that there should not be a distinction, but in law I think that there is and always will be a distinction. But we are now creating a precedent whereby, effectively, in this legislation there is no distinction between tax avoidance and tax evasion. That is one of the unfortunate fall-outs. Nevertheless, we must be guided by the overriding consideration which is that in this legislation we seek to provide tax equity and tax justice to make sure that tax can be collected from all those who have had a tax benefit by some sort of arrangement, either deliberate or otherwise, during the relevant period. So the legislation seeks to recover the tax from the companies themselves, if people care to try to reconstruct them, from the vendor shareholders who benefited, and from the promoters and their agents. There are also tracing provisions, because many of the promoters acquired a debt in minimising their tax liabilities to enable it to be traced through trusts and the like.

I think that the legislation is inherently fair. It does not seek to challenge the small man, because where the assessments are less than $100 the Commissioner of Taxation will not be seeking recoupment. The legislation is very fair in that the people who have got the benefit have had a generously long period in which to pay the money back. For example, there was a possibility that two companies could have been stripped in 1975 but the Commissioner may not have issued the assessment notices on the same date. There could have been three or four years difference. Had we not agreed to issue copy assessments on which the liability for both cases will be due on the same date, we could have unfairly had a situation in which one person's penalty at 20 per cent could have commenced two or three years or more before another's, and at 20 per cent that would have been a high price to pay. But we are issuing copy assessment notices which will apply from a common date for all classes of people involved under this legislation. What could be fairer than that?

Because of liquidity problems that it could force upon some businesses and others, the legislation has generously provided a period of 12 months in which to pay without penalty. So it will not be necessary to force quick liquidations of stock at uneconomic prices. It will not be necessary to close down businesses or to sack people in order to get the cash in hand. They are being given 12 months, and I have been told that that is a generous and most reasonable exercise, remembering that these people have had interest-free money for a number of years. But it is not penalty-type legislation at which we are looking. We are looking at legislation which is inherently just and inherently fair.

I was rather disappointed that Senator Button felt that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) had not acted with due expedition. Senator Button asked what the Government was doing when all this was happening in 1978. The allegation, essentially, was that the Government was protecting the tax avoidance industry. It is only fair to try to protect the Treasurer by giving one or two dates to show what he did in this period. I shall go only to 1978, because the record is continuous. On 8 February 1978 the Commissioner of Taxation advised the Treasurer of the High Court decision in what is known as the Cridland case, which involved exploiting the averaging provisions and involved a potentially large revenue loss. On the same date, the Commissioner also advised the Treasurer in relation to trafficking current year company losses involving significant losses of revenue. On 10 February the Commissioner advised the Acting Treasurer of share trading schemes that had come under his notice. On 31 March there was further advice in relation to Curran schemes, and the figures quoted were up to $2,000m.

But in response on 7 April, in the same year, the Treasurer introduced legislation against averaging, share trading and Curran schemes, and he informed the House that the Curran schemes provisions would be made retrospective to the 1977 Budget day. Again, he acted very quickly. At the same time, he forshadowed to the House that current year loss schemes in the area of avoidance would attract remedial legislation, and legislation was introduced on 16 November 1978 . On 19 April 1978 the Treasurer foreshadowed legislation against pre-payment schemes. On 24 May 1978 the Commissioner advised of problems in relation to trust stripping schemes. On 9 June the Commissioner advised of the retention of carry forward losses generated by Curran-type schemes. On 11 June the Treasurer foreshadowed legislation against trust stripping schemes. On 27 July the Commissioner advised of expenditure recoupment schemes. On 1 August the Commissioner advised of the Nilsen Development Laboratories Pty Ltd schemes, which involved a revenue loss of $600m. On 7 April the Commission advised of amounts involving $3.9 billion on a variant of the expenditure recoupment scheme . The action came on 24 September of the same year, when the Treasurer foreshadowed legislation against recoupment schemes and the latest trading stock adjustment schemes. On 27 September the Treasurer foreshadowed legislation which would have remedied the problem in the Nilsen decision. On 3 October he foreshadowed legislation against Curran schemes.

There is the record. The amounts quoted in some cases were horrendous. In one case it was $3.9 billion. To allege that our Government has done nothing in that period against tax avoidance is to deny the truth of what John Howard has been fighting desperately against ever since he became Treasurer, as did his predecessor, Sir Phillip Lynch. I think that there have been between 16 and 19 Acts involving nearly 50 sections being added to legislation with the intent of overcoming taxation avoidance. So the record is there. I have given just one year's record. I have not cited all the cases. The record stands, and it is one that Australian taxpayers should recognise. It is that we as a Government have been in the forefront in combatting tax evasion. Some of the opponents of this legislation intend to introduce an innocence clause. I submit that the introduction of an innocence clause would serve the purpose of completely wiping out the effectiveness of this sort of legislation. What are we trying to do? Are we behind the Government in trying to overcome all these problems in relation to tax avoidance or are we not? We are genuine.
