The legislation has been extended to cover a liability on promoters. When it was first mooted the legislation was designed to recover money from the vendor shareholders who benefited. But it was felt unreasonable that the people who were the real perpetrators of these schemes should not get off scott-free. So we looked at what was the average remuneration to these people. It was something like 12 1/2 per cent on profits. The legislation contains provisions which impose a recovery of 20 per cent of the tax outstanding which represents something like 12 1/2 per cent on profits. But that 20 per cent recovery from the promoters and their agents-which is important-will be deducted from the liability of the vendor shareholders so that no more than 100 per cent of the tax owing will be recovered from any transaction. To overcome some of the complications a class of shareholders is set out whereby a representative group is selected to whom the assessment will be issued. The legislation provides a means whereby a vendor shareholder, if he wishes, can pay his tax liability notwithstanding that others within the company arrangement or other shareholders may object.

I think this is important, because of the complexity of this legislation, that the people involved-the vendor shareholders and promoters -have been given this 12 months in which payment can be made. The legislation also covers situations in which not all the shares are sold. These shares are mortgaged and the tax avoiding arrangements of this implication are to avoid stamp duty, particularly in South Australia. The company then defaulted under the mortgage and that was the tax avoiding arrangement. This legislation seeks to cover that type of situation. Not all voting rights attach to shares. Some attach to the officeholder, principally to a governing director. In this case, under the legislation, the governing director is assessable on the basis of the consideration that he received. What could be fairer? The whole purpose of this legislation is to provide justice and fairness. If there be anything said against this legislation it may be that we have bent over backwards to try to make it fair. We have made it perhaps a little too complicated to achieve fairness and I do not think this is unreasonable.

The legislation extends to what is known as blind trusts to cover eventualities and to enable tax to be assessed at what is known as a secondary level. In the limited time available to me let me summarise the legislation. The law will apply only to those who have derived a tax benefit, to a promoter or his agent who have received a consideration under the scheme. Fraud does exist. What the legislation will do is allow money which is owed to be collected. There are essentially machinery provisions but there are also necessary taxing provisions. On page 98 of the Costigan report on the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union it is stated:
The object of tax avoidance schemes is to avoid the payment of company tax on a company by leaving only a shell of a company with no assets to pay that tax.

How else is the Commissioner of Taxation expected to collect money when there are no assets from which to pay the tax? I repeat that the Government has bent over backwards to make the law fair to all. No assessments will be issued for small amounts of less than $100 thus missing out on what might be called the innocent little people; so the small people will not be affected. There is equity in the legislation because copies of the provisions will be issued on a common date. Penalties will operate only when the taxation that is due has been evaded. I think the legislation is inherently fair. I mentioned that in 1980 we introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill, which provided severe penalties- a $50,000 fine or 5 years gaol-and since 1980 this has effectively wiped out the sort of thing that we are seeking to recover in respect of the period 1972-80. May I quote from a letter of 31 August from Dr Forbes, Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia. It states:
Executive does not like the element of retrospectivity involved in proposed new legislation, but accepts the inevitability of this in the circumstances.
The circumstances were so horrendous, so unusual, so much revenue was lost and so many people benefited at the taxpayers' expense. The letter continues:
It believes it is an occasion when the pursuit of tax evaders-and a fair go for the community as a whole-is the most important of the competing principles.
I think this is the basis on which this legislation has to be judged. I support the legislation and wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Previous Australian Labor Party speakers have made it perfectly clear that we will support this legislation but if ever legislation justified a description of too little, too late it is this package of measures. I say that for three reasons. Firstly, there would never have been legislation at all if the Government had not been embarrassed into it by the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Secondly, the legislation would never have been necessary if the Government had been doing its job properly in the mid 1970s and had moved quickly in that period to choke off the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme promoters before their activities became rampant the way they subsequently did through that inactivity. The third reason we say this legislation is too little too late is that it simply will not succeed in recovering the money that it should be recovering from the people it should be recovering it from.

SPEECH.PARA: There are gaping loopholes in the way in which this legislation has been constructed. Although a macho front has been to some extent maintained and reported in the media the reality of this situation has been that there has been a quite craven capitulation to some of the Government's closest supporters of the tax avoidance industry. An extraordinary impression seems to have been gaining ground in recent weeks that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has turned the tax argument around. Far from his Government being seen as producing the problem through its scandalous inactivity it is now seen, some people say, that the Government is legislating with salutary toughness and as a result putting itself beyond effective criticism so far as tax avoidance and evasion are concerned. I think it needs to be said, as it was said rather less politely by my colleague Senator Walsh earlier, that if this impression is gaining currency then that represents a massive failure of perception on the part of those who report and analyse events. The reality is that this Government's reaction, here as everywhere else in its alleged campaign against tax avoidance and evasion, has been belated and feeble and it deserves not congratulation but condemnation for that record.

I will substantiate those claims, beginning with the belatedness of this legislation. Of course, the background to it is what has been described on numerous occasions as the greatest failure of public administration in the history of this country. I am talking, of course, about the tax avoidance and evasion explosion which took off in the mid 1970s, in circumstances where tax avoiders got cheekier and cheekier. As the Government's inactivity on some of these schemes grew unbelievably protracted, the schemes in question grew cruder and cruder.

The bottom-of-the-harbour chronology is now very well known. It has already been adverted to by a number of speakers in this debate. Back in 1974 the first of the straw company evasion activities was identified by the Australian Taxation Office and in Perth a clear cut test case came to light in that year which seemed to be a model opportunity for full scale investigation and quick enforcement action.

That investigation was mounted efficiently by the Taxation Office, opinions were sought and obtained from learned counsel, Mr Brinsden, late in 1974 and early 1975, suggesting clearly that there were grounds for proceeding both by way of criminal prosecution and civil recovery through the law of misfeasance. By August 1975 things had proceeded to the point in relation to that fundamentally important Perth test case where the Australian Taxation Office had authorised the Deputy Crown Solicitor to proceed to prosecute the people involved under the conspiracy provisions of the Crimes Act.

But there in August 1975 the matter rested. A year later there was a police report which confirmed, in the view of the police, the ability of criminal prosecution to succeed. From time to time other opinions were obtained in relation to other cases, all of them pointing in the same direction. But absolutely nothing happened as a result of the default of the Attorney-General's Department which has been the subject of so much debate, quite properly, in this place. By March 1978 the Crown Solicitor was finally prodded into action by the Commissioner of Taxation's giving oral advice that in his view he did not think there was sufficient evidentiary foundation for this matter to proceed. That oral advice was followed, over a year later in April 1979, by written advice- advice still not tabled in this Parliament so that we can see for ourselves its quality, but advice which we are told did in fact occur.

We have been further led to appreciate that for the whole of the period from March 1978 when the Government finally turned its attention to this particular problem until December 1980 when it finally succeeded in legislating effectively -or apparently effectively-against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, we had an unbelievably protracted, leisurely decision making process taking place so far as the drafting of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was concerned-a protracted , leisurely period in the course of which neglect and default to prosecute those immediately involved in the loss to revenue has been calculated at certainly hundreds of millions and possibly thousands of millions of dollars.

The constant theme in this debate has been that the Australian Labor Party's record was not any better so far as tax avoidance and evasion was concerned during its period in office. It is useful to diverge for a moment or two to scotch that particular canard with some new figures that have emerged that make it perfectly clear what the reality of the situation is. One point that has been made constantly is that the notorious Curran tax avoidance scheme was identified and was the subject of a statement by the Treasurer in 1974, but that no legislation was in fact enacted before we were bundled eventually, unceremoniously, out of office in November 1975. It is fair comment that legislation should have been enacted rather than the matter being left in the hiatus that it was. But it is equally fair comment that the incoming Liberal Government, keen if it was to act in these areas, should have, given the lapse of time, been prepared to legislate immediately. But, of course, no such legislation was introduced-not for 12 months, not for two years and not in fact until 1978-against that scheme. So the one criticism with any tinge of reality or force about it collapses so far as that experience was concerned.

The best evidence of the comparative default of the respective governments in this area comes from the figures in successive reports of the Commissioner of Taxation recording the number of identified participants in tax avoidance schemes. The Commissioner of Taxation records in his recently tabled report in the 1981-82 financial year there were 28,366 individuals identified as having taken part, not just in understating their income or things of that kind but in identified tax avoidance schemes. That represented a 27 per cent increase on the number of people so involving themselves in the previous financial year 1980-81. So much for the effectiveness, one might think, of the Income Tax Assessment Act Part IVA amending legislation in that financial year. On the Taxation Commissioner's assessment, the loss to revenue involved in those schemes was at least $1,500m.

The really interesting exercise is to compare the number of participants I have mentioned, 28,366 in the last financial year, with the number in the last period of the Labor Government in 1975-76. The comparable latter figure is 861. In other words, there has been a 33-fold increase over the period between 1975-76 and 1981-82 in the number of identified participants in tax avoidance schemes. That is a difference between hundreds-861-in the last months of our period in office and 28,366 in the most recent financial year. The implications of this utter and humiliating failure to act in the whole tax avoidance and evasion area are, of course, well known.

In our assessment, in figures that we have quite often repeated, the failure to confront the industry of avoidance and evasion has meant that the ordinary taxpaying household in this nation is up for an extra $30 a week on average as a result of that failure to act. The credibility of that figure has been constantly challenged by Mr Howard and others. It might be useful to mention again what the basis of that calculation is so that people can understand the force of what we are saying. It is very simply this: All the best estimates, including that of Mr Eric Risstrom, are that the combined loss to revenue of both tax evasion and tax avoidance, in both cases encompassing schemes and arrangements of a crude as well as a sophisticated kind, is a total of something like $7,000m split roughly down the middle between evasion and avoidance. If we take into account the fact that there are just over 4.5 million households in this nation, the most simple arithmetical calculation will produce the result that the cost of that loss to revenue each year, running at around $7,000m, taking into account all the different forms of avoidance and evasion, is what we have so often stated it to be.

What has been the Government's legislative response to this tax avoidance and evasion nightmare that has been evident for so long? Of course, through most of the 1970s and until very recently the Government's response simply took the form of a series of piecemeal measures-50 or so in total; quite a lot of them-against particular tax avoidance schemes, but always belatedly, always after the event and always in circumstances where the schemers were allowed to get away with at least one year, often two years, of profit to themselves by virtue of the inevitable belatedness of this machinery in catching up with them. There was no general anti-tax avoidance or anti-evasion measures passed until 1980, with the passage eventually at the end of that year of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act -at least three years too late, given the state of affairs that I have referred to before-and in 1981 the passage of the alleged general anti-avoidance provision, the new Part IVA of the tax Act-at least four years too late given the track record that the High Court had been putting up for that period.

There the Government rested with those sorts of measures and those sorts of legislative strategies. There the Government would have gone on resting had it not been for the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports jolting it out of its complacency. The Government has had a profound distaste for the constructive attempts that the Labor Party has been making over the last three or four years to bring forward an alternative approach to the problem of tax avoidance and tax evasion. Firstly, that approach has involved-I will not spell it out in detail as I have done so on other occasions-retrospective legislation against those avoidance schemes that can properly be characterised as blatant and artificial. Secondly, it involved a proper general anti-avoidance provision not just confined, like the present Part IVA to blatant schemes but one which in its application is wide enough, like the old section 260, to pick up many more ambiguous forms of tax avoidance where it is necessary to have the Commissioner' s discretion operating in a not very tightly constrained set of guidelines as under Part IVA. In relation to criminal legislation for crude evasion we have adopted a bipartisan approach with the Government. That is certainly part of the armoury. The fourth element in our approach has, of course, been something which the Government has steadfastly refused to do; that is, to produce a massive upgrading of the resources of the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that the legislation in the books will in fact mean something in the way it is administered in practice.

As I said, nothing occurred from the Government by way of a willingness to talk through these issues in a sensible and constructive way, to think about ways of generating better anti-avoidance legislation than Part IVA, or to think about the circumstances in which retrospective legislation might in fact be appropriate as the best means not so much of recouping revenue but of deterring this kind of activity in the future. That kind of legislation was dismissed as crude, unprincipled and unworthy of attention by this Government. But now, of course, everything has changed. What has changed has not been any intellectual conversion on the part of the Government; it has been a political conversion forced upon it by the embarrassment of the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports . The embarrassment has gone to the extent of forcing the Government, in the now immortal words of Mr Michael Baume, into a situation of 'having to be seen to be doing something'. As Senator Button said earlier, that is exactly what the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill is all about.

It is a very difficult Bill to summarise because of its complexity. It is complex, indeed, to the point of unintelligibility in many respects. This is illustrated by the way in which it is full of drafting difficulties because of the obvious haste with which it had to be thrown together to accommodate the then election timetable of this Government. To the extent that one can summarise it, one can say, of course, very simply that it provides for recoupment of unpaid company tax assessed and due where this is unable to be recovered as a consequence of some fraudulent stripping and dumping operation on the part of the proprietors of the company concerned-a stripping and dumping operation which , of course, in many cases as we now know involved the appointment of sham directors with criminal backgrounds and stripping and dumping operations which involved in many cases the quite literal destruction of the records by tipping them into the sea or otherwise disposing of them. In every case, as everyone now knows, the company was reduced to a mere shell so far as its assets were concerned and, while retaining a formal liability, it is in fact unable to be recovered against.

Confronted with that situation, what this Bill does is to seek to recoup moneys from a particular class of persons-the vendors and the promoters who encouraged the vendors to dispose of their companies in a particular way. The Bill basically does three things to operate the recoupment that is involved. In the first place, it does of course impose a retrospective liability on vendors and, to some extent, on promoters as well. Despite the melodrama with which Senator Macklin invested his contribution to this debate, it is probably fair to say that this legislation operates not so much to make illegal what was legal at the time so far as the vendors were concerned but rather it operates to make them pay rather a lot of money which, at the time, they did not have to pay and which they thought they had got out of paying. That perhaps simply is a semantic quibble. It is undoubtedly retrospective legislation. There is no point whatsoever in trying to hide the fact that people are being subjected to a liability which would not exist in the absence of this particular legislation.

The second element in the legislation is the requirement that those who have to pay up have, in effect, to pick up the full tab of the unpaid company tax. There are all sorts of formulae for adjusting the contribution between the vendors and the promoters. What is involved is vesting in the vendors and, to a lesser extent, the promoters, the full liability for paying the unpaid company tax which has been assessed and making them pay tax which is otherwise unrecoverable .

The remaining aspect of the legislation which has generated so much interest, and in some breasts excitement, is that it does not allow any general claim of innocence to be made. There is a particular context in which an innocence claim can be made. That is the notorious Horgan clause to which Senator Walsh referred and which will be the subject of a good deal of debate at the Committee stage. Generally speaking, it is the case that a general claim of innocence cannot be made in such a way as to avert liability on the part of the vendors. The position is that they cannot claim, in effect, that they knew not what they were doing when some Father Christmas came along and said: 'You have a company with $ 100,000 worth of cashed-up current profits that you want to sell and on which you would have to pay $46,000 in tax to the Taxation Office at the end of this financial year if you didn't sell it. Don't worry, I will give you $90,000, taking $10,000 for myself, because we have got a magic solution, some black box through which we will pass this particular company of yours which will ensure that no taxation liability does in fact have to be paid'.

So the Bill does not take seriously the claims of innocence on the part of vendors who found themselves the proud recipients of Santa Claus treatment of that particular kind. It proceeds on the assumption-an assumption which we in the Australian Labor Party find attractive-that the vendor shareholders in question who sold their companies in these circumstances were very substantially financially advantaged by their participation in those particular sales at that particular time, that if there was any innocence on their part, if there was any ignorance on their part as to what was subsequently going to happen to those shares and to the company in question, then that innocence, that ignorance, was of the constructive or calculated kind. They must have known that, at worst, the companies they were selling were going to end up at the bottom of the harbour or , in some other way, stripped of their assets in some fraudulent scheme. At the very best they must have known that the only way the liability to tax could have been evaded was through the operation of some blatant, contrived, artificial avoidance scheme.

In either case, I would suggest that the moral position of the vendor shareholders is identical. They are not, as a class, in such a moral position as I think ought to attract the serious sympathy of any senator in this place. It is not a matter of imposing retrospective penalties on anybody; it is a matter of requiring vendor shareholders-who made a nice big fat financial killing as a result of their greed at the time in question when confronted with the opportunity to participate in these kinds of sale arrangements, who benefited from that greed and who ought now to pay the price that the rest of the community has had to pay-to pay the taxes that would otherwise have fallen due.

There is a continuing debate, of course-it has recurred again in some contributions today-about the necessity for this legislation doing all those things. The argument is put: How can one say that it is necessary when one also wants to say that the government was at fault for not actively pursuing these people in the mid-1970s when it did have machinery and it did have weaponry at hand with which to pursue them? How can one simultaneously advance both those propositions-that the weaponry was there and was not used and yet, at the same time, say that it is now necessary to employ new weaponry? It might be a conundrum to some people-I can understand it being a conundrum to someone like Senator Chipp, whose grasp of these matters is not notorious for its dexterity or its extent-but the answer is really very simple. There was a remedy. We would better understand it if the Government would continue to table the papers for which we have called setting out the legal opinions on this. I do repeat Senator Chipp's statement that we certainly have not abandoned that particular enterprise of obliging the Government to table the papers in question. One can accept that there was a liability at law, both criminal and civil, such that could have been deployed in the mid-1970s. That deployment of litigation resources in the mid-1970s would have had to be mobilised against only a handful of companies because that is all we were talking about numerically at that time.

The law in question-that of criminal conspiracy on the criminal side and that of misfeasance on the civil recovery side-is rather technical, is rather cumbrous and is rather difficult to apply. It is the cased now that with not a mere handful of companies involved but some 4,600 companies involved it would as a practical matter be quite inconceivable that this law could be applied systematically across the board so as to recoup successfully the amount of money that seems to be here involved. I note that the Government is, of course, mobilising teams of special prosecutors to ensure that some prosecution activity goes on and that some people at least end up getting their just criminal desserts. But it simply is nonsensical to say that the kind of weaponry which would have been very successful indeed, had it been used effectively in the mid- 1970s, would now be successful in doing the full range of the thing that this legislation purports to do.

I have talked about what the legislation does and why in general terms it is justified in seeking to do that. What I have not yet said anything about is what the legislation does not do. I think it is important if one is making out a case , as I want to, for the feebleness basically of this legislation to draw attention to at least some of the more obvious weaknesses. Many of the points that I want to make can be made, of course, much more elaborately and sensibly in the Committee stage debate. But I think this is an appropriate time to summarise at least what the Bill does not do.

The first thing that the Bill does not do is that it completely fails to recover the money that has been cheated in the same transactions as the bottom- of-the-harbour sales that we are talking about by way of unpaid personal income tax as distinct from unpaid company tax. The present Bill is designed to recover , we are told, something like $620m in unpaid company tax. But it does not operate to do anything by way of recovering between $3000m and $511m worth of unpaid personal income tax that would be payable had the accumulated profits that were also brought into account into these transactions been brought into account and made part of the proper scope of this legislation. Very simply and quickly, something like two-thirds, I understand, of the 4,600 companies which have so far been identified as participating in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes such that they were ultimately stripped, dumped and reduced to shells-

TALK.START.PARA: —Division 7 tax picks up those companies.

—No, it does not. I am talking about circumstances where Division 7 tax has been paid. We are talking about net residual accumulated profits, what is left over and what is legitimately in the hands of a company and could legitimately stay there without being taxed until such time as it is distributed . We are talking about accumulated profits on which tax is payable only when they are distributed and in the hands of the shareholder. In something like two- thirds of the 4,600 companies that are so far involved there were accumulated profits of this residual kind as well as current year profits involved. What has happened is that in the hands of the purchaser strippers those accumulated profits were equally neatly stripped out of the company and distributed but not in such a way as to attract a personal income tax liability, the standard technique for this purpose being the Slutzkin scheme as it operated in the hands of the promoters. That was the more sophisticated way of doing it. The less sophisticated way was for the purchaser-promoter simply to take the money and run. Either way there was a situation where a good deal of personal income tax remained unpaid in relation to accumulated profits that were passed over in the very same transactions as current year profits were passed over by some hungry vendors to the promoters and purchasers involved in these schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to be heard to be suggesting that in every single case where accumulated profits are stripped out of the companies there is necessarily a tax avoidance motive of a blatant, contrived and unambiguous kind such as would properly attract retrospective legislation of this kind. I think it can be argued that sometimes accumulated profits strips occur in the context of legitimate company rationalisation in circumstances where there is no tax avoidance motive. That is another argument for another day. But in the context of these transactions where it is pretty evident, by virtue of the way in which the vendors were disposing of accumulated current year profits, that there was a very clear tax avoidance motive I do not think the moral position of those vendors is any better in relation to their accumulated profit component that they shoved in their pockets than it is in relation to the current year component of the profits they shoved in their pockets. The Australian Labor Party believes this legislation should be extended accordingly.

The second basic weakness in this Bill is, of course, that going back to current year profits simply does not cover that field completely. There is a massive loophole now in the Bill by virtue of clause 3 (12)-the Horgan clause, as Senator Walsh has so properly described it-which will be the subject of detailed attention in the Committee stage debate. It is a disgraceful capitulation on the part of the Government to have made that particular concession-a widely unreported capitulation-and I hope that circumstance changes after the debate here in the Senate.

Another thing that the Bill does not do is cover the field in terms of making life difficult for the current year profit vendors. I am referring in particular to the back-sliding that went on between the first and final drafts of the Bill. Four or five particular areas of back-sliding can be briefly summarised as follows. We had the companies originally being subject to penalty tax for failure to lodge tax returns and for late payment but those provisions were, of course, dropped and the liability was not passed on in that respect to the vendors. We had the late payment penalty being reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. Then we had the Bills being further sanitised by a provision allowing the tax dodgers involved 12 months to pay without penalty-a concession that is simply not nearly so generous in respect to other ordinary and less favoured classes of vendor.

We have a further provision in the latest draft of this Bill reducing or taking away the capacity of the Commissioner of Taxation to name those persons involved in these schemes-again an obvious endeavour to protect well-known Liberal Party identities and supporters from disclosure. We have an extraordinary provision now which enables promoters, for income tax purposes, to claim deductions for the moneys that they pay out by way of their contribution to this recoupment tax . Apart from all these areas of back-sliding we have a failure, as the amendment also states, to deal with other areas of tax evasion involving straw companies. This is, despite all the hairy chested huff and puff that has going on with it a feeble and belated piece of legislation which simply does not deserve the wholehearted support that is being sought for it by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a long speaking list for this debate on a parcel of retrospective tax Bills. Those 10 speakers who have preceded me have contributed much to the debate. In fact, the speaking list on this legislation is longer than any other I can remember for any other Bill coming before this Senate. To avoid repetition and to keep my contribution brief , I will avoid debating the points that have been raised by my opponents in this matter. However, I say to Senator Evans that he is wrong in his basic assertion that the Government has done nothing about tax evasion. No government in the history of Australia has done more than the present Government to close off tax loop-holes. The fundamental problem is the nature of the Income Tax Assessment Act. While we have a document like it we will always have people going through it and beating it. We will not solve the problem until we get a simpler tax Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that I cannot support these Bills. I cannot support them because they are unashamedly and undisguisedly pieces of retrospective legislation. The fact that they are retrospective means that they will have a major and an unfair impact on some members of the Australian community. They will make some actions which were perfectly legal 10 years ago illegal today. Retrospective legislation , except in very exceptional circumstances, is avoided by all governments for it undermines the very basis of the rule of law, the basis on which democratic governments operate. It is banned under the Constitution of some countries. It is specifically against the philosophy of the Liberal Party. It sets a very dangerous precedent. As Senator Martyr so eloquently showed this morning, the opportunities that it provides for the Australian Labor Party to come in with a whole swag of restrospective legislation is quite frightening. For this Government to bring in such legislation shows the level of ignorance in the Executive level as to the difficulties under which the business world operates. The business world simply cannot exist with retrospective legislation. Life is made not only difficult but also impossible if we keep changing the rules under which a company raises its finances.

Running a company is far more difficult and complex than running a family. As companies get larger and larger there are very involved procedures in staying alive in today's environment of high inflation with consequential high interest rates. In the light of legislation as it stands at the present time it is utterly untenable, if we are going to keep people employed in this world, for us to be changing the rules under which companies make decisions.

At this stage, I do not wish to debate the details of the Bills because they are not important. We cannot get away from the central point that the legislation is blatantly retrospective. No amount of dissembling can avoid that. I do not take a position of stating dogmatically that I will never support retrospective legislation. However, I would need exceptional circumstances to do so. I am not convinced by any of the arguments advanced in relation to these Bills that exceptional circumstances apply to them. As a legislator I find it is difficult enough to get people to conform to the law as it stands today without having them worry about what we might do to the law as it existed 10 years back. The ordered social and commercial life of this country would become impossible if we started to do that. Just as no government can legislate to bind a future government as to what its actions from legislative point of view might be, so no government can go back in history and say that what is right in former times is wrong today.

I make it very clear at the outset that I have no truck at all with tax evaders . They have broken the law and there is no penalty too heavy for them. Every Australian should contribute his share, within the legal requirements, to the running and fair cost of living within this country. There is no argument about that. I am very conscious of the political opprobrium that comes from taking a position contrary to that of supporting these Bills. It is not at all a position of support for the wrong-doers. They have got my unbridled contempt. I hope they suffer the penalties for their wrong-doings. Quite clearly, the short-term gain is in supporting these Bills. That is the simplistic view which the public adopts as the correct thing to do. Unfortunately, in the longer term, the security of Australia means that the Bills must be opposed.

Society has to be governed by a rule of law to be fair and just. People who live in the society must obey those laws. There is nothing sacrosanct about laws . They are man made and often imperfect. They are imperfect because people such as us make them. Sometimes they are badly constructed; sometimes they are badly thought through. Of course, quite frequently laws that were once good become inadequate because the circumstances that led to their introduction have now changed. In that situation the correct remedy is to change the laws through parliamentary procedure and to have the change apply to the situation from then on. It is perfectly proper for a Minister or Executive government to introduce a Bill to alter a law which is not achieving the intention of the law when it was passed through parliament. Here, this Parliament clearly is being asked to enter into some retrospective legislation. Having due regard to all the circumstances, I believe that it is very difficult to avoid the conclusion that we are covering up for a lack of appropriate action at the time by the Executive and the Commissioner of Taxation. The Commissioner is a person who already possesses the widest powers of anyone in the whole of Australia.

I return to the rule of law. Liberty is possible only within the rule of law. The alternative to that is a state of anarchy-the rule of the strong, which in practical terms means the rule of the most brutal and the most unprincipled. Therefore, society has to have laws and furthermore society must believe those laws will be applied. As Senator Martyr said, the certainty that the law will be applied is a fundamental part of that doctrine. The certainty that the law will be applied carries with it a presumption that those who conform to the law are safe within the law. Therefore, it is utterly untenable that after the event the law should be changed-in this particular case, up to 10 years after the event.

I find the rationalisation of those who support this legislation to be quite untenable. Broadly, their arguments fall into two classes. The first is that the amount of money involved is so great that it has to be recovered irrespective of the principles involved. I think the assumption is that there is a great deal of money around but I will be very surprised if much money is recovered by this legislation. Perhaps only $200m or $300m will be recovered. Secondly, those who support the legislation frankly concede that it is wrong but they say they are going along with it because it is happening on only one occasion. Both those arguments are intellectually and morally bankrupt. Of course the Australian Labor Party is not inhibited in any way by retrospectivity. Senator Evans has indicated on many occasions what the ALP will do, if it gains power, in regard to retrospective legislation on tax matters. In one statement attributed to him he said that the present legislation is only the thin edge of the wedge. As I said earlier, business cannot live with retrospective legislation with respect to its financing. Of all the people on the Opposition side, probably only Senator Walsh has a glimmer of the truth of that statement.

I will move some amendments in the Committee stage. I do not wish to go through those now but I make some general comments about the legislation. Broadly, the vendors of companies who will be affected by this legislation fall into two groups. The first group of vendors knew full well what was going on. They very clearly set out to defraud the Commissioner of Taxation. The second group of vendors really did not know what was going on and they had no intention to defraud the Commissioner. They did not know that tax would be avoided. I do not know the ratio of the two groups but, at a guess, I would say that those who knew that they were defrauding the Commissioner of Taxation made up the major group and those who did not know were clearly in the minority. However, they would still form a substantial minority. But numbers do not determine justice in our system. Whether only six companies, or even one company, were involved, it would be wrong to penalise one innocent person because the other 99 were guilty. We operate under a rule of law which gives the benefit of doubt.

The people in the first group were involved in a deliberate, fraudulent practice. I have no time for them or their advisers. Fraud is always a criminal offence and it should be prosecuted with the full force of the law. It could have been prosecuted under the law as it existed at the time, for there are and there were laws to cover this fraudulent practice. The point is that neither the Commissioner of Taxation nor the Government took any action under the existing legislation against those people. Royal Commissioner Costigan made a strong case in his fourth report on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union that charges were possible on the grounds of conspiracy. He put forward a very closely reasoned case. But that was never tried. The only example I know of a conspiracy charge being laid against promoters, operators or vendors of companies, is the recent charging of Maher and Faint. I am advised that there may well be difficulties with that charge because there seems to be a view in legal circles that it is very difficult to prove a charge of conspiracy. I would have thought that section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provided an opportunity for the Government to move against fraudulent people in the income tax world without any difficulty at all. Section 231 is in black and white. In part, it states:

231. (1) Any person who, or any company on whose behalf the public officer, or a director, servant or agent of the company, by any wilful act, default or neglect, or by any fraud, act or contrivance whatever, avoids or attempts to avoid assessment or taxation shall be guilty of an offence.

Penalty: Not less than Fifty dollars, or more than One thousand dollars and, in addition, the Court may order the person to pay to the Commissioner a sum not exceeding double the amount of tax that has been avoided or attempted to be avoided.

That is a very simple provision of the Act. I believe that in 1959 Mr Justice McTiernan, in the High Court, used that provision to convict an evader. Apart from that I am not aware of the Commonwealth resorting to the use of section 231 on any occasion since. It seems to be a very simple clause, one that is much simpler to apply than is the charge of conspiracy. It has the great beauty of doubling the taxation penalty. I would have thought that if section 231 had been resolutely applied it would have meant sudden death to all these tax avoidance schemes over the years. But nothing along those lines has been done.

I turn now to the second group-the people who are very disadvantaged by this legislation. They simply acted within the law as it stood at the time and are guilty of no crime whatsoever. Most of these people took professional advice and acted on it. It is quite wrong in such cases to attribute improper motives to their professional advisers because those advisers were bound by law to so advise their clients as to maximise their financial interests. I am very much indebted to Senator Macklin for the way in which he went through some of the examples relating to why people sell companies. Quite simply, in the commercial world there is a whole range of very valid reasons why companies should be sold and disposed of. One simple reason is that the company could be used in primary production or oil exploration and taxation benefits could be legally and legitimately claimed on those grounds. It is quite wrong to attribute to owners or vendors of companies in this category any attempt at tax evasion. In today's commercial world one is often under pressure to operate as efficiently as one can. There seems to be in this Parliament no conception of the great difficulties experienced in times of high inflation, where one is dealing with inventories worth millions of dollars, trying to stay alive, pay income tax and employ people. Equally, there seems to be no appeciation of those difficulties by the Commissioner of Taxation. It is very difficult to trade, to stay in business at the present time-as indeed it has been for the last 10 years.

The proposed legislation would have many consequences. One of the most striking would be that shareholders of a limited liability company would be liable for the debts of that company. That is quite revolutionary. It negates the purpose of having a limited liability company. This means not only that the shareholders are now liable for the debts of that company, namely, a notional income tax, but also for a notional income tax in respect of a company that they no longer own- that they have sold to someone else or that has been sold to several other people. To say the least, this is a most revolutionary move in Australian commercial law. It is rather like a case in which a new car dealer sells a car. It is subsequently sold several times and eight years later is used in a bank robbery. The original dealer then finds that he is charged before the courts as an accessory after the fact in bank robbery. It is just nonsense!

There are certain fundamentals on which society operates. There are bonds of unconscious trust that hold a society together. One is the expectation that other people will obey the rule of law. People who sold these companies quite honestly could rightfully expect that the people who bought them would live within the rule of law. For example, if one went out to drive a car on a public road one would do so always with the expectation that the other road users would obey the rule of law; that they would drive on the correct side of the road and would not kill one in a head-on collision. As taxpayers we all pay our taxes to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. We do that in the expectation that he will bank the money in Consolidated Revenue and not sock it away for a holiday on the Gold Coast. We would not pay our tax if we thought the Commissioner of Taxation was not honest.

The essential point is that the law was altered in December 1980, nearly two years ago. It stopped dead this particular form of tax evasion. It is regrettable that action was not taken before 1980, but a contract was made between the Government, the Commissioner of Taxation and those people. We have to live, as members of the Government, with the contract that existed up to the time of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of December 1980. The whole matter has to be seen in perspective. Bad and all as it might have been, it is only part of the taxation evasion scheme in Australia. The black economy, the cash economy, is probably a far bigger factor than the tax evasion schemes applying to companies. Figures officially quoted for the black economy range between five and 10 per cent. Some figures indicate that it ranges up to 20 per cent of the gross domestic product of Australia. That is really a huge factor. When one gets to figures beyond 10 per cent of the GDP one is getting far beyond the wildest estimates of Senator Evans as to what is happening with these forms of company tax evasion.

As I said at the outset, the basic problem here is the Income Tax Assessment Act. It has now reached a stage where it is beyond reasonable comprehension. It can no longer be fiddled with or fine tuned. It has become the major vehicle in tax raising in Australia. I would like to give honourable senators an example. In 1955-56 personal income tax accounted for 38.4 per cent of Commonwealth Budget revenue. In 1982-83, this fiscal year, it is expected to account for 55.8 per cent. It has now become the major vehicle for financing Federal Budgets. Furthermore, it has an uneven application. In 1954-55 the maximum marginal tax rate began to apply at almost 18 times average weekly earnings. By 1969-70 it began to apply at eight times the average earnings. By 1975-76 it applied at 2.8 times average earnings and the figure for 1982-83 is expected to be two times average earnings. The whole of the Income Tax Assessment Act is moving against an equal and fair distribution of the taxation burden in this country. We cannot fix it under the present system. We must reform both the Income Tax Assessment Act and the mix between direct and indirect taxation.

I was always an advocate against increasing indirect taxation. When I first came into the Senate I spoke against it. But having had the opportunity over the years to see the effect of the present taxation system with relation to personal income tax, I am well aware of the great defects, the unfairness and the sheer impracticality of the present Income Tax Assessment Act. I believe there are unfair elements in indirect taxation, but I do not believe they are beyond the will of man to be compensated for. The great advantage of indirect taxation is that it is harder to evade than direct personal income tax.

With respect to direct income tax, I believe we have to throw out that Act and start again. I would go so far as to say that any political party in Australia which produces a simple, innovative rewriting of the Income Tax Assessment Act would win the next election on that issue alone. I say that because there is such a public outcry against the impracticality, the unworkability and the unfairness of the present Income Tax Assessment Act. I do not know what form the new Act should take, but I certainly have no objection to the proposition that we have a flat tax. I am well aware that if it were imposed in a direct substitutional way for the present Income Tax Assessment Act, gross inequalities and unfairness would be involved. But just as with indirect tax, this can be resolved on a fair basis. All it needs is a bit of thought. The great advantage of an indirect tax is that it would have a degree of simplicity that this present document, which is about two inches thick, can never have.

I do not know what it costs to administer the Income Tax Assessment Act. Some people have spoken today about the poverty of funding given by the Government, to the Commission of Taxation, saying he should be able to employ more assessors to implement this Act. Surely it is wrong to have a tax Act which needs to be administered by an army of people. The administrative costs deny to the people of Australia the benefits of raising income tax. We are not in the business of keeping tax assessors in work. We are in the business of providing services to the people of Australia. If we had a simple tax Act we could reduce dramatically our administrative costs in collecting tax. I do not know the answer to the problems with the present tax Act. But while we have the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 we will always be behind the eight ball because there will always be smart and unscrupulous operators who will be able to pick holes in it, no matter how extensively it is amended. We will always be behind the action. We can never get in front of it. The only answer is to have a different structure. My time is nearly up. I regret that these Bills were ever introduced into this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment by the Australian Labor Party to the motion for the second reading of the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982. I indicate that in the event of the amendment not being supported we will substantially support the Government's position. We disassociate ourselves from the contributions that have been made by those rebel members of the Government who are clearly speaking on behalf of those who have spent a great deal of time in recent months lobbying against the Government's retrospective legislation. I wish to raise several matters concerning tax avoidance and evasion-I referred to it earlier as tax aversion, which I think is a very appropriate description-because it is clear that the tax avoidance and evasion that exists in the Australian community has special application to a small group of people. I refer largely to those in the business sector who have taken advantage of decisions made by the Barwick High Court to avoid meeting their responsibilities and avoid making their contributions to an equitable tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment condemns the Government's dismal record in confronting tax evasion and avoidance. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 is determined to try to close those loopholes which have clearly existed. We have seen divisions within the Government parties and within the Australian Democrats . I am pleased to say that there is no such division within the Australian Labor Party.

We will take every step available to us to make sure that we have an equitable tax system in Australia and that those who earn more, whether as a result of speculation, business acumen or labour, pay their due share of tax. I refer to the comment by Senator MacGibbon that many people who will be caught by this legislation acted in accordance with the law. He went on to say that they went to their lawyers or accountants for the purpose of avoiding tax and they were often given information which enabled them to evade tax. In those circumstances the Parliament is entitled to take whatever steps it deems necessary to rectify that evasion.

It is a fact that this Bill would never have come before the Parliament had it not been for the decision of the Victorian Parliament to establish the McCabe- Lafranchi inquiry. The report of that inquiry gave emphasis to what the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union said about the problem of wholesale tax evasion in Australia. Those reports would have blown this Government away in a gust of popular anger at the tax evasion and avoidance rip-off, if the Government had not acted as it has been forced to act in presenting the Parliament with this legislation.

Our amendment seeks to condemn this Government which has not been persuaded to take the sort of action over the years that would have realised the income of additional millions of dollars that has been lost to general revenue and found its way into the pockets of tax cheats, both shareholder-vendors and scheme promoters. No one can justify these people not being forced now to pay their due share of tax-a huge amount of money. It is difficult to be sure how much is involved, but it certainly must run into billions of dollars which have been lost to the vast majority of people in Australia who pay their tax and who, as a result of that, have found themselves paying higher taxes. This lost revenue has gone into the pockets of the unscrupulous, many of whom are supporters of and office-holders in the Government parties. It needs to be said that the average taxpayer in this country has been forced to pay between $32 and $35 a week more as a result of the activities of these tax cheats. That means that the average person in Australia paying his tax through the pay-as-you-earn system has been paying something like $1,800 more than he should have paid because of the unscrupulous attitude taken by numerous people concerned as they were with avoiding their tax responsibility.

The vendor-shareholders have received capital gains and avoided their tax liability. They did so by utilising the expertise of lawyers and accountants for that purpose. Of course, they were aided in this process by one of the chief tax evaders in this country. I refer to the former Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick, whose judgments clearly have been designed to make the job of the Australian Taxation Ofice in this country more difficult, if not impossible in respect of collecting the tax that was due to the Commonwealth of Australia on the basis of an equitable system. That is why we condemn the Government's inactivity and its protection of its social and economic base over the years 1978 at least, to 1982 until it was forced out of its burrow to bring legislation before the Parliament in order to establish in the public mind that the Government could not but condemn what has been going on surreptitiously over recent years. The point I want to make is the neglect on the part of the Government and the fact that the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes dealt with in this Bill were first detected way back in 1973. Commissioner Costigan said in his report:
This scheme was first detected in a wide spread manner by the Australian Taxation Office in 1973.

Of course, in the early days of this debate the Government sought to suggest that there was some omission on the part of the Labor Government in the year 1974-75 when these matters were brought to the attention of the Government, ignoring the fact that we had taken action to institute administrative steps that would have overcome the problem. That was fouled up in the Perth office of the Crown Solicitor. Initially the scheme was found to be operating in Perth and Mr Costigan, as we now know well, detailed this particular case. A decision was made by the Taxation Office to prosecute the persons involved in one scheme; that is, it was decided that a test case should be run. But unfortunately, as we now know, that was stopped, and the proceedings for prosecution under the Crimes Act for conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth never got off the ground for the reasons outlined in Mr Costigan's report. Both the Crown Solicitor's Office and the Taxation Office were clearly negligent in that repect. Of course, when we consider the political atmosphere in the country in 1974-75 it is clear that people realised that the conservatives generally were destabilising the political processes to such an extent that they were able to sit down and conspire to bring these schemes to fruition, schemes which then began to grow in the early years of the Fraser Government.

I refer to the numerous submissions that the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O' Reilly, put to the Treasurer (Mr Howard). In the tabled documents we see a letter dated 19 January 1978 to the Treasurer suggesting 60 legislative proposals. During 1978-on 13 February, 11 April, 24 May, 1 June and 6 June- memoranda were sent to the Treasurer by Commissioner O'Reilly. What happened on 6 June 1978? The Cabinet could not agree with the submissions and so they were stalled as a result of the inactivity of the Fraser-Anthony administration. Mr O 'Reilly again had to write to the Treasurer on another 11 or 12 occasions over the succeeding three years in order to try to convince the Government of the need for legislative action. He also had to write to the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) pointing out the lost revenue as a result of these schemes and the need for legislation.

It was not until 1980 that certain legislation, which had as its objective a closing down of a number of these schemes, was passed. As we know from the documents tabled in the Senate some time ago, this delay went on as a result of the Government's own procrastination. While this was going on, bottom-of-the- harbour schemes mushroomed. After a series of legal opinions which clearly advised the Government that recommendations for prosecution could be successful, and after some 18 months of communication from the Taxation Office to the Government, action was finally taken, as I said, in the legislation passed in 1980 in the form of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

The Australian Labor Party and I believe-I am sure people outside the Parliament believe this-that this delay was inexcusable and irresponsible and that it amounts to a complete misuse of taxpayers' funds and electors' trust. This Government's neglect and inaction gives the lie to the 1980 election promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He was quoted at large as saying: 'We are clamping down on tax avoidance'. That is what he said at the last election and yet he knew quite well that the years of procrastination by the Government in the Cabinet room were responsible for the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of revenue due from companies and those associated with the shareholding area. What a thing for a Prime Minister seeking re- election to say after he and his Government have let at least $600m in tax-this is admitted by the Treasurer-slip away due to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes over that vital five-year period. This is the Government's own admission. It is suggested by rebel Liberal and National Party senators that we should turn a blind eye and forget about legislation which seeks to recover that large amount of money. That suggestion comes at a time when there is uncertainty in the community, rising unemployment and when States are cutting back their expenditure because of the lack of assistance from the Commonwealth.

The Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports give us some idea of the magnitude of the problem that was allowed to develop in those years by this very neglectful Fraser Administration. Costigan gives the following figures on the growth of the pre-tax profits strip, or the wet Slutzkin schemes as they have been described and as identified by the Taxation Office. In 1973 only 27 companies were involved; in 1974 the number had grown to 65; there were 117 in 1975; and in 1977 the figure grew to 507; in 1979 there were 622; and in 1980 there were 1, 412. So we see the growth in the number of people avoiding their tax responsibilities. Of course Mr Costigan cautioned against the use of these figures, indicating that the extent of the problem may be far worse. The Labor Party believes they are far worse and that that is probably only the tip of the iceberg. Mr Costigan stated:
It should not be assumed that the Taxation Office, even today, is able to prepare an exhaustive list of all companies involved . . .

As I understand it, the New South Wales Government's attempts to look at the problem in the same way as the Victorian Government have resulted in the disclosure of a considerable number of companies in my State which have been involved in these nefarious schemes. Mr Costigan goes on to say:
I am confident they have done their best to find out. Unfortunately, the current investigative techniques are not up to the task in hand.

So here again we have an area of gross neglect by the Liberal and National Party governments. McCabe-Lafranchi alleged that at least 3,000 companies were involved in these schemes. The Tax Office now admits that it believes that at least 6,000 companies were involved in these subversive and nefarious activities .

This is the sort of tax cheating that has been going on while the Fraser Government looked in another direction, concerning itself always with legislation against workers, with attacking everybody else in the Australian community, attacking royal commissioners, the Taxation Office, the Public Service, workers and salary earners-attacking everybody else but itself until finally it has been forced by public opinion to bring this piece of legislation to the light of day. This legislation will be passed only with the assistance of the Australian Labor Party in the Senate. If McCabe, Lafranchi and Costigan had not been diligent in their work and if these reports had not been handed down and the extent of this cheating exposed, we would still not know and this Government would still have been able to avoid and ignore its responsibilities in this area.

The Taxation Office has been given no help in the difficult task of tracking down these cheats. I well recall that Mr Howard, the Treasurer, on his return from overseas attempted to shift the blame for this difficulty on to the Taxation Office. The facilities of the Taxation Office have been allowed to run down as a result of direct decisions of this Government to cut back on staff. Between 1975 and 1981 the total number of staff employed by the Taxation Office fell marginally by 90-that is by 0.7 per cent. However, over the same period the total number of returns lodged increased by 12 per cent. This meant that the number of staff per thousand returns fell from 1.6 to 1.42 over this time-a fall of 11 per cent. At a time when these tax cheats were accelerating their activities, when our population was increasing, when the Australian economy was booming, this Government took steps to restrict the capacity of the Australian Tax Office to collect the tax that was due from one section of the Australian community. Let us have no doubt about it, pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, who represent more than 90 per cent of the Australian people, are not able to avoid their tax responsibility. Mr Deputy President, you, a wage earner, a Commonwealth or State public servant, a local government employee or any worker outside cannot avoid taxation responsibilities. Tax is taken out at the point at which salary is received. So only one section of the Australian community-those people involved in professional activities and company activities-have been taking advantage of the lethargy of the Fraser Administration over the years that it has been in office from 1975 to 1982.

So at the same time as the Taxation Office staff level fell the work load of the Office increased dramatically, as is demonstrated, in the figures to which I have referred. Also, the level of tax avoidance exploded and many new concessions were added to the taxation system. Of course, it is hardly surprising that Professor Russell Mathews, Australia's foremost tax expert, summed up the taxation system as follows:

Whatever the problems and their consequences, tax authorities, governments and the courts have allowed tax avoidance to flourish on such a scale as to make personal income tax a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earners. Despite the emphasis which has been given to vertical equity in the design of the Australian income tax system, the essential problem is not to make the rich pay higher rates of tax, or even more tax, than the poor: It is to make the rich pay any income tax at all. There has recently been some discussion about the potential for a tax revolt in Australia. It must be recognised that a massive tax revolt has already taken place: but it is a revolt of business taxpayers against wage and salary earners, of the rich against the poor.

So the Fraser Government's overall tax record is consistent with its neglect in the area of tax evasion and avoidance. Clearly that indictment by Russell Mathews is one that ought to cause the heads of members of the Senate, especially those of the 10, 11 or a dozen government rebels who are to vote against this legislation when it is finally put to a vote, to hang in shame at the failure of the Government to accept its responsibilities. The Government's record confirms and extends inequity and unfairness and which places the burden on the wage and salary earner. Since Mr Fraser assumed office with the proclaimed aim of lowering of the tax burden and a commitment to tax indexation he has allowed the greatest tax burden ever to fall on the Australian people. This matter of tax avoidance and tax evasion-I emphasise the words 'tax evasion' -is the greatest tax scandal to hit this country this century.

The scandalous taxation record of the Government is very relevant to the Senate 's consideration of this legislation. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill is claimed to be confirmation of the Government's determination to enshrine fairness in the Australian taxation system. Mr Fraser has suggested so much in his address to the nation. He is hanging his hat on this legislation, despite concerted division and opposition in his own ranks. He will need the support of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber to get this legislation adopted. There is nothing fair about the overall taxation system he presides over. It rips the people off. This year, for example, total tax collections by the Commonwealth will represent 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product compared with 23.1 per cent during the last year of the Whitlam Labor Government-and this Government claims that it is a low tax government. The burden of this massive increase in taxation has not been spread evenly over all taxpayers. Ordinary wage and salary earners have been forced to bear the brunt of rising taxes. Tax collections from wage and salary earners, pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, have risen from 41.7 per cent of total tax receipts in 1975-76-the year of the last Labor Budget-to 45.4 per cent under the present Budget. At the same time taxes collected from the business sector, from individual non- PAYE taxpayers-those with incomes from business, properties and dividends and professional persons and companies-have fallen as a proportion of total tax collections. Surely that would have excited the interest of the Government if it were concerned to have an equitable tax system. But no, it asked no questions of the Australian Taxation Office. It accepted the figures it was given without asking any questions. A table I have shows the proportion of total tax collections attributed to PAYE and non-PAYE taxpayers and companies. It has been prepared by the office of the shadow Treasurer and incorporated in the House of Representatives Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate that table.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has that table been shown to the Minister in charge of the House?
—No, Madam Acting Deputy President, I have not seen the Minister about it but I can assure you that it has been incorporated in the House of Representatives.
—I do not foresee any difficulties if it has been approved by the House of Representatives.

—These figures give a clear picture of the basic tax policy of the Fraser Government. It is a redistributive tax policy, one that distributes away from the low and middle income earners. Consequently, it ought to be condemned. In addition to Mr Fraser's regressive income tax policies we have seen indirect tax collections rise by $2,774m in the last two Budgets alone. Sales tax as a proportion of total tax collections has risen from 6.5 per cent to 8.7 per cent in that period. Indirect taxes, of course, fall most heavily on those on lower incomes. They are particularly prone to avoidance and evasion, as recent reports have indicated. This inverted position flows from the failure to collect tax from certain sections of the business community. I concede that most sections of the business community have not been involved in these schemes and that only a small percentage have taken advantage of these nefarious schemes to rob the average Australian taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the background to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill. In summary, this background traces a history of scandalous neglect on the part of the Fraser Government towards tax cheating and a history of regressive and dishonest tax moves by that Government. Now with that history behind him, the Prime Minister is asking the Parliament and the people of Australia to believe that the Bill before us makes up for the years of neglect and for the years of failure to collect the due proportion of tax from a significant section of the Australian people. We say that it does not absolve it from those responsibilities.

The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill is supported by the Opposition. Nevertheless, it is inadequate for a number of reasons. The inadequacies in the Bill have been outlined by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) and the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Evans. Basically the Bill falls short because of these factors: It fails to move to recoup individual income tax which should have been paid on dividends distributed to shareholders in the case of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes-only lost company tax and undistributed profits tax will be regained. It provides a very wide degree of leniency to tax evaders in respect of the time that they are given to pay their evaded tax. It fails to act at all against the dry-Slutzkin scheme which involves the avoidance of tax payable on the profits distributed to shareholders , but upon which company tax has been paid. If the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were really serious about being fair, these cases of blatant avoidance would be mopped up. It fails to act on a wide range of other tax evasion and avoidance schemes, picking up only a tiny proportion of Australia's cheated tax bill.

While the Opposition supports this Bill, it does so to ensure that some other step, however small it may be, is made against the outrage of tax cheating which has been synonomous with the actions of the Government in the last six or seven years. It does so noting also that many in the Government ranks cannot find their way clear to support even this small move. That, in my view, condemns them for all time. The Liberal and National parties are littered with people who oppose this legislation because they benefit from the current scheme. The Liberal and National parties are littered with the new rich of Perth who loll around on their yachts on the Swan River or bask at Rottnest Island. The New South Wales branches of these parties are infested with these tax bludgers. Mr Fraser, desperate for electoral support, has decided to move against some of the more blatant cases of corruption-corruption that is at the very heart of the party that he leads and is found in this Government. This small piece of legislation is all he can come up with. For the sake of the millions of honest Australian taxpayers, the ambit of the legislation needs to be extended. I commend the amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition.

Finally, I want to say a little about retrospectivity. I remind the Senate that , in the early 1950s, allegations were made about a communist. Laws at that time did not cover that case. The Menzies Government had no hesitation in enacting retrospective legislation with the support of the conservatives to deal with that matter because it was not covered by existing legislation. I think it is hypocritical for Government members to get up and say that they are opposed to retrospective legislation when, in fact, they have been party to it on occasions in the past. I find it also inconsistent and unacceptable that Government members can stand up and defend white collar crime which, in the minds of many criminologists, is the biggest form of crime occurring in our country today. Young men-perhaps some young women-who are foolish enough to believe that they can band together and rob a bank and get away with $15,000 or $20,000, when caught will spend six or seven years in a penitentiary for that crime of taking money from an institution. Yet, thousands of people in our community have been involved in monstrous crimes of stealing, not $15,000, $20,000 or $30,000 but millions and millions of dollars. They are the people who should be called to book for the activities in which they have been involved over the last six or seven years.

In conclusion, I am not impressed by the number of letters that I have been getting from the Gold Coast, the north of New South Wales and the North Shore of Sydney suggesting that I ought not to support retrospective legislation, when the writers are living in leisure and taking advantage of loopholes which were given, perhaps, some legal recognition as a result of decisions made by the Barwick High Court. I make no bones about it. I support retrospective legislation when it seeks to establish some equity in our taxing system, when people have set about, through their various means, to evade their responsibilities and have forced ordinary citizens, as a consequence, to pay between $30 and $35 a week more in tax than they would have been taxed if everyone had borne his fair share of the tax burden.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1506) Senator Hearn asked a question without notice relating to the effect of television advertisements and programs on epileptics, to which the Minister for Communications provided a reply in Hansard of 18 August 1982. Supplementary information has now become available through the Minister for Health and is provided for the information of honourable senators as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A computer-based literature survey on the potential for flashing lights triggering off epileptic attacks (of which seizures are only one form) has been done. It appears that flashing lights between 8 and 25 times a second cause the majority of light-induced epileptic attacks. Discotheques, amusement arcade games which display flashing lights to signal the end of the game, faulty fluorescent lighting, lights flickering through trees or venetian blinds, and even a hand waved in front of the face, may all trigger epilepsy. It is not surprising therefore that some special effects on television could trigger such attacks. In fact, for some people, just sitting too close to the television set (even if only the test pattern is being broadcast) may bring on an attack.

While the problem is recognised, it must be emphasised that epileptics form only a small percentage of the population, with those suffering light induced attacks (photolepsy) representing only a small proportion of this percentage. Of these sufferers of photolepsy, only a few will have attacks triggered by flashing light and, of these, only a very small proportion are likely to be affected by flashing light on television.

Industry is aware of this problem and I understand that when it was drawn to the attention of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations some two years ago, they withdrew (voluntarily) one commercial and sought the advice of Professor James McLeod of the University of Sydney. On that advice effects known to trigger attacks have been avoided since.
Similarly, I understand that the lights at discotheques flash at a frequency below which is regarded as likely to trigger photoepileptic attacks.

However, some people may still be affected by 'normal' television. In such cases it has been suggested that the likelihood of an attack being induced by television can be reduced by ensuring that the television is viewed from a reasonable distance (greater than 1.5 metres), in a well-lit room, preferably with a table lamp sitting on top of the television set itself.
